data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself fording the river, all wet and cold from the water. Keeping your eyes on your car, you move slowly across. Look at the car. Look at it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cause a <radical>landslide</radical> so you have to <kanji>shake</kanji> the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to <kanji>wave</kanji> at the ground now.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine shaking your fingers at the dirt. Do you think you can shake the dirt hard enough to cause a landslide (spoilers, no).
data.reading_mnemonic: You think you finally got the earth to <kanji>shake</kanji> but when you look down it's just your <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?!
data.reading_hint: Imagine your shins shaking, your hands are waving, and they won't stop. No! You shouldn't have tried to start a landslide. This was a bad idea!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> going down your <radical>dry</radical> face is just <kanji>sweat</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Sweat really does feel like a tsunami though. Wow, it's dry and hot out right now!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sweat</kanji> isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your <reading>ass</reading> (<ja>あせ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The one place you wish sweat wouldn't go, but somehow it always does: the ass.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>moon</radical>, it’s easy to turn a <radical>pig</radical> into <kanji>pork</kanji>. The low gravity of the moon makes the whole process much easier and cost efficient. Soon, all the pig farming will be done on the moon and there will never be a pork shortage ever again.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine going to a pig farm/restaurant on the moon. You’re in a space suit, eating some space pork. It’s delicious. Imagine the best pork you’ve ever had. This is better than that.
data.reading_mnemonic: At this particular pig restaurant, they have a secret ingredient that goes onto their <kanji>pork</kanji>. Lots and lots of <reading>butte</reading>r (<ja>ぶた</ja>). Okay, so it’s not that big of a secret. But boy is it delicious. Mmm, butter.
data.reading_hint: Butter and pork. A match made in heaven! Imagine yourself scarfing down this buttered pork by the pound. You’re stuffed, but you have to eat more. It’s soooo gooood.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leaf</radical> has to do the same <radical>task</radical> <kanji>again</kanji> and again. Grow out of a tree, change color, fall to the ground, get absorbed back into the tree, then start all over again.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of the tasks a leaf has to do in its lifetime again and again.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once <kanji>again</kanji> the leaf picks up a <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) and cuts itself off of the tree at the end of fall, like some kind of invincible <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Picture a leaf sawing itself off of a tree. Then picture it again. Now picture Bill Nye pointing to it and saying, "This leaf is a cyborg. See how it has little robot parts, allowing it to do this again and again?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> with another <radical>woman</radical> and, with your <radical>fingers</radical>, <kanji>adjoin</kanji> yourselves together. You are united, you are one.
data.meaning_hint: Look around you. Other women are adjoining their fingers and standing with you. There's hundreds, no, thousands of you standing together.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of the women who are now <kanji>adjoin</kanji>ing together are in <reading>sets</reading> (<ja>せつ</ja>). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison.
data.reading_hint: Picture a bunch of women protesting together. They're holding hands in sets, adjoined together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There once was an <radical>animal</radical> with an <radical>insect</radical> friend who felt very <kanji>alone</kanji> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this animal and this insect. Let’s say it’s a flea and a dog. Imagine them going everywhere together. To the park, getting ice cream, even the drive in movie theater. They’re inseparable.
data.reading_mnemonic: One activity that the animal can never do <kanji>alone</kanji> is solve Su<reading>doku</reading> (<ja>どく</ja>) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.
data.reading_hint: Picture this animal with the insect on his head doing a Sudoku. See the insect hopping around on the animals head shouting answers and suggestions into the animal’s ear. How cute.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fortune</radical> radical and the <kanji>fortune</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! But it also means <kanji>occupy</kanji> as well, so don’t forget that. Fortune and occupy both occupy the same radical.
data.meaning_hint: Just remember that this kanji also means occupy and you’ll be just fine.
data.reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>occupy</kanji> some free time you have, you go and get your <kanji>fortune</kanji> told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting your fortune told by a centaur fortune teller. Do you trust this mythical beast to know your future? Watch him manipulate his crystal ball as his hooves stomp the ground beneath him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone is reaching out with their <radical>fingers</radical> to <radical>call</radical> for you. They <kanji>beckon</kanji> you closer, this way.
data.meaning_hint: Something about the way they're beckoning you with their fingers is really enticing. You can't help but walk toward them.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person <kanji>beckon</kanji>ing you is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call.
data.reading_hint: Even if the Shougun didn't have an army that would crush you if you didn't come when he called, you'd go anyway. Those beckoning fingers are just so... weirdly enticing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Cut this <radical>comb</radical> up with your <radical>weapon</radical> and turn it into the <kanji>steps</kanji> for some <kanji>stairs</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: When you think about it, a comb is like a ladder. So if you cut all the rungs off with your weapon and put them on the ground, they turn into stairs!
data.reading_mnemonic: You slowly work to create these <kanji>stairs</kanji>, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>) they are done!
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing at the top of the stairs you made yourself, looking down at the entire town below you, as the light of dawn breaks and fills everything before you with light. And now more people can see this beautiful sight if they climb your steps.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you eat a <radical>rice paddy</radical> the size of the <radical>moon</radical>, your <kanji>stomach</kanji> is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a whole rice paddy in your stomach. A rice paddy the size of the moon. Your stomach hurts a lot. You feel like you’re going to throw up.
data.reading_mnemonic: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended <kanji>stomach</kanji>. Bam! The <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.
data.reading_hint: This eagle saw your stomach distress and decided to help by making you barf. Hear the screech of the eagle as it swoops down and rams you in the stomach.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside this <radical>moon</radical> is a <radical>black hole</radical>... haha just kidding, it's your <kanji>belly</kanji>! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good <kanji>stomach</kanji> you have!
data.meaning_hint: Look down at your perfect belly. It's looking back up at you.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't treat your <kanji>belly</kanji> with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "<reading>F**k</reading> (<ja>ふく</ja>) you!" Be nice to your stomach!
data.reading_hint: Forget to eat lunch? Belly grumbles f**k you. Tell someone you're fat and need to lose weight? Belly cries f**k you. Be nice to your belly.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>sick</radical> <radical>mama</radical> tries to do a <radical>task</radical> she's filled with <kanji>pain</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Sick people shouldn't have to do things, of course they're in pain. You shouldn't let your mama do anything if she's in pain, do it for her!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your mama's <kanji>pain</kanji> is <reading>too</reading> (<ja>つう</ja>) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too.
data.reading_hint: You finish doing your tasks and hers too, and you ask her, "How is the pain now, Mama?" "THE PAIN IS TOO MUCH!" she cries. Oh mama.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're on your <radical>scooter</radical> and you run over a <radical>root</radical>, you'll need to <kanji>retreat</kanji>. The roots have obviously <kanji>reject</kanji>ed you, they want you to leave, so you should.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the roots raising up a little bit from the ground and tripping up your scooter. They reject you, so you should just retreat.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>retreat</kanji> by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.
data.reading_hint: You didn't retreat fast enough, the roots are rejecting your life, and strangling you with your own tie.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> by the <radical>exit</radical> letting you know to <kanji>yield</kanji>. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this flag telling you to yield. Now look through the exit right by the flag. You can see a bunch of people out there walking. Imagine standing by the exit, yielding to the other people until you have an opening. Hear the hustle and bustle of the people as you wait.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even though the flag told you to <kanji>yield</kanji>, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old <reading>coots</reading> (<ja>くつ</ja>)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!
data.reading_hint: Darn coots! Forget the yield flag, it’s time to exit. Imagine busting out of the exit, punching and pushing your way through the old coots. Hear them scream and shout “Augh! My hip!” as you plow through them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>soul</radical> is lying in the <radical>grass</radical> in a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, you're going to <kanji>worry</kanji> about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your soul curled up inside this treasure chest that's just sitting out on the grass. Anyone could open it up and look inside, and this worries you quite a bit!
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, you also <kanji>worry</kanji> about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? <reading>Nah, yah</reading> (<ja>なや</ja>). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind.
data.reading_hint: You worry about what you'll find if you look directly at your soul. But you also worry about what will happen if someone else looks. So you're stuck in a constant state of worrying: nah or yah?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>sun</radical> while holding a <radical>comb</radical> in a <radical>cage</radical> and sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, you comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in your spare time, sitting on this stool in a cage in the sun. Feel the warmth of the sun on your body and feel the metal bars of the cage holding you in. You try to forget about your situation by combing your hair with the comb. The comb radical is a little modified, so be sure to remember that you made this comb yourself and it’s a little wonky.
data.reading_mnemonic: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>, you used to steal <reading>ca</reading>rs (<ja>か</ja>). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself in this cage. You’re going to be there for life because you’d stolen too many cars. Feel the tears run down your face as you continue to comb your hair. You’re going to die in this cage.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>thread</radical> and moving to the <radical>sound</radical> of the music, a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes a <kanji>weave</kanji> through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard bipping and bopping to the sound of the music as he weaves this thread through his clothes to repair them.
data.reading_mnemonic: This drunkard is actually a <reading>Sheikh</reading> (<ja>しき</ja>) (an Arabic leader), but he’s just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he is using the thread to <kanji>weave</kanji> back together is one of his fancy formal robes.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this drunken Sheikh again, only this time he is moving to the sound of some Arabic music. You know what that sounds like, right?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>substitute</radical> some <radical>shellfish</radical> for collateral so your friend will <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
data.meaning_hint: "Shellfish used to be money! People used to lend them to each other all the time!" you say to your friend. "Hmm... okay, I guess so," they say skeptically.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want your friend to <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money so you can buy yourself a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself in this new car that you got with the money your friend lent you. Hear the roar of the engine and feel the wind in your hair.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're riding your <radical>scooter</radical> through some <radical>rice</radical>, it's likely you've gone <kanji>astray</kanji>. Also you might be <kanji>lost</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Usually there aren't paved areas inside areas of rice. You must be really lost if you ended up here with your scooter.
data.reading_mnemonic: You got so <kanji>lost</kanji> and went so <kanji>astray</kanji> you ended up on the <reading>May</reading>flower  (<ja>めい</ja>), a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.
data.reading_hint: How you got so lost that you ended up on an old ship from 1620 is beyond my understanding. But you did it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> who has his <radical>mouth</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>, has a <radical>heart</radical> that is <kanji>misguided</kanji>. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this misguided drunkard. His whole deal is messed up.
data.reading_mnemonic: Nowadays we don't say <kanji>misguided</kanji>, we say <reading>wack</reading> (<ja>わく</ja>). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack.
data.reading_hint: Did I do it? Did I figure out the kid lingo? Am I cool? Or am I just another wack, misguided adult?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> to some <radical>grain</radical> and some <radical>stairs</radical>: I want to <kanji>invite</kanji> you to my place.
data.meaning_hint: So you do. You invite a stalk of grain and a set of stairs to your home.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>invite</kanji>d them to your home because your roommate was having a party and inviting a lot of <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>) over. You wanted to look cool, so you invited some grain and some stairs, the two coolest things you could think of.
data.reading_hint: Surprisingly, the youths were impressed and spent a long time trying to talk to them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>capital</radical>, a broken <radical>dog</radical> begins to <kanji>settle in</kanji>. This dog used to live in the country, but he kept getting caught in bear and fox traps which busted the poor dog up. The dog didn’t want to live like this, so he decided to settle in the capital city where there aren’t pesky animal traps to get caught in.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this dog going to the capital and settling in. The poor dog looks pretty messed up though. The radical for dog in this kanji is a bit modified, so just remember that the dog in this story is all messed up.
data.reading_mnemonic: In order to help the dog <kanji>settle in</kanji>, the capital cobbler makes him a pair of <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). The shoes help him walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they help him relax and feel like a dog again.
data.reading_hint: Watch the broken dog settle in to his new shoes in his new home in the capital. The old dog can finally enjoy life!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone just asked you to <radical>say</radical> which <radical>direction</radical> they should <kanji>visit</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You better think long and hard about where you think they should visit before you say so. They're relying on you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You end up saying, "You should <kanji>visit</kanji> my <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>)." How kind of you!
data.reading_hint: Your home is just over that direction, and it's your favorite place to visit, so why wouldn't this stranger want to visit your home too?! So come and visit my home, random person!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> with a broken <radical>heart</radical> is very <kanji>angry</kanji>. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.
data.meaning_hint: This woman is so angry! Pretend you are the woman. Sit on your stool and feel your heart, painful in your chest, as you fume and think about how angry you are.
data.reading_mnemonic: The guy who broke your heart and made you so <kanji>angry</kanji> was such a <reading>do</reading>g (<ja>ど</ja>). He cheated on you multiple times, with your mother and your sister! What a dog!
data.reading_hint: You’re so angry! Imagine your ex as being an actual dog and picture yourself hitting it right in the face with your stool. Hear the dog whimpering in pain as you demolish it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to go to the <radical>sun</radical> so you set up a <radical>slide</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> stories tall so you can <kanji>ascend</kanji> into the heavens.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the air whoosh past your face as you shoot off the end of the long slide and ascend into the air. It's starting to get hot and the sun is getting closer!
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>ascend</kanji> into the sky and toward the sun because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig.
data.reading_hint: As you ascend, look back through tear-filled eyes and see the Shougun staring up at you. He nods slightly. You've pleased him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Closing each <radical>eye</radical> is something that the <radical>peoples</radical> do before they <kanji>sleep</kanji>. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.
data.meaning_hint: You are one of these peoples, so imagine yourself closing your eyes and sleeping. Go ahead and do it right now. Close one eye, and then the other. Now imagine yourself sleeping.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason you want to <kanji>sleep</kanji> is because all the other peoples were <reading>mean</reading> (<ja>みん</ja>) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.
data.reading_hint: Those other peoples were really mean to you. Imagine all the mean things they were saying to you. What did they say? Think about all these mean things as you close your eyes and drift off to sleep. Also keep in mind that this kanji has the same reading as <ja>民</ja>, which is included in this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>eye</radical>s start to close as you drive your <radical>car</radical> because you’re getting <kanji>drowsy</kanji>. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!
data.meaning_hint: Feel yourself getting drowsy as you drive this goofy car. You’re so tired. Struggle to keep your eyes open. Also visualize this car missing its top and its bottom because the car radical is modified.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason you’re so <kanji>drowsy</kanji>, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself swinging on this tire swing. You’ve been swinging for a while and you’re getting really drowsy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When someone is <radical>sick</radical> in order to diagnose the <radical>correct</radical> cause and treatment, you need to check their <kanji>symptom</kanji>s. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!
data.meaning_hint: If you know all of the symptoms for each and every sickness you'd be able to cure them all!
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to figure out the <kanji>symptom</kanji>s the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.
data.reading_hint: You get all up close and personal with the Shougun. Hmm, his symptoms are watery eyes, stuffy nose, angry shouting (wait no, that's not a symptom, is it?). Don't mess up!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a special <radical>thread</radical> in your <radical>towel</radical> you can use to make it <radical>stand</radical> up by <kanji>tighten</kanji>ing it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine pulling this thread and watch as your towel tightens and goes rigid, standing up almost completely on its own (except that the thread did it).
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>tighten</kanji> your towel before you eat <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers.
data.reading_hint: A tightened towel stands up for easy grease cleanup. No wiping on your pants, no dripping on the floor.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>white</radical>. This color will <kanji>urge</kanji> and <kanji>compel</kanji> you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to <kanji>coerce</kanji> you, even.
data.meaning_hint: Look at how white the scooter is. It urges you to use it. It compels you. You feel coerced...
data.reading_mnemonic: When they <kanji>urge</kanji>, <kanji>compel</kanji> and <kanji>coerce</kanji> you like this, they are <reading>hack</reading>ing (<ja>はく</ja>) your brain.
data.reading_hint:
Really all marketing, advertising, and the like is just a hack of your brain.

Hint: If you see <ja>白</ja> in a kanji, there's a good likelihood the reading will be <ja>はく</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>leather</radical> and <radical>change</radical> it into <kanji>shoes</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You start with a sheet of leather. Now imagine yourself going through the process of changing them to shoes. Smell the leather and feel it, too.
data.reading_mnemonic: Some <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old <reading>coots</reading> (<ja>くつ</ja>). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.
data.reading_hint: Imagine some of these old coots busting into a modern shoe store and kicking over all the display stands and setting everything on fire because they hate non leather shoes so much. Hear the old coots screaming and babbling nonsense as they destroy the store.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits while you're <radical>farming</radical>, you'll have to wear really <kanji>thick</kanji> clothes to deal with it. The water is thick with fish and cars and other ripped-up debris too, which makes it even harder.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting on your thick farming suit as the tsunami comes at you. You hold onto your hoe and brace yourself for the wall of water.
data.reading_mnemonic: You knew to put on your <kanji>thick</kanji> tsunami-proof farming gear because <reading>No</reading>stradamus (<ja>のう</ja>) warned you it was coming. He sent a message to your brain yesterday so you'd know what to wear today.
data.reading_hint: Thanks Nostradamus, now I'm in my nice, thick gear, struggling to hoe my fields through this wall of tsunami water. But I'm not dead and I'm not wet.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Setting up a <radical>stand</radical> on the top of a <radical>mountain</radical>, you <radical>rake</radical> all the rocks to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself at the top of the mountain, holding the rake in your hands. Look over the edge. Feel the sinking feeling in your stomach as you realize how high up you really are.
data.reading_mnemonic: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). You lay next to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself at the edge of this mountain getting your tan on. Feel the sun beating down on you and feel the fresh mountain breeze blowing over your body. It’s very relaxing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> eats a <radical>beggar</radical> and his <radical>stool</radical>, which were on the <radical>ground</radical> next to him, which seems to be a bit <kanji>extreme</kanji>, don't you think?
data.meaning_hint: The beggar was just sitting there on a stool! Why so extreme?
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately we still haven’t come up with a good reading for <ja>きょく</ja>, but just try and remember this reading as <reading>Goku</reading> (<ja>ごく</ja>) from Dragon Ball Z and his strange step brother <reading>Kyoku</reading> (<ja>きょく</ja>). Goku and Kyoku are the beggars in this story, the ones performing all the <kanji>extremes</kanji>. First Goku gets eaten by the tree with the mouth, and then Kyoku gets eaten as well.
data.reading_hint: You know Goku from Dragon Ball, right? Imagine him doing all sorts of extreme things. Then imagine his less impressive brother, Kyoku, also doing extremes. And then they get eaten by the tree.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> you'll have a <radical>surplus</radical> of possible <kanji>route</kanji>s. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!
data.meaning_hint: Okay, so it might not be legal to take the sidewalk route depending on where you live, but physically, you can do whatever you want because scooters are small.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to take the fastest <kanji>route</kanji>, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>) on every single person trying to walk there.
data.reading_hint: Psh, whatever. They aren't your toes, and this is the fastest route! You'll name it the toe route and do whatever you want.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>yoga</radical> class uses a special <radical>brush</radical> to stay <kanji>healthy</kanji>. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick.
data.meaning_hint: If you want to be healthy too, just do yoga and rub this healthy brush all over your bod.
data.reading_mnemonic: Not everyone wants to be <kanji>healthy</kanji>, but <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Ken, the picture of samurai health, doing yoga and getting that brush all up in those bits.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>canopy</radical> needs a <radical>brush</radical> and some <radical>water</radical> because it's gotten gross. When it's clean, you feel at <kanji>ease</kanji>, and at <kanji>peace</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Look at your dirty canopy. Feel irritated, aggravated, annoyed, and all similar feelings at it because it's not clean. Then, take some water to it and get brushing. When you're done, it's clean. Now, feel a feeling of ease come over you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You feel totally at <kanji>ease</kanji> looking at your canopy. Someone comes up behind you and starts massaging your shoulders. It's <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. He wants you to feel even more at ease.
data.reading_hint: <ja>こういち</ja> says, "Yes. Feel at ease. Feel at peace. This is a good canopy you cleaned."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside the "<radical>Good</radical> <radical>Building</radical>" there's a single <kanji>guy</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Feel free to walk around the Good Building. There are no things or people, except for that one guy. Who is that guy.
data.reading_mnemonic: You talk to that <kanji>guy</kanji>. The only thing he does is offer you <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: You try to talk to the guy, poke him, and even yell at him. But, all he does is hand you some fish roe. When you take it, he offers you more fish roe. What's up with this guy?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>thread</radical>s have to <radical>suit</radical> you if you want a good <kanji>salary</kanji>. No one is going to give you a salary if your clothes don't suit you. You have to look professional!
data.meaning_hint: When you see someone wearing a fancy suit that suits them, don't you wonder about how much their salary is?
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>salary</kanji> is paid in <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (<ja>きゅう</ja>). Maybe you shouldn't have worn that cucumber tie when you interviewed for this job, even though it suited you well.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your salary being paid in cucumbers. Open that sweet paycheck and watch the cucumbers come tumbling out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> takes you to the <radical>barracks</radical>, <radical>drop</radical>s you off, and then goes in <kanji>reverse</kanji> all the way back home in the <kanji>opposite</kanji> direction.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine riding your scooter to the barracks. It literally drops you on the ground when you get there, and then drives in reverse back the opposite way you came.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial.
data.reading_hint: You Gak up the wheels so when the scooter tries to switch to reverse it gets stuck. Success! But now it can't go forward either. Darn you Gak, you tricked me again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>giant</radical> radical and the <kanji>giant</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
data.reading_mnemonic: Just recently, a <kanji>giant</kanji> rampaged through Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.
data.reading_hint: See Little Kyoto after the giant rampaged through it. It looks even smaller and more pathetic than ever. Look at all the smoldering rubble and smell the smoke with your nose.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> is over your <radical>car</radical> because your car is in <kanji>storage</kanji> in a large <kanji>warehouse</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The canopy just protects your car from the elements as it sits in storage for long periods of time.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your car is in this <kanji>storage</kanji> <kanji>warehouse</kanji>, just sitting there. A <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a kid sneaking into your canopy to steal your car that's in storage. Maybe it's two <ja>子</ja>s, one stacked on the other with a trench coat. One <ja>子</ja> works the pedals while the other <ja>子</ja> works the steering.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing <radical>stick</radical> at the <radical>sun</radical>, you attain the <radical>legs</radical> of a <kanji>child</kanji>. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself getting new legs. Legs that belong to a child. They’re limber and young and full of energy! Feel your legs of a child underneath you!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you delight in your new legs, <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>) descends from the sky. “My <kanji>child</kanji>,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”
data.reading_hint: Say back to Jesus, “I’m not your child Jesus! And you’re just jealous of my new legs! You wish you had the legs of a child, Jesus! Your legs are like super old!” Actually say this out loud, and remember how Jesus wishes he could be a child again too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You got your <radical>ice</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. Of course, your ice orders are to make things <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>cold</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Making things cool and cold are pretty much the only orders you'll hear from ice. Ice is very simple in that regard.
data.reading_mnemonic: How will you make things <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>cold</kanji>? You'll use a special <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun that shoots a cold ray.
data.reading_hint:
Imagine a cold ray coming out of your ray gun. Anything it touches becomes cold. "Stay cool, bird boy," you say.

Hint: when you see the radical <radical>orders</radical> it's fairly likely the reading will be <ja>れい</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Ice</radical> from the <radical>east</radical> is <kanji>frozen</kanji>. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this super frozen ice from the east. You’ve never seen anything quite like it before. It’s so frozen, it’s like it was frozen once and then frozen again. Twice frozen. Feel the ice and how freezing cold it is. It’s super cold, guys.
data.reading_mnemonic: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was <kanji>frozen</kanji> in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. <ja>とうきょう</ja> is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being in <ja>とうきょう</ja> and seeing all this frozen ice. Hear people speaking Japanese all around you as you touch and feel the freezing twice-frozen ice.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Super <radical>poop</radical> is a super <radical>power</radical> you have in <kanji>infancy</kanji>. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power!
data.meaning_hint:
Infants poop a lot. There's poop everywhere. The powerful aroma overwhelms you. Eww.

Also refers to childhood, when you still have some of your poop powers, but they're already starting to go away.
data.reading_mnemonic: In <kanji>infancy</kanji>, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power.
data.reading_hint: See this infant gobbling up all the yogurt he can get his grubby little hands on. Soon, he begins to poop all over the place. Hear the infant screaming, "Goo-goo! Yogurt poop power! I'm a baby! Wahhhh!!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: Only give <radical>grain</radical>s to a <radical>turkey</radical> if it's <kanji>immature</kanji>. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine an immature turkey complaining at you until you give it grains. Now it's taking selfies with the grains and posting pics to Instagram and hashtagging them #GRAINLIFE.
data.reading_mnemonic: Another thing <kanji>immature</kanji> turkeys (and people) love is <reading>chee</reading>se (<ja>ち</ja>). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a bunch of immature kids and turkeys eating cheese together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>winter</radical> <radical>table</radical> would be an odd thing to <kanji>deal with</kanji>. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst!
data.meaning_hint: Look at this winter table. How are you ever going to deal with it? Just think of your favorite warm food and then imagine it getting cold. Deal with it, dog.
data.reading_mnemonic: This winter table is something you have to <kanji>deal with</kanji>, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus <reading>show</reading> (<ja>しょ</ja>)? They like weird stuff like this.
data.reading_hint: Feel the relief of getting rid of this table. No more having to deal with it anymore. The circus show can have it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You wear a great big <radical>cross</radical> on your chest and you attend a <radical>specialty</radical> <kanji>exhibition</kanji> for <kanji>gambling</kanji>. The big cross on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross, and everyone is gambling.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself at this specialty exhibition. Feel the weight of the cross shaped badge on your chest as you continue gambling at the exhibition.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re not very good at <kanji>gambling</kanji>, but you are pretty good at cheating. You <reading>hack</reading> (<ja>はく</ja>) the specialty <kanji>exhibition</kanji> gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system.
data.reading_hint: Hack the gambling machines. Imagine the sounds of the exhibition around you as you work to hack the machines. Look at the computer parts and cables as you work.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> that's <radical>blue</radical> is <kanji>pure</kanji>. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure!
data.meaning_hint: Picture this pure blue tsunami. You can see every crystal clear drop of water in it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Seeing this <kanji>pure</kanji> blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash!
data.reading_hint: SPLAASHH! The tsunami's pure water splits and it absorbed into your saber. Now it's pure too. And transparent!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> takes <radical>life</radical>, cuts it like a <radical>sword</radical> through <radical>thread</radical>, and leaves everything behind completely <kanji>pure</kanji>. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, it's completely pure.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami purifying the land of life, and in your mind see the sword cutting clean through the thread of life.
data.reading_mnemonic: After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is <kanji>pure</kanji> white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<ja>けつ</ja>) all over the place to make it not so pure.
data.reading_hint: The area is SO pure that the ground absorbs the ketsup and now it's all pure... ketsup color.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>Wolverine</radical> swam in the <radical>water</radical> while his father made a <kanji>record</kanji> of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine.
data.meaning_hint: See this gold Wolverine holding his gold medal after getting out of the water. His dad doesn’t want to forget anything about this precious moment so he makes a record of it. Imagine him scribbling furiously in his notebook.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a <kanji>record</kanji> of this also. One angry fan threw a <reading>rock</reading> (<ja>ろく</ja>) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a pitiful Wolverine crying on the ground as each rock hits him. All he wanted was some recognition from his father. Poor guy. Imagine poor Wolverine like this as his dad just looks on and writes in his notebook.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> has a <radical>pig</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> on it because it's our <kanji>squad</kanji>'s place.
data.meaning_hint: Our symbol is the horn pig and we put it on everything to show the whole world our squad owns this turf. #SQUADGOALS
data.reading_mnemonic: Our <kanji>squad</kanji> also wears special <reading>tie</reading>s (<ja>たい</ja>) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A FAMILY.
data.reading_hint: Picture our squad. It's Koichi, Viet, the Crabigator and Tofugu. We're all wearing matching horned pig ties and walking toward you in slow motion, our squad building towering behind us with the pig smirking down at you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> uses a <radical>stick</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> made of <radical>hair</radical> to enforce <kanji>discipline</kanji>. The leader uses the stick made of hair to discipline his followers. He hits them with it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the leader disciplining his people with the hair stick in the winter. Imagine him yelling “DISCIPLINE!!” with each hit of the stick as you feel the cold winter air around you.
data.reading_mnemonic: If the leader uses a stick to <kanji>discipline</kanji> his followers, eventually they'll fight back. The disciplined masses start to take off their <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>) and throw them at the leader!
data.reading_hint: Watch as the leader gets pelted with all sorts of types of shoes. Boots, high heels, baby slippers. They're all colliding with him as the people shout, "Discipline solves nothing!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gladiator</radical> in front of you draws his <radical>sword</radical>. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the <kanji>ticket</kanji> in your hand.
data.meaning_hint: Right! You needed to buy a ticket to see the gladiator! He doesn't want to kill you, he wants to check to make sure you bought a ticket.
data.reading_mnemonic: The gladiator happily marks your <kanji>ticket</kanji> with his blade, when <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again.
data.reading_hint: Ken takes a long time to examine your ticket. I don't think he understands that he needs a ticket to fight the gladiator. Maybe you should give him yours.

data.meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>woman</radical> dressed as <radical>Wolverine</radical> with a <radical>towel</radical> tied around her <radical>forehead</radical> is your <kanji>wife</kanji>. You're cosplaying together!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your kick-butt wife in her Wolverine costume, the towel around her forehead so she doesn't sweat into her eyes, as you prepare to go to a convention together.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>wife</kanji> suddenly looks at you and calls you a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine.
data.reading_hint: Your wife is shaking her head saying, "You fool, it's my turn to be Wolverine, you're gonna have to change." Then she smooches your cheek, calls you a fool one more time, and leaves without you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>odd</radical> radical and the <kanji>odd</kanji> kanji are the same. They're both... really <kanji>strange</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Remember how odd this one is?
data.reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>odd</kanji> too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your <kanji>strange</kanji> habits with a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>).
data.reading_hint: You only give this odd key to people you trust, so they can unlock your odd secrets and see how odd you are deep down.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> is one of the <radical>few</radical> <kanji>strange</kanji> things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few strange things in this world, with woman being one of them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine saying this to a woman. Try and imagine her face as you tell her how strange she is.
data.reading_mnemonic: But when you think about it, we're all a little strange. Me, you, <reading>myou</reading> (<ja>みょう</ja>) everybody!
data.reading_hint: Who's strange? Me and you. Me, you - we are strange! Strange, strange, strange!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you know the radical meaning <radical>lovely</radical>, you know the kanji meaning <kanji>lovely</kanji> as well!
data.meaning_hint: You know what would make learning this radical lovely? Studying your radicals.
data.reading_mnemonic: "<kanji>Lovely</kanji>" is the name of my <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing.
data.reading_hint: Try to imagine feeling this way about your ray gun. It's so lovely.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> on the <radical>mountain</radical>, reading off the numbers of <radical>pi</radical> on this <radical>winter</radical> morning. Everything is so perfect, so mathematical here. You view it as <kanji>delicate</kanji>. Not in the sense that it will break apart at any moment, more in the sense that there are smaller, more subtle things to be enjoyed on this mountain, which is why you loiter here doing math.
data.meaning_hint: You'll have to imagine the things you consider to be "delicate." Is that the snow falling on the branches? Is it the breeze? Is it something else? That's for you to decide, but imagine it vividly whatever it is.
data.reading_mnemonic: Ah! Of course! The <kanji>delicate</kanji> bumble <reading>be</reading>e (<ja>び</ja>), that is your epitome of delicate. It lands upon your finger, and you look at its every fiber of being.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself looking at the bee, thinking how each hair on its body is so delicate. Maybe it has a delicate aroma to go with it. A faint smell of honey?

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to <radical>fins</radical> on a <radical>plate</radical> that are meant to <kanji>benefit</kanji> everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up.
data.meaning_hint: You pick up the horns off the ground and put them on your head, then eat some fins off the plate. This is just one of many benefits to living here. You'll never go hungry!
data.reading_mnemonic: Another <kanji>benefit</kanji> is free <ja><reading>駅</reading></ja> usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this <ja>駅</ja> is completely free.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so using the <ja>駅</ja> is probably a better benefit than eating cold fins off a plate on the ground, but you take what you can get. They're all free!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>grain</radical>, from one <radical>evening</radical> to the next <radical>evening</radical>, experiences a <kanji>shift</kanji>. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the grain in your head with a time-lapse of one evening after another happening in the background. Slowly, the grain shifts.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shift</kanji> is caused by the <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off.
data.reading_hint: Picture the eagle flying down on the second evening, scattering the grains it doesn't eat, shifting their location.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Grain</radical> <radical>Mouth</radical> <radical>King</radical> pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the <kanji>extent</kanji> to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat.
data.meaning_hint: Of course, you need to imagine pulling the Grain Mouth King's finger, to some extent. You can't just read what we write for you, without going to the imagination zone. Pull that finger real hard a couple times, and watch an extra large purge of grain pour forth.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>extent</kanji> to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots instead.
data.reading_hint: Imagine hearing the rumors that the Grain Mouth King ran out of grain, so you go check the extent of his failure yourself. But tater tots taste pretty good too. Imagine eating one of his mouth tater tots and go ahead and comment about it to him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rice</radical> that is <radical>blue</radical> has a strong <kanji>spirit</kanji>. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out!
data.meaning_hint: Picture this rice, the pulsing blue spirit of each grain is glowing so bright!
data.reading_mnemonic:
You want to see the <kanji>spirit</kanji> up close, so you take your <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything!

Then it's gone.
data.reading_hint: As you release the spirits in the rice, your saber begins to glow blue too. Their spirits are going inside your saber, making it stronger!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Sometime in the future, <radical>thread</radical> of every <radical>color</radical> will be faced with <kanji>extinction</kanji>. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what the world would be like without thread. No thread of any color. How would you fix tears in clothes or make new ones? It would be a strange world where thread is extinct.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>extinction</kanji> of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly <reading>zits</reading> (<ja>ぜつ</ja>). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits.
data.reading_hint: Pretend you have deadly zits. They’re everywhere, not just your face. You can’t pop them or you’ll die, but they’re all bulging and extremely painful. Now you’re facing extinction. Lousy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You stick <radical>horns</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> using them as <radical>spikes</radical> and you <kanji>line up</kanji> the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself lining up these horns in the ground. The spikes are sharp and you poke yourself with one. Ouch. Need to be more careful as you line these up.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>line up</kanji> these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on <reading>hay</reading> (<ja>へい</ja>) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the hay in that bull's mouth as it chomps angrily, watching you line up horns in the ground. It probably wishes you were the hay.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> protecting your <radical>life</radical> and the <radical>net</radical> protecting your <radical>heart</radical> are both protected by the <kanji>constitution</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The constitution makes it so that everything you hold dear is locked away, nice and safe on a piece of paper, and no one can change the rules or hurt you without your say so.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your country's <kanji>constitution</kanji> is being protected by none other than <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai, hero for hire.
data.reading_hint: Picture Ken standing in front of your constitution. But keep a close watch, cause wily ol' Nic Cage is in the business of thievin' on constitutions.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Blood</radical> and <radical>hair</radical> and <radical>tofu</radical> make up the <kanji>populace</kanji>. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway.
data.meaning_hint: Blood shows that all the people are related. Hair shows that we're all humans. Tofu is food to all. So, as you can see, those three words describe the entire populace.
data.reading_mnemonic: The entire <kanji>populace</kanji> deserves <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat.
data.reading_hint: If you see people in your populace without shoes, it's your job as a fellow member of society to help them get some!

data.meaning_mnemonic: As a <radical>hat</radical>, <radical>four people</radical> holding a <radical>cross</radical> use an <kanji>umbrella</kanji>. The umbrella is big enough to be a hat for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that’s why they’re holding the cross.
data.meaning_hint: See these four people all under one umbrella. No one is carrying the umbrella, it’s just resting on all of their heads like a hat. Their hands are busy holding that cross, anyway.
data.reading_mnemonic: You know the Spanish phrase “Mi <reading>casa</reading> (<ja>かさ</ja>) es su casa”? Well this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is an <kanji>umbrella</kanji>. Mi casa es yours too, because it’s an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the four people in the umbrella hat again, only this time imagine them skipping along singing “Mi casa es su casa”. It’ll help you remember.

data.meaning_mnemonic: After a <radical>tsunami</radical>, you find an <radical>axe</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to some <radical>fins</radical> on the <kanji>beach</kanji>. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach.
data.meaning_hint: See these things on the beach. It makes sense to see fins, as fins are usually in the ocean, so seeing them on the beach is logical. Pick up the stuff you find as you feel the beach sand between your toes.
data.reading_mnemonic: Walking down the <kanji>beach</kanji> a bit more, you also find a <reading>hammer</reading> (<ja>はま</ja>). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer.
data.reading_hint: Pick up the hammer in your hand. It’s pretty heavy. The tsunami must have been very strong to pick up such a heavy hammer.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone is coming toward you in a <radical>car</radical>, holding a <radical>weapon</radical> in their <radical>hand</radical>, they're going to <kanji>attack</kanji> you!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the car, weapon out the window, preparing to attack you full force!
data.reading_mnemonic: Right before the <kanji>attack</kanji> begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's <reading>Gecki</reading> (<ja>げき</ja>), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge.
data.reading_hint: Gecki is attacking you now. He's hitting you over and over with his tiny car. He's yelling and smacking your ankles with his weapon. And all you can do is wait and let the attack happen, because you know you deserve it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Construction</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> leads to <kanji>aggression</kanji>. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself walking through the winter construction site, taking out your aggression on anyone you see. You hate this winter construction!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're taking your <kanji>aggression</kanji> out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him.
data.reading_hint:
"Aggression" is going to depend on you, so you should imagine a scene where you take your aggression out on <ja>こういち</ja>, whatever that entails.

Hint: When you see <ja>工</ja> in a kanji it will often take the <ja>こう</ja> reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: To the <radical>servant</radical> you say: "<radical>gun</radical>, <radical>ground</radical>, <radical>plate</radical>." It is your job to <kanji>oversee</kanji> everything they do.
data.meaning_hint: You point to the gun. You point to the ground (that's where the gun goes). You point to the plate (you want it). You have to oversee everything the servant does.
data.reading_mnemonic: Why must you <kanji>oversee</kanji> everything? Because you are Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>), and Genghis Khan oversees everything.
data.reading_hint: If anyone had to oversee a lot, it was Genghis Khan, who had one of the largest kingdoms in all of history.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> is <radical>not</radical> a <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> or a <kanji>counter for cups</kanji>. Don’t get them mixed up. The last time you tried making a cup out of a tree to count your throat got filled with splinters when you used it. There wasn't even any liquid in it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine cutting a tree into a cup of liquid and focus on the pain in your throat when you try to actually use it. Instead you kick the tree and angrily count cups of liquid in your head, because they simply are NOT the same.
data.reading_mnemonic: Another way to remember the <kanji>counter for cups</kanji> using a <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> would be by creating and memorizing a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>) about them. Aren’t haikus useful?
data.reading_hint: Think of a haiku about a cup of liquid and a counter for cups. Use that haiku to help remember this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>morning</radical>, you use a <radical>gun</radical> on your <radical>nose</radical> to make it <kanji>dry</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Don't worry, there aren't bullets in the gun. It's an air gun! So just imagine shooting the air into your nose every morning to make sure it's nice and dry.
data.reading_mnemonic: This technique for a nice <kanji>dry</kanji> nose was invented by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem.
data.reading_hint: Now the next time you manage to get your nose nice and dry, think back to our founding father Genghis Khan and thank him for where you are today.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>turkey</radical>s is our <kanji>sponsor</kanji>. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading.
data.meaning_hint: This message is brought to you by our generous sponsor, the leader of the mountain turkeys. Long may he reign.
data.reading_mnemonic: This same <kanji>sponsor</kanji> is also how you made your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments.
data.reading_hint: Turn your cyborg over and you'll see a stamp under one of its feet. It says, "Sponsored by" with a little picture of a turkey on top a mountain.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> sees your bare <radical>foot</radical> and <kanji>urge</kanji>s you to put a sock on it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your leader's face when he sees your bare foot, and just how emphatic he is as he urges to you put a sock on it. He's really worried your foot's going to get cold!
data.reading_mnemonic: As <kanji>urge</kanji>d, you put a <reading>sock</reading> (<ja>そく</ja>) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock.
data.reading_hint: Feel this sock on your foot. It feels great. Wiggle your toes around inside the sock as you think about how glad you are that you did as your leader urged. Note that this kanji also has the same reading as <ja>足</ja>, so keep that in mind too!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>district</radical> that <radical>lack</radical>s things will be in <kanji>Europe</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a map of Europe in your mind. Now picture little words saying which district is lacking what. This one is lacking water. That one is lacking food.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Europe</kanji> is lacking so much because their <ja><reading>王</reading></ja> (<ja>おう</ja>) keeps taking everything.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so maybe this is an old view of Europe. But back in the old days the <ja>王</ja>s there would take everything from their subjects, so every district would lack something. Good thing things aren't that way now, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> rolls in and destroys all the <radical>construction</radical> that was being done on the <kanji>inlet</kanji> and the <kanji>bay</kanji>. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all the construction on the bay and the inlet getting destroyed by the tsunami. Look at all of it fall apart and crash to the ground as the tsunami knocks it down. Imagine yourself right near the action, feeling the water spray from the tsunami.
data.reading_mnemonic: Imagine the Japanese people standing on the <kanji>bay</kanji> and the <kanji>inlet</kanji> as the tsunami approaches. “<reading>Eh</reading> (<ja>え</ja>)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!”
data.reading_hint: EH? A tsunami you say? Those construction areas are screwed, man. Again, imagine the tsunami demolishing the area. Then be all like, “Eh? A tsunami? Aw, man.”

data.meaning_mnemonic: If what you <radical>say</radical> comes out <radical>blue</radical>, everyone knows that means you made a <kanji>request</kanji>. You request a favor and the words slide out of your mouth in a bright, blue blob. They hover in front of you for a few seconds, before splashing onto the person you made the request to.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this blue, slimy request. You could have done that thing by yourself, but you requested it of someone else, and now it's all over and everyone can see it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The next time someone <kanji>request</kanji>s something from you, take out your <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) and slice it in half!
data.reading_hint: Now they have the blue request gunk on them, and you can walk away as your already-blue sword absorbs the rest. Oh, and you don't have to fulfill the request (bonus!).

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>narwhal</radical> and the <radical>turkey</radical> are meeting in <radical>private</radical> to uh, show each other some private things. Doing this they realize they're both <kanji>male</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a male narwhal and a male turkey meeting together in private. Whispering. Giggling. Pointing at each other's male bits.
data.reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>male</kanji> animals are obviously experimenting with things still. Ah, they must be <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>)!  To be a youth, again!
data.reading_hint: It's just nature. Youths like to learn and try new things. And if two male youth animals wanna get together in private that's their business.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>morning</radical>, <radical>Korea</radical> will still be <kanji>Korea</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture Korea first thing in the morning. You can see all the cities, the countryside, everything waking up.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Korea</kanji> is still here today on this beautiful morning because of Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>). When he was conquering all that land in Asia and Europe he looked at Korea in the morning light and said, "Nah, they can keep it."
data.reading_hint: Picture Genghis Khan admiring Korea from afar, but letting it live on.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You set up a <radical>net</radical> on a <radical>cross</radical> to wash your <radical>clothes</radical> in the river, when a huge wave of <radical>dirt</radical> smashes into it, <kanji>break</kanji>ing the whole thing and sending your clothes tumbling down the river.
data.meaning_hint: Oh, why did it have to break! If the net had been strong enough, your clothes wouldn't be even more dirty and lost down the river right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: You angrily search to see what caused your clothes washing machine to <kanji>break</kanji> and you see some <reading>ka</reading>yaks (<ja>かい</ja>) upriver. The people in the kayaks are jumping around, kicking dirt up, which is what broke your stuff.
data.reading_hint: "Hey you, kayak lovers!" you scream, "How dare you break my stuff, I'll get you and all the kayaks out there! You'll pay!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> to wear a <radical>hat</radical> to cover your <radical>hair</radical> if your doctor <kanji>diagnose</kanji>s you with hair loss. It's the best option, folks.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the doctor diagnosing you with hair loss. He pulls out a hat and places it on your poor, thinning hair.
data.reading_mnemonic: You just had the doctor <kanji>diagnose</kanji> you with hair loss. How terrible! You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention, you bang your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day.
data.reading_hint: Hold your shin as you feel the throbbing pain in it. Even though the pain is so extreme, you can’t help but still think about the diagnosis you got from the doctor.

data.meaning_mnemonic: At the <radical>gate</radical>, you <radical>kiss</radical> <kanji>the cabinet</kanji> members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine kissing all the members of the cabinet. A lot of them are old men. Imagine kissing all of them at the gate. Eww.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to kiss each member of <kanji>the cabinet</kanji> to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster!
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself sneaking past the cabinet members, finding your cock, grabbing it, and getting out of there. You’ve recovered your rooster! The day is won.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A good <radical>leader</radical> will use <radical>charcoal</radical> to mark her <kanji>colleague</kanji>s. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing one of the leader's colleagues walking around, watching you. You'd get back to work and stop goofing around, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to be good around her <kanji>colleague</kanji>s, because if you aren't your <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights.
data.reading_hint: Imagine goofing off in your row boat and then seeing one of the colleagues waiting on the shore for you. No! She's gonna take your row boat away!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Grain</radical>s get <radical>blame</radical>d for how much they <kanji>accumulate</kanji>. If the grains accumulate too much then they make more work for the farmers. If they accumulate too little, then they're starving the people. Ugh, grains just can't win with you people. They're blamed for everything.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a pile of grains accumulating in size while a person watches. No matter how large the pile gets, the person keeps blaming them for something!
data.reading_mnemonic: Now the grains have <kanji>accumulate</kanji>d a ton, they're overflowing in their grain sacks, and the farmer freezes and says, "Now those are some <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>) grains."
data.reading_hint: Is that why people become farmers? Because they think... accumulating a lot of grains is sexy? People are weird.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Above</radical> you, on a <radical>small</radical> <radical>stool</radical> is the <radical>eye</radical> of your <kanji>coach</kanji>. He's really high above you though, and all you can make out is the glint of his eye as he perches on that stool. But he's yelling out orders and corrections, which you can hear very well.
data.meaning_hint: Look up from the field or court and see the eye of your coach shining down and watching you closely. It makes you uncomfortable, honestly.
data.reading_mnemonic: You finally win the big game and the <kanji>coach</kanji> is coming down off of his stool, and you see that's he's the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu!!! That explains why you could only ever make out his eyeball!
data.reading_hint: Coach Tokugawa hovers before you, in full shougun garb, and nods his head in approval, winks, then disappears.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>servant</radical> radical and the <kanji>servant</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means <kanji>retainer</kanji> and you’ll be fine.
data.meaning_hint: Retainer and servant are basically the same thing, so remembering this one shouldn’t be too hard for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>servant</kanji>, also known as your <kanji>retainer</kanji>, bangs his <reading>shins</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>) all the time so you make him wear <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your servant banging his shins on everything in your house. Hand him a pair of jeans and tell him to put them on to soften the blows.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and you give it a <radical>kiss</radical> before granting it the <kanji>abbreviation</kanji>, RP. The rice paddy isn’t too fond of this abbreviation, so you kiss it again to soothe it.
data.meaning_hint: As you imagine yourself giving a kiss to a rice paddy, think about whether or not the abbreviation RP would ever catch on. Do you think it would?
data.reading_mnemonic: The rice paddy still refuses to accept this <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> despite your kisses. Therefore, you are forced to take the rice paddy and hang it from a torture <reading>rack</reading> (<ja>りゃく</ja>) until it agrees to accept the abbreviation.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the rice paddy on the rack, squealing for mercy. Turn the handle to turn the rack, causing the rice paddy even more discomfort.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On every <radical>boat</radical> there is a <radical>table</radical> with a <radical>lid</radical> on it that's used for <kanji>navigation</kanji>. When you take the lid off, there is a big map, a sextant, and some little boat miniatures. All the navigation tools.
data.meaning_hint: You forget to put the lid back on the navigation station and all those tools and boat pieces go flying around the boat and into the water. Oops.
data.reading_mnemonic: You watch the <kanji>navigation</kanji> equipment roll away and then you feel a slap on the back of your head. Ouch! You turn around and there stands <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who you took with you as the navigator of this expedition. And, you just lost all his stuff!
data.reading_hint: Picture this seafaring <ja>こういち</ja> angrily chasing you around the ruined navigation station, trying to hit you with a telescope.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> someone <radical>odd</radical> is trying to <kanji>approach</kanji> you. You back up, but they continue their approach anyway.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being under the same roof as an odd person who wants to approach you. You don't want anything to do with them, but they won't back off.
data.reading_mnemonic: They <kanji>approach</kanji> too closely and you can't take it anymore. You run out from under the roof, slam the door closed, and lock it with a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>).
data.reading_hint: You hold the key tightly in your hand and press your ear to the roof. You can still hear the odd person... thing(?) approaching. Hopefully this key keeps it away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're <radical>anti</radical>-<radical>tree</radical>, you won't mind if I turn all of them into <kanji>board</kanji>s! Hahaha!
data.meaning_hint: "Boards are much more useful than trees." - The Anti-Tree Association. Now picture this sign on a big machine that's cutting up all the trees into big boards.
data.reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>board</kanji>s are now being sold to <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo, who's going to smuggle them all over the universe.
data.reading_hint: "Hey kid, I got nothin' against the trees. Business is business, and these trees are gonna get me out of debt," Han says, mussing up your hair. You don't know if you like him anymore.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> you use to <radical>go</radical> from place to place is the <kanji>street</kanji>. Back in the old days, all roads were made of dirt, not like the newfangled roads of today.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine using a dirt street to go from one place to another.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're walking down the <kanji>street</kanji>, staring at the dirt, a <reading>guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>) bumps into you, "Hey guy, watch where you're going!" As he says this he bumps into another guy. "Watch it guy, I'm walkin' in this street!" "Woah guy, this isn't your business, this is my street!"
data.reading_hint: You walk away from the two guys yelling and head down a different street. You hope all streets aren't full of loud guys.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> you <radical>jackhammer</radical> your <kanji>religion</kanji> into people.
data.meaning_hint: It's a religion building. They have a lot of different names, churches, mosques, temples, cathedrals, but none of those matter. All that matters is that you really drill whichever religion you want into the heads of the people who come under your roof.
