data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>religion</kanji> requires everyone to take off their <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). Mostly because the shoes will help them resist the jackhammering, so you tell them that to join your religion they have to leave their shoes at the door.
data.reading_hint: Picture the pile of shoes left outside. If you see a bunch of shoes like this you can be sure there's a religious place around here.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>servant</radical> sits on a <radical>stool</radical>, holding a piece of <radical>thread</radical>, looking very <kanji>tense</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You walk by this tense servant and pause for a moment. They raise their tense eyes up at you and you can see they're shaking.
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask the servant why they're so <kanji>tense</kanji>, and they say they've been assigned to assassinate the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England with this piece of thread.
data.reading_hint: Imagine how tense you would be if you were about to try to murder the King! Your entire body would tense up, maybe to the point that you wouldn't be able to actually go through with it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who is <radical>good</radical> is my <kanji>daughter</kanji>. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it.
data.meaning_hint: Look at how good this woman is! She’s my daughter! She’s good! You wish your daughter was as good a woman as mine is!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>daughter</kanji>, on the other hand, is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a <reading>moose who may</reading> (<ja>むすめ</ja>) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things.
data.reading_hint: Think about how your daughter is basically a moose who may do dumb things. How ashamed you feel. How very, very ashamed. Unlike how I feel about my wonderful, perfect, not a moose-like daughter.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>roof</radical>, but still in the <radical>sun</radical>, a <radical>woman</radical> is laying out a fabulous <kanji>banquet</kanji>. The woman doesn't want anyone to burn from the sun, but banquets are best outside, so she's set up a roof to protect her and her guests.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a large banquet of food on a sunny day, covered by an outdoor roof, and a woman carefully setting it all up.
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the <kanji>banquet</kanji> roof comes crashing down right before the guests arrive, and it <reading>end</reading>s (<ja>えん</ja>) before it can start.
data.reading_hint: Honestly though, have you ever been to a banquet that ended well? Something always goes wrong when you have that many people under one roof.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>soul</radical> of a <radical>narwhal</radical> was sucked into its <radical>towel</radical>, which is <kanji>scary</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Watch as the narwhal's face contorts as you see its soul get slurped out by the towel it was using.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch this <kanji>scary</kanji> scene you can't help but mutter, "<reading>Foo</reading>l," (<ja>ふ</ja>) under your breath. Then you hear "Fool, fool, fool, it's too scary you fool!" and you realize all of the other narwhals are chanting.
data.reading_hint: You don't know what's more scary. That the narwhal's soul got sucked out, or that all of its kind is calling it a fool now that it's dead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>saw</radical> cuts into your <radical>heart</radical> and you are filled with <kanji>fear</kanji>. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever.
data.meaning_hint: Try and imagine this saw slicing into your heart. Are you filled with fear? You should be.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even more so than your <kanji>fear</kanji> of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. You always wanted to take a trip to <ja>きょうと</ja>, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go.
data.reading_hint: I fear you’ll never make it to <ja>きょうと</ja>. Think of <ja>きょうと</ja> and how you long for it as you slowly die from that saw wound to the heart.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>tsunami</radical> in <radical>heaven</radical> and you take a <radical>small</radical> <radical>drop</radical> of water and <kanji>append</kanji> it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability.
data.meaning_hint: Take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Feel the drop of water on your finger and visualize yourself flicking it at the tsunami as it races towards heaven.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just after you <kanji>append</kanji> the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows <reading>ten</reading> (<ja>てん</ja>) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall.
data.reading_hint: Look up at this ten story tall tsunami. It looks big and powerful. Feel the water spray from the tsunami as it towers over you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>animal</radical> eats a <radical>child</radical> from a <radical>plate</radical> in a very <kanji>fierce</kanji> manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style.
data.meaning_hint: See the fierce animal fiercely eating the child from the plate. It’s very gruesome. See blood and body parts flying everywhere as the animal devours the child.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason this <kanji>fierce</kanji> animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to <reading>mow</reading> (<ja>もう</ja>) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him.
data.reading_hint: That child really shouldn’t have forgotten to mow the lawn. Imagine you are the child, being eaten by the fierce animal and wishing that you would have just mowed the lawn like you said you would.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>yakuza</radical>'s <radical>knife</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s, you know something very <kanji>violent</kanji> and <kanji>intense</kanji> is about to happen.
data.meaning_hint: The yakuza member is so upset his knife boils. Right after, they will definitely get violent and intense.
data.reading_mnemonic: When someone gets <kanji>violent</kanji> or <kanji>intense</kanji>, they always yell "<reading>Let's</reading> (<ja>れつ</ja>) get violent and intense!"
data.reading_hint: In the case of our mnemonic, it's a yakuza member getting violent. So, imagine a yakuza member saying "Ret's get violent!" before doing just that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>cross</radical> in your <radical>forehead</radical> with a <radical>thread</radical> attached to it, forcing you to <kanji>search</kanji> where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on.
data.meaning_hint: It hurts to have this cross stuck in your forehead, but try to ignore that as you search for where the thread leads. Imagine gathering the thread in your hands as you move along.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>search</kanji> is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a <reading>sack</reading> (<ja>さく</ja>). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?!
data.reading_hint: Why are there more crosses and threads in the sack? Are you supposed to take them from the sack and throw them at other people’s foreheads? Maybe. Imagine yourself reaching into the sack and throwing the crosses at other people.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Say</radical> <radical>good luck</radical> to one person enough and they'll be <kanji>stuffed</kanji> full of that luck.
data.meaning_hint: Better safe than sorry. Don't just say good luck once, make sure they're stuffed!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>stuffed</kanji> them by saying good luck <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) whole times!
data.reading_hint: Picture a person with the actual words "good luck" stuffed into their body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>demon</radical> on a <radical>jet</radical> is pretty <kanji>alluring</kanji>. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.
data.meaning_hint: See this demon flying around in his jet. Do you feel allured? You should. Hear the roar of the jet engine as the demon cackles.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>alluring</kanji> demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. <reading>Me</reading>at (<ja>み</ja>). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.
data.reading_hint: The demon won’t be so alluring once you see him scarfing down humans, tearing the meat from their bones. How gross.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're stuck in a <radical>prison</radical> on the <radical>sun</radical> with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>. Lucky for you a <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you take your spoon and use the tsunami to quench your <kanji>thirst</kanji>. You spoon the hot, hot water into your mouth as fast as you can. This is the only way to get water on the sun.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this thirst of yours. You've been in this sun prison for longer than you can remember. You've been holding onto this spoon, waiting for this moment for so long.
data.reading_mnemonic: This method of quenching your <kanji>thirst</kanji> reminds you of being in a <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh (<ja>かわ</ja>). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right?
data.reading_hint: Imagine quenching your thirst in a real car wash. Open your mouth and let the soapy water dump on over and in you. You'll never be thirsty again!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>lineage</radical> radical and the <kanji>lineage</kanji> kanji are the same.
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: You trace your <kanji>lineage</kanji> back and realize that every single person in your family loved <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>). Most of them were cake bakers, too!
data.reading_hint: You come from a lineage of cake makers and eaters. No wonder you love cake so much! (And if you hate cake, no wonder your family doesn't like you.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: You meet a <radical>woman</radical> from another <radical>clan</radical> under the rising <radical>sun</radical> to prepare for <kanji>marriage</kanji>. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together.
data.meaning_hint: Marriage is a big deal and it's going to connect your two clans, so you have to do the ceremony in the sun in front of everyone so they can see.
data.reading_mnemonic: For the <kanji>marriage</kanji> to be official, you need to wait for a <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman.
data.reading_hint: Do you want to go through with this marriage? You better hope you see a condor then! It's the official bird of love and unification, ya know. That's why so many people wait until they're older to get married these days, because there aren't as many condors thanks to deforestation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>scooter</radical> running in one <radical>direction</radical> is a <radical>gun</radical>-toting <radical>child</radical>. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just <kanji>play</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a child riding a scooter with a gun having a good time. "Come play with me!" they shout. "No!" you yell back.
data.reading_mnemonic: Everything is <kanji>play</kanji> for <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one.
data.reading_hint:
Imagine trying to explain to the youth that this is not play and that they should stop, but them youths can't stop playing.

P.S. From the WaniKani staff to you: Don't let youths play with guns, please.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Traveling in the <radical>direction</radical> of the ocean, you take a <radical>gun</radical> and shoot a <radical>crab</radical>, then stick a <kanji>flag</kanji> in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to.
data.meaning_hint: Look at your flag and hear it flapping in the wind. Also hear your ears ringing a bit from when you shot that crab. Look at all the bits of exploded crab strewn around the area. Yowza.
data.reading_mnemonic: To make sure that no one removes your <kanji>flag</kanji>, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself locking this flag up with your key. Imagine turning the key in the lock and hearing the click when it is secured.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is being <radical>call</radical>ed on to <radical>boil</radical> the earth by <kanji>illuminating</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: We don't want the earth to actually boil, but we do want some of that boiling hot sun light to illuminate all of the darkness of the universe and let us see.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person who calls the sun asking it to <kanji>illuminate</kanji> the earth is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun calling out to the sun, asking it to illuminate our planet with its boiling hot rays. You better thank the Shougun the next time you see him for everything he does for you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>soul</radical> of a <radical>person</radical> has a <radical>hook</radical> that can make them <kanji>pleasant</kanji>. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body?
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that feeling you get when everything is just SO pleasant. There is a pressure from your soul's hook digging in. It's a good feeling though, a pleasant one! It isn't too hard or too soft.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you want to feel this <kanji>pleasant</kanji> feeling just look at a <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now.
data.reading_hint: Go look up pictures of kayaks to get some of that pleasant high. Mm, your soul is hooking you real good.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you are <radical>anti</radical> <radical>one sided</radical> paper you should bind them all up into an <kanji>edition</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: One sided paper is just anti everything. It's bad for the environment. It's bad for easy reading. Put all those one sided papers together into one, big edition instead.
data.reading_mnemonic: The first <kanji>edition</kanji> you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo. You hated how short and one sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore!
data.reading_hint: Please read my super special Han Solo edition of the Star Wars story. I ripped out all the one sided pages that had him in it and put them into a single edition together so it's just the good stuff now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Those that can only eat a <radical>part</radical> of a <radical>shellfish</radical> are probably a bit <kanji>poor</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Poor people can't even afford a whole shellfish. They have to settle with just a part.
data.reading_mnemonic: And since they are <kanji>poor</kanji>, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash <reading>bin</reading> (<ja>びん</ja>). It's quite unfortunate.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a poor person going through a garbage bin to find only a part of of a shellfish. What a sad sight.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you look for a <radical>leaf</radical> among the <radical>hills</radical> you will notice they are <kanji>scarce</kanji>. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being on the hills. You want a leaf to find and take back as a souvenir but there are none. Imagine looking feverishly for a leaf even though you don’t really expect to find one.
data.reading_mnemonic: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too <kanji>scarce</kanji> to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree.
data.reading_hint: Leaves are scarce here because someone is using these hills for their bowling. The bowling balls knock over everything, and leaves can't grow.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> with a <radical>mohawk</radical>, now that's the most <kanji>suitable</kanji> hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter!
data.meaning_hint: You keep seeing scooters all over the city with mohawks and you can't get it out of your head that it's the most suitable thing you've ever seen.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want this <kanji>suitable</kanji> hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a <reading>techie</reading> (<ja>てき</ja>), so it's easy for you to install one.
data.reading_hint: Imagine going online to check out some of your techie message boards and learning the most suitable mohawk for your scooter then installing it yourself.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to buy a <radical>geoduck</radical> you have to go to the bank <radical>beforehand</radical> to <kanji>deposit</kanji> enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy even one! They're expensive, after all.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself depositing your money beforehand. Imagine the delicious geoduck you'll be able to buy now that the money has been deposited into your account!
data.reading_mnemonic: You go to the bank to make the <kanji>deposit</kanji> and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<ja>よ</ja>). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo! Now you can't see! Now you can't make the deposit!
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to make a deposit to your bank after getting hit in the face with a yo-yo. You can hardly see what you're shoving your money into. You hope it isn't the hands of the kid that hit you!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you do <radical>yoga</radical> <radical>correct</radical>ly, you will not only <kanji>prolong</kanji> your body but your life!
data.meaning_hint: Do you want to prolong your life? Then do yoga correctly!
data.reading_mnemonic: You can <kanji>prolong</kanji> your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just <reading>en</reading>d (<ja>えん</ja>) suddenly.
data.reading_hint: Correct yoga will prolong your life but no yoga will end it. Do you think that's a fair trade?

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are some <radical>feathers</radical> resting on a <radical>stand</radical> and you and <kanji>the following</kanji> of the feathers are <kanji>following</kanji> the feathers. The feathers have a following, and you are one member of the following. You and your fellow followers follow the feathers wherever they may go.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you and the following following the feathers all around. Following the feathers isn’t always easy, but you do it anyway. Imagine touching one of the feathers and feeling the smooth texture on your skin.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you and <kanji>the following</kanji> are <kanji>following</kanji> the feathers from their departure from the stand, one of the members of the following drops an egg and <reading>yolk</reading> (<ja>よく</ja>) spills everywhere. What a mess! Being a quick thinker, you use one of the feathers to soak up the yolk and clean up the mess.
data.reading_hint: Imagine cleaning up egg yolk with a feather. The rest of the following follows your example and takes the other feathers, helping you clean up the yolk.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>servant</radical> holding a <radical>gun</radical> sits on the <radical>ground</radical> to <radical>see</radical> if he can find something to <kanji>look at</kanji>. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this servant. He’s doing a great job. Oops, look like he sees you. Yup, he’s pointing his gun at you. Imagine staring down the barrel of his gun as you slowly back away.
data.reading_mnemonic: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy (<ja>らん</ja>) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, <kanji>look at</kanji> this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.
data.reading_hint: Pretend you are Macho Man Randy Savage. Run at this servant guy, take his gun away, and beat him up. Ohhh yeaaahhh!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> will <radical>cross</radical> through your body and into the <radical>net</radical> of your <radical>clothes</radical> so that you'll be hit with <kanji>nostalgia</kanji> when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes.
data.meaning_hint: When you put on an old piece of clothing, a shirt maybe, or some pants, feel the nostalgia that was embedded in it and left there by your soul.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>nostalgia</kanji> ties <reading>knots</reading> (<ja>なつ</ja>) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides.
data.reading_hint: Feel these nostalgic knots inside you. Now tie knots in the clothes that make you feel nostalgic so you don't wear them again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical>, put them on this <radical>turtle shell</radical>, and <kanji>push</kanji> push push! Push the turtle right on out of there.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself using your fingers to push a turtle out of its shell. It really doesn't want to leave, so you have to push really hard.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>push</kanji> this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new <reading>o</reading>bi (<ja>お</ja>). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first.
data.reading_hint: Imagine pushing some turtle shells flat to make a beautiful obi. Wear it out, watch everyone gasp in awe. Oh... oh no! They're trying to push you out of your obi like you did the turtle. They're mad about your turtle crime!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>ground</radical> of the <radical>rice paddy</radical> is a <radical>treasure</radical>. You pull it out of the mucky ground. This will <kanji>renew</kanji> your life for the better. <kanji>Again</kanji>, this treasure will change your life!
data.meaning_hint: Pull out the treasure. Think about all the things you will be able to renew in your life. Your car. Your boat. Your house. You lost it all but now you'll be able to get it back.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Again</kanji>, you are going to <kanji>renew</kanji> your life! Everything will be better. Then, the person who caused all this grief grabs your treasure and runs. <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> is running off with the treasure that was supposed to renew your life!
data.reading_hint: Yell at <ja>こういち</ja> to give your treasure back. Then, fall to the muck as you realize you won't be able to renew your life anymore.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> <radical>pirate</radical> jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a <kanji>pillow</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It hurts a little bit, but the fact that tree pirates use pillows as their weapons is a bit anticlimactic.
data.reading_mnemonic: As he hits you with his <kanji>pillow</kanji> he makes a demand: "Give me your <reading>Mac cooler</reading> (<ja>まくら</ja>). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer.
data.reading_hint: You give him your Mac cooler and he goes on his way. He's quite happy he can cool down his Mac, now. The trees are quite warm and he hears this will help to cool down his tree apples.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> knocks a <radical>cleat</radical> off a <radical>child</radical> and the shoe begins to <kanji>float</kanji> away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami.
data.meaning_hint: Your cleat is floating away but you’re floating too. The water is really deep now, but you try and float towards your cleat to retrieve it. Imagine floating in this wet water reaching for your lost cleat.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you <kanji>float</kanji> in the water, an <reading>u</reading>ni (<ja>う</ja>) jabs into your foot. “<reading>Uwa</reading>aa~ (<ja>うわ</ja>)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~”
data.reading_hint: Say “Uwaaa~” out loud a few times while you imagine an <ja>うに</ja> stabbing you as you float along with the tsunami water. What a day you’ve had.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> rips a <radical>flag</radical> off your house in the <radical>rain</radical>, causing a <kanji>leak</kanji> where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this leak in your house and see the rain water coming in. Hear it drip drip dripping down the wall.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>leak</kanji> is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm!
data.reading_hint: Did you know that roe can plug any leak? It’s true. If you don’t mind wasting some, you should break a leak into your own house and then try to plug it back up again with some salmon roe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take some <radical>bamboo</radical> and <radical>attach</radical> it together into a <kanji>token</kanji> of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to attach some bamboo together into a token for someone.
data.reading_mnemonic: You hand over the <kanji>token</kanji> but your friend drops it and yells, "You <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>)! I'm allergic to bamboo!"
data.reading_hint: Imagine the embarrassment you feel, forgetting they were allergic to bamboo. Oh well, it’s the thought that counts. You’re still a fool, though.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Picture a <radical>shellfish</radical> <radical>lifeguard</radical>. They're not going anywhere. First, they're a shellfish, so they can't really move. And, they're a lifeguard, so they need to be in their lifeguard tower. How does this shellfish lifeguard get stuff? Through <kanji>subscription</kanji> services.
data.meaning_hint: See a bunch of subscription boxes around the lifeguard tower. It gets everything this way.
data.reading_mnemonic: The shellfish lifeguard's favorite <kanji>subscription</kanji> is its subscription to <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> magazine. It has all the latest <ja>こういち</ja> versions, news, and interviews.
data.reading_hint:
See the shellfish lifeguard drooling as its <ja>こういち</ja> magazine subscription arrives. "I will read this one now, but I can't wait until next month," it says as a boat sinks in the distance.

Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be <ja>こう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>run</radical> every day and soon you <radical>become</radical> a human that can <kanji>go beyond</kanji> the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.
data.meaning_hint: Run fast! Go beyond the limits imposed upon you by nature! Imagine yourself running faster than any human has ever run ever. Feel yourself cutting through the air, wind breaking across you as you break the sound barrier. Boom!
data.reading_mnemonic: To solidify your ability to <kanji>go beyond</kanji> the abilities of other humans, you <reading>etch</reading> (<ja>えつ</ja>) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.
data.reading_hint: Etch these runes into your legs. Go ahead and run a finger over your legs and pretend to etch runes into them. These runes you etch will allow you to run fast forever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <radical>eat</radical> you want to see the shape of your <radical>gun</radical> from under a <radical>towel</radical>, so you <kanji>decorate</kanji> your house with them.
data.meaning_hint: Just picture it: an entire home decorated top to bottom with guns covered in towels, so only the outline shows. As your guests try to eat you say, "Guess what gun this is?! Haha, you got it wrong, pull the towel back."
data.reading_mnemonic: If you actually <kanji>decorate</kanji> your house like this it will give people quite a <reading>shock</reading> (<ja>しょく</ja>). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming.
data.reading_hint: Maybe you should be more conscious of other people when you decorate. Or at least, don't shock people into fainting or yelling or leaving. Guns do that, you know?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> gets trapped in a small room with a <radical>stool</radical> and an <radical>insect</radical>, and together they create a very <kanji>boisterous</kanji> situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the boisterous sounds coming from this small room. Hear the horse neigh and stomp his hooves, hear the insect buzzing loudly, and hear the wooden stool rattle around as the horse and insect try to escape the room.
data.reading_mnemonic: At the height of their <kanji>boisterous</kanji> sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling.
data.reading_hint: The horse gets even more frightened now that it killed the insect and saw an actual soul float by its head and it grows even more boisterous.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You fly <radical>north</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> and break your <kanji>back</kanji> when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine flying north to the moon. Feel the force of being rocketed through space on your journey. Now feel your spine telescope and your back break. It really smarts.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>back</kanji> hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>) form. 

I flew to the moon.
It is there I broke my back.
My back hurts real bad.
data.reading_hint: Say this haiku out loud. Memorize it and use this haiku to remember this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put your <radical>fingers</radical> and an <radical>ear</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical> so you can get your <kanji>photograph</kanji> taken. This is a glamour <kanji>photo</kanji>, so you have to be in one of these weird, cheesy poses for it to come out jusssst right.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting your fingers and your ear on a stool, now try to relax your head a little bit, and smile for the camera. This is a professional photograph, so you better do what you're told!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're getting the <kanji>photograph</kanji> taken, the photographer suddenly gets angry at you. "You <reading>sat</reading> (<ja>さつ</ja>) down!" he screams. "I sat down?" you ask. "Yes! And now the photo is ruined!"
data.reading_hint: You've never gotten a professional photograph taken before, but if you had known if you sat(s) down you'd ruin the shot you never would have. Remember everyone, if you sat down while your photo was being taken, you ruined it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>next</radical> <radical>plate</radical> is the one you will <kanji>steal</kanji>. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one.
data.meaning_hint: Wait for this next plate. Here it is—now steal it! Imagine stealing this plate and making off with it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>steal</kanji> this plate from a <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja> restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of <ja>とうきょう</ja> as you lose your pursuers.
data.reading_hint: Be careful not to drop that plate! Wouldn’t want to steal something just to break it. Imagine running through the streets of <ja>とうきょう</ja>. See all the sights and hear all the sounds. Just don’t get too distracted, you gotta get to a safe place and stash your stolen plate away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rocket</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> has several points which will <kanji>detach</kanji> during takeoff.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the rocket turkey taking off. Just like a regular rocket, as it goes up, used pieces of the turkey rocket detach and fall back to the ground.
data.reading_mnemonic: When the rocket turkey parts <kanji>detach</kanji>, they fall to the ground onto a bed of <reading>ree</reading>ds <reading>り</reading>.
data.reading_hint: The reeds catch on fire - probably best not to fire off turkey rockets so close to these fields of reeds. Imagine the launch site completely surrounded by reeds.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>bully</radical> take an <radical>insect</radical> and <kanji>dissolve</kanji> it in some acid. Bullies are messed up, mean people. They do awful things that normal kids and people wouldn't do... like dissolve a living creature.
data.meaning_hint: Actually... try to forget this one. Don't think about a bully dissolving things in acid. Think happy thoughts. Like... the bully getting dissolved instead and all the little insects coming back to life and being happy.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only bullies heartless enough to <kanji>dissolve</kanji> insects like this are youths (<reading>ゆう</reading>). Do you really think an adult would melt a harmless critter? No. Only inexperienced youths could be so cruel.
data.reading_hint: When you first read this and you pictured the bully dissolving the insect, you pictured them as a youth, right? See? It makes complete sense.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Bring <radical>thread</radical> to the <radical>library</radical> to <kanji>knit</kanji>. Libraries are quiet and generally pretty empty nowadays, so it's the perfect place to relax and do some knitting. Of course, if you find thread lying around in a library you know what to do now.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself sitting on a rocking chair in the library knitting away. It's quiet and peaceful and the light is warming you just right. Ahh, bliss!
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to come to the library to <kanji>knit</kanji> because if you try to do it at home all your <reading>hen</reading>s (<ja>へん</ja>) will try to eat the thread. Hens love eating things that look like worms, like hay, string, and thread. So it's important to get far away from them before you start to knit.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the granny or grampy you are (and must be to have hens and want to knit in peace in a library). You're tired of these hens eating your thread while you try to knit sweaters for all your grandbabies so you come to the library.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> growing out of a <radical>rice paddy</radical> into the shape of a <radical>cross</radical> are really <kanji>showy</kanji> <kanji>flower</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture these showy flowers growing straight up and out of the middle of the rice paddy, into the shape of a giant cross.
data.reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>flower</kanji>s are too <kanji>showy</kanji>. You hate them. You hate these showy flowers so much you run them over with your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Imagine how the car feels as you ram into the showy flowers. The petals explode and rain everywhere. You turn on your windshield wipers to push them away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>root</radical> where your <radical>fang</radical> <kanji>previously</kanji> was. Your fang isn't there anymore, you ripped it out.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the root where your fang previously was. Previously, when you were young, you had a lot of nice fangs but they're all rotting as you get older and you pull them out.
data.reading_mnemonic: To remember the beautiful fangs you <kanji>previously</kanji> had, you keep all of the ones you pull out in a box you lock with a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Previously you didn't have a key, but now you do to keep your old fangs safe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>line up</radical> your body with the <radical>sun</radical> and everything looks <kanji>normal</kanji>.  The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal.
data.meaning_hint: Gaze out in a line from the sun as you observe the world. Everything is very normal looking and comforting.
data.reading_mnemonic: Soon you see something that doesn’t look so <kanji>normal</kanji>. It’s a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this creepy looking fool as he approaches. He’s kind of freaking you out. Feel very uncomfortable as you continue looking at this fool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>lid</radical> on a dish you're cooking, made up of the <radical>mouth</radical>s and <radical>forehead</radical>s of a <radical>pig</radical>. Unknown to most, these are the juiciest, most delicious parts of a pig. And dang, they are the most <kanji>luxurious</kanji>, too.
data.meaning_hint: Mix those pig mouths and foreheads in your pot. Think of how luxurious your soup looks.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Luxurious</kanji> pig mouth forehead soup is a favorite of Grandpa Koichi (<ja><reading>ごう</reading>いち</ja>). You see him sniffing around your window, then he knocks and waves.
data.reading_hint: "Can I have some of your luxurious soup?" Grandpa Koichi asks. "It smells so swell."

data.meaning_mnemonic: You are given some <radical>gold</radical> to <radical>oversee</radical> a <kanji>model</kanji>. You are a famous architect, so you get a lot of gold for overseeing the construction of models like this one.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you oversee this model being built. Observe it and watch as it grows under your watchful eye.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the <kanji>model</kanji> nears completion, you realize it's taking the shape of Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>). Was that what this was supposed to look like? You were so busy overseeing the gold in your pocket, you forgot!
data.reading_hint: You watch nervously as this model of Genghis Khan is finished. You're really not sure if this is who you were meant to model it after, but it's too late to change it now. Genghis Khan it is!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical>s are at a <radical>surplus</radical>. Because of that, we will need to <kanji>exclude</kanji> some of them from our future plans. Also, we'll need to <kanji>remove</kanji> some buildings too.
data.meaning_hint: Say you're looking at a map of the city, with all the buildings laid out on it. There are too many, so you start marking which ones to exclude from the building plans. You also remove some buildings from the map all together.
data.reading_mnemonic: Working with you on this project to <kanji>exclude</kanji> buildings from the plan, as well as <kanji>remove</kanji> buildings that already exist is little <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (<ja>じょ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: She's pointing out buildings to exclude / remove with great ferocity. "Remove this one. Exclude this one. Oh, and remove this one too."

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Wolverine</radical> is doing a <radical>construction</radical> job and he’s using his <radical>mouth</radical> to <radical>measure</radical> so he knows how many folks he needs to <kanji>inquire</kanji> about helping him with the job. Using one’s mouth is a strange way to measure something, but that’s just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he’ll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire about working for him.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Wolverine going around, measuring the construction site with his mouth. Look at him with his mouth wide open, wandering around the site deep in thought. What a weirdo.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>inquire</kanji> as to why Wolverine is using his mouth to measure out this construction site. As you get closer you notice his cool ripped <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>). Instead you inquire how he got such a fresh style. He looks you up and down, pulls out his claws, and tears yours up to match his. You’ve completely forgotten what it was you were asking, but who cares! Look how great you look!
data.reading_hint: Look down at your ripped up jeans. You’re so fashionable now! Just like good old ‘90s Wolvie.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>poop</radical> twice on a sleeping <radical>drunkard</radical> <radical>person</radical> and you find yourself wondering <kanji>how many</kanji> more times you can poop on them and wonder <kanji>how much</kanji> they can take before they realize what’s going on.
data.meaning_hint: You’ve already pooped twice on this drunkard, how many more times can you do it? How much do you think this person can take? Just imagine yourself doing this.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you continue thinking about <kanji>how much</kanji> poop this drunkard can take and <kanji>how many</kanji> more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you <reading>eke</reading> (<ja>いく</ja>) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as you eke out that last poop. Really concentrate on eking it out so you can get away in time. Flex your butt muscles for added effect.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>canopy</radical> <radical>guy</radical> is a guy who stands in the <kanji>corridor</kanji> trying to sell people canopies.
data.meaning_hint: You walk through this corridor every day, and the canopy guy always accosts you with canopy sales. You wish there was another corridor you could take, but it's the only way to get where you want to go.
data.reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>corridor</kanji>, but this time the canopy guy is gone. In his place is a new salesman. This one is trying to sell you <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The roe salesman in the corridor is worse than the canopy salesman. They're both insistent, but the roe salesman smells bad.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Wolverine</radical> ties a <radical>towel</radical> around his <radical>forehead</radical> and takes out his <radical>fingers</radical> instead of his claws so he can <kanji>sweep</kanji> the floor clean. When Wolverine fights, his claws are out and he makes a big ol' mess. But once the fighting is done, it's time to get to work and sweep the mess up.
data.meaning_hint: Picture Wolverine, hair held back with a towel, claws detracted, sweeping up a bar that he just had a big fight in. He's sweeping up broken bottles and broken chairs and broken evil x-men.
data.reading_mnemonic: Wolverine knows that <kanji>sweep</kanji>ing is good for the <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). Plus, if you don't help clean up after you defeat bad guys, you're just as bad as them. Sweeping up the mess cleans your soul of any guilt too!
data.reading_hint: Sweeping is good for the soul. Sweeping is good for the soul. Sweeping is like chicken soup for the soul.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> came in and buried your <radical>flag</radical> so now you have to use a <radical>spoon</radical> and dig it out of the <kanji>mud</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine using a spoon to dig your flag outta all this mud. So much mud! Feel its cold, soiled wetness on your hands as you dig away.
data.reading_mnemonic: The time of <reading>day</reading> (<ja>でい</ja>) is high noon, so the sun soon dries the <kanji>mud</kanji> and makes it harder to dig through. It just might take you all day to spoon your way through this mud.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself out in the day, continuing to dig through the now hardened mud. Feel your arm getting tired as day slowly turns to night.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> in <radical>spring</radical> that's nice and <radical>dry</radical> will make a good <kanji>pole</kanji> or <kanji>rod</kanji>. Break it out of the ground and it's just flexible enough for tons of applications.
data.meaning_hint: Use this pole to hang your towels or curtains. Ooh, use it to pole vault!
data.reading_mnemonic: After much deliberation, you decide to use this <kanji>pole</kanji> to go <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>). You line up a few more poles for the pins, and roll a rock toward them.
data.reading_hint: You decide to name this super hard, pole bowling tree-pole-pin bowling. Even harder than candlepin. The thinnest, most extreme pole bowling of all time!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you can write an interesting <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> while riding on a <radical>horse</radical>, I’ll be pretty <kanji>surprised</kanji>. It’s hard enough to write a poem as it is, let alone an interesting one. And then you’re riding on a horse and the poem has to be about winter? Heck, I’d be surprised if you didn’t fall off the horse and injure yourself.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to write a poem while riding a horse. It’d be really hard to do. I bet you’d be surprised if you managed to do it as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You might also be <kanji>surprised</kanji> to learn that you are to ride this horse all across <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. That gives you a time limit. You have until you traverse <ja>きょうと</ja> to write this poem about winter.
data.reading_hint: Imagine riding through <ja>きょうと</ja> on a horse. As if that wasn’t difficult enough for poem writing, now you have all the sights and sounds of <ja>きょうと</ja> to distract you as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>mouth</radical> when you see a <radical>Chinese</radical> person and you <kanji>sigh</kanji>. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia.
data.meaning_hint: Let out a long sigh as you recall memories from China and all the Chinese things you saw and did. Oh, sigh.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your favorite Chinese thing to do is <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will <kanji>sigh</kanji> or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on.
data.reading_hint: Sigh again as you remember how nice it was to tan everywhere. Picture yourself wandering around some Chinese streets with your shirt off as you soak in the rays and get a tan.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>warehouse</radical> radical and the <kanji>warehouse</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>warehouse</kanji> to store all of your <reading>sou</reading>ls (<ja>そう</ja>). When people or animals you know pass away, you take their souls and store them in your dry warehouse for safekeeping. It's a public service, really.
data.reading_hint: Imagine if you kept a bunch of souls in a warehouse. This way they can't haunt anyone. And they can't get lost out in the spirit world. The warehouse is best for them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>child</radical> shares his <radical>lineage</radical> with a <kanji>grandchild</kanji>. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this family tree. See the child, and then the grandchild. Trace the lineage with your finger as you observe.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <reading>son</reading> (<ja>そん</ja>) of a son is a <kanji>grandchild</kanji>. In this case, a grandson. Easy.
data.reading_hint: Just remember that a son is all you really want. You need a son to carry on the family name and the lineage. So make sure that your child and your grandchild are both sons.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Birds use <radical>grass</radical> and <radical>fruit</radical> to make their <kanji>nest</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a cute little nest with a family of birds in it. It looks like it was woven together with bits of grass and strawberries, so it smells delicious too.
data.reading_mnemonic: The bottom of the <kanji>nest</kanji> also seems to be padded with someone's <reading>su</reading>it (<ja>す</ja>). Did... did this bird attack a human for this?!
data.reading_hint: Picture the nest, made of grass, fruit, and the suit of the angry salaryman who's shouting below the tree, and missing the top half of his suit.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>mountain</radical> coming out of the <radical>ground</radical> that you want to climb, but your <radical>forehead</radical> needs a <radical>towel</radical> for all your sweat. You don't have a towel, so you take off your <kanji>belt</kanji> and tie it around your forehead.
data.meaning_hint: The belt is easy to tighten and it catches all the sweat before it can fall into your eyes. It isn't quite as absorbent as a towel though.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>belt</kanji> isn't absorbent enough, so you wrap it in your <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>) and then tie the whole thing around your forehead again.
data.reading_hint: It works! Your belt tied in a tie is the perfect invention!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>tombstone</radical> to measure its <kanji>diameter</kanji>. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine loitering around a tombstone. You're leaning on it. You're staring at nothing. Oh, and you're also measuring its diameter.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to know the <kanji>diameter</kanji> of each tombstone so you can make <reading>ca</reading>kes (<ja>けい</ja>) for each one. But the cakes can't be wider than the tombstones, or they'll flop off onto the ground.
data.reading_hint: These carefully measured tombstone-diameter cakes are your special way of saying thanks to the ghosts for letting you loiter around their graves.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>request</radical> that <radical>winter</radical> <kanji>rescue</kanji> you from the warmth of the other seasons.
data.meaning_hint: It's so hot. You hate it. You really hope winter will get your request and come early to rescue you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You get a note in the mail from winter! This is it, you're going to be rescued! You open the note and it says, "I have <kanji>rescue</kanji>d you with this <reading>cu</reading>cumber (<ja>きゅう</ja>)." A cucumber falls out of the note.
data.reading_hint: This cucumber is supposed to be cool and refreshing enough to rescue you from the heat. I guess it was too much to expect winter to come early just for you. At least cucumbers are yummy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you play <radical>blackjack</radical> on the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical>, your cards will <kanji>scatter</kanji> everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine playing blackjack on the moon where even the slightest move causes the cards to scatter about. Watch them float along. It’s very frustrating to play this way.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are playing blackjack with <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the <kanji>scatter</kanji> of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself next to Santa-san as he tries to prevent the cards from scattering. Look at the expression of concentration on Santa-san’s face as he tries to prevent the scatter.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you grind <radical>rice</radical>, every <radical>part</radical> of it, eventually it will become a fine <kanji>powder</kanji>. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself grinding this rice into a powder. Hear the scrape of the rice on stone as you grind it down to the finest powder.
data.reading_mnemonic: Actually, grinding the rice down to a <kanji>powder</kanji> is super <reading>fun</reading> (<ja>ふん</ja>). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN!
data.reading_hint: Okay, we got a little carried away there. Just keep in mind how fun this is. Make sure you say fun with a little bit of a Scottish accent. You know what they say, Scots have more fun!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>moon</radical> while you sit on a <radical>cliff</radical>, you inject a syringe of <radical>tofu</radical> right into your <kanji>vein</kanji>. Ahh, tofu. You’re addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the tofu running through your veins. Feel the tofu goodness spreading all over your body. It’s so intense you can even taste a little tofu in your mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every <kanji>vein</kanji> on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. “You cyan’t <reading>myake</reading> (<ja>みゃく</ja>) me!” You slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. “None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!”
data.reading_hint: Say this out loud, it’ll help you remember. Really focus on the “myake” be sure to say it like you’re all bugged out from tofu overdose.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want some <radical>flowers</radical> so you take your <radical>cleat</radical> to the side of a <radical>tree</radical> hoping they'll fall down, but you get a <kanji>vegetable</kanji> instead. What? You kick the tree again and another, different vegetable falls out.
data.meaning_hint: Now you have two vegetables and no flowers. Do vegetables even grow on trees?
data.reading_mnemonic: You feed these <kanji>vegetable</kanji>s (that you didn't even want) to your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). It only needs a little though, since its stomach is so thin, so you just make it hold the rest.
data.reading_hint: Picture your cyborg nibbling on the vegetables you cleat-kicked out of this tree. You give all of the things you don't like to your cyborg nowadays. Which is probably why there are so many weird things all over it...

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to <radical>change</radical> your <radical>shellfish</radical> into <kanji>freight</kanji> so you can transport it. That means packing them up into giant freight containers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine changing your shellfish from loose, wet form, to solid freight form. It's actually a lot of hard work.
data.reading_mnemonic: To move this <kanji>freight</kanji>, you need a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). You strap all of the freight containers to the top of your car, stacked nice and high and precarious, so you can move it.
data.reading_hint: Picture all of this freight stacked on top of your car. As you drive the car, every turn you make feels slow and heavy from the freight weight.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> made from a <radical>womb</radical> must be placed upon the <kanji>land</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Why must it be placed upon the land? If it were put in water, it would dissolve too quickly. So, you put your womb building on the land, instead.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>land</kanji> around your womb building will, unfortunately, <reading>reek</reading> (<ja>りく</ja>) though.
data.reading_hint: It's made of biological materials, so of course it will reek.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> of (odd looking) <radical>lion</radical>s puts a <radical>drop</radical> of magic liquid on his face to look like a <radical>person</radical> who might <kanji>resemble</kanji> someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms.
data.meaning_hint: Watch this leader as the transformation takes place. Now he doesn’t resemble anything like the leader he used to be. He doesn’t look like the same person. Watch him morph in your head.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason he doesn’t <kanji>resemble</kanji> the same person anymore is because he actually resembles a horse now. The leader is now a horse! Listen to him <reading>neigh</reading> (<ja>ね</ja>) and stamp his feet. Woah, easy there boy!
data.reading_hint: Listen to this horse who used to be a leader neigh and stomp around. Hear the neigh in your ears as you try and calm the horse down.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have some <radical>dirt</radical> next to a <radical>pool</radical> that has an extra <radical>drop</radical> of water in it because you need them to be <kanji>equal</kanji>. If there's too much dirt outside the pool and not enough water inside, it's gonna look weird. We can't have that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a pool that isn't equal. It's like a tiny kiddy pool with an inch of water. And it's surrounded by mounds of dirt. No no no, this won't do—add more water to make them equal.
data.reading_mnemonic: You spend a few hours making sure the water-to-dirt ratio is perfectly <kanji>equal</kanji>, not for yourself, but because the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England told you to. You may agree that equality is important, but it's the King's responsibility to keep things that way. Which is why he ordered you, small peon, to do the equalizing work for him.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so the existence of a king kind of makes things not, well, equal, for all people. But at least aesthetically everything will be!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a strange patch of <radical>dirt</radical> in this <radical>greenhouse</radical> that's actually a <kanji>grave</kanji>. Dig around a little and you'll find the marker buried in there. If you dig deeper you'll probably find less pleasant things.
data.meaning_hint: I guess it makes sense to have a grave in a greenhouse. The heat will help the body decompose, then that nice, rich dirt will help the flowers grow.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to dig even deeper into the <kanji>grave</kanji> out of curiosity and you find a <reading>bow</reading> (<ja>ぼ</ja>) and some arrows. This must be the grave of a great archer! But you probably shouldn't keep digging around in this grave looking for more stuff.
data.reading_hint: Hold the grave bow in your hands. It smells like dirt and wood. Maybe no one will notice if you take it... though you may end up haunted by whoever is buried in this grave.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>scarecrow</radical> because you're <kanji>rich</kanji>. You want to scare away all the poor, non-rich people so you put a scarecrow on your roof.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking up at the roof at this scarecrow. There's a sign around its neck that says, "Rich people welcome." Ah, you're safe. Time to go to bed!
data.reading_mnemonic: You wake up the next morning and all of your <kanji>rich</kanji>es have been stolen! You call the police and they call you a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>)! Pardon me?! "You basically put an advertisement on your roof telling everyone you're rich. Of course you got robbed, you fool."
data.reading_hint: You poor sad, no longer rich fool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're <radical>loiter</radical>ing, staring down at the <radical>cross</radical> that got caught in the <radical>net</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical>, because it's trying to teach you to act with <kanji>virtue</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: People who keep the cross in their hearts are supposed to be full of virtue, always doing the right thing, always helping others. But you aren't sure if you want to be virtuous, it's a lot of responsibility. So you look down at this symbolic cross and loiter instead of making a decision.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you try to decide if you want to live a life of <kanji>virtue</kanji> the ghost of <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.
data.reading_hint: I don't know about you, but I'm pretty sure Tokugawa Ieyasu is telling you to choose a life of virtue.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to get your <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>pi</radical> <radical>tree</radical>, you're going to have to <kanji>look for</kanji> it. This isn't a tree made of pie, or growing fully-baked pies. It's a pi tree, one that exists infinitely. It's the most rare tree in the world. And if you want to stick your fingers in it, you have to <kanji>search for it</kanji>, far and wide!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine it like a quest from a book or movie. You have a band of travelers, and you're all out searching for it together!
data.reading_mnemonic: You try to <kanji>look for</kanji> the pi tree for so long that you can't help but get a very deep <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). You can't search for anything inside, and you definitely can't find the pi tree inside, so you spend a lot of time outside in the bright sun.
data.reading_hint: Feel the sun's rays on your skin as you search and search and search for the tree. Watch as your skin gets darker, crispier, and hmm, smells like cooked meats. Now that's a good tan.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> sticks his <radical>toe</radical> into a <radical>shellfish</radical>. You ask him why and he says he wants to <kanji>spy</kanji> on it.
data.meaning_hint: There’s a hidden camera on his toe and the leader wants to have plenty of secret spy footage to review later.
data.reading_mnemonic: You and the leader review the <kanji>spy</kanji> footage and find a single <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tot hidden within the shellfish. Together you uncover a huge smuggling ring. Clams, oysters, muscles, you name it! Shellfish of all kinds are using their bodies to sneak tater tots to the undersea world.
data.reading_hint: If it wasn't for your toe spy network, these egregious tater tot crimes would have never reached the light of day.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>thread</radical> is <radical>odd</radical>, but that's what makes it <kanji>beautiful</kanji>. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you.
data.meaning_hint: If something is a bit odd, it's usually beautiful in its own way, just like this beautiful thread.
data.reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>beautiful</kanji> thread and lock it up with a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only!
data.reading_hint: To remember that there's a beautiful thread hidden away, you tie a not-as-beautiful thread to the end of the key.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>canopy</radical> comes <radical>beforehand</radical>, it's a <kanji>preface</kanji> for the rest of the canopy.
data.meaning_hint: Although not necessarily a book preface, you can imagine a book made out of canvas pages. The canvas pages that came beforehand (i.e. in the beginning, before the book started) is the preface.
data.reading_mnemonic: You read the <kanji>preface</kanji>. It just goes on and on and on about <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (<ja>じょ</ja>), a short lady the author loves very much.
data.reading_hint: Actually imagine reading through the preface of your favorite book. Except, there's a preface that just goes into great detail about Jo-Anne and doesn't seem related at all to the book.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In its <radical>scooter</radical>, a <radical>cat pirate</radical> scoots up to <kanji>welcome</kanji> you!
data.meaning_hint: "Nya! Welcome to my ship, grab a scooter and scoot on up here, we're about to start the welcome ceremonya!"
data.reading_mnemonic: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they <kanji>welcome</kanji> all kinds of people. Especially <reading>gay</reading> (<ja>げい</ja>) people. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate either thinks you're gay or wants you to be.
data.reading_hint:
You're really happy this cat pirate welcomes gay people aboard. Whether that's because you're gay or just because you're a baseline decent human being is up to you.

Also if you aren't the kind of person who would welcome gay people onto your cat pirate ship, you should just leave nyaow.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you can understand a <radical>samurai</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>, you'll discover their true <kanji>intention</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: If you're facing down a samurai, it's pretty important for you to be able to understand their intentions. Not all samurai are good, you know.
data.reading_mnemonic: You try to read the <kanji>intention</kanji>s of the samurai in front of you and they're dark, evil, scary. Oh no! These are the intentions of the <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) samurai!
data.reading_hint: The sheep samurai only has violent intentions for other samurai and sheep. Its heart is dark and surprisingly easy to read.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <radical>big</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> but a good <radical>heart</radical>, people will recognize your <kanji>kindness</kanji>. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you.
data.meaning_hint: Share your kindness with the world. Use your big mouth to let people know what you’re doing. “I’M TAKING OUT THE TRASH AND NOBODY EVEN ASKED ME!” Y’know, that sort of thing. Go ahead and say that out loud a few times.
data.reading_mnemonic: To further show your <kanji>kindness</kanji>, you chop up some <reading>on</reading>ions (<ja>おん</ja>) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it’s a nice act of kindness that you’re toughing it out for your pal.
data.reading_hint: Imagine chopping up these onions. Smell the onion smell in the air as your eyes begin to sting from the onions. Your friend had better appreciate this kindness.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> and dig the <radical>tree</radical> bits out of this <radical>cleat</radical> to <kanji>gather</kanji> it into evidence. Gather it in a pile or a bag, just make sure it's all in one place so you can take a closer look later.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your fingers really getting in there to gather the tree pieces from out of this cleat. Some of the tree bits are stabbing under your fingernails, but you have to keep gathering them, don't stop now!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>gather</kanji> them all together and realize there are <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>) parts mixed in with the tree bits. Uh oh, it's as you feared. Your cyborg definitely got into trouble somewhere around here and you walked all over it with your cleats.
data.reading_hint: Gather all of these cyborg bits so you can find it and reattach them later.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>tree</radical> sitting on the <radical>grass</radical> is a <radical>woman</radical> who loves <kanji>sakura</kanji>, or <kanji>cherry tree</kanji>, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself sitting under the tree in the grass with the woman. Smell the cherries and see the sakura blossoms falling down all around you. How whimsical.
data.reading_mnemonic: How do you say <kanji>cherry tree</kanji> in Japanese? <reading>Sakura</reading> (<ja>さくら</ja>). <kanji>Sakura</kanji> is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember.
data.reading_hint: Sakura means cherry tree and sakura is the way to pronounce this kanji. Easy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eternity</radical> radical and the <kanji>eternity</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: How long is an <kanji>eternity</kanji>? Just look at this little <reading>a</reading>corn (<ja>えい</ja>) and ask. The acorn starts small but it grows into a huge tree and can live for all eternity by dropping more acorns to create more trees. Its acorn line will live on forever!
data.reading_hint: It's the miracle of eternal life!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> that hits at <radical>night</radical> leaves even more <kanji>fluid</kanji> than normal. It's dark at night, so the sun isn't there to help evaporate all that tsunami <kanji>liquid</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the dark fluids from the tsunami flowing by your window at night. You look out and the liquid is shining in the moonlight. It looks like an entire sea is out there!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>fluid</kanji> stays in the <ja><reading>駅</reading></ja> (<ja>えき</ja>) longer than anywhere else. All of those tsunami liquids pour deep inside the <ja>駅</ja> late at night and the sun still can't reach them to help evaporate them during the day. It's a real *night*mare.
data.reading_hint: Picture the <ja>駅</ja> filled to the brim with fluids and liquids. Maybe if you swim, you'll be able to catch your train.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical>'s <radical>root</radical> is the <kanji>eyeball</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Go ahead and feel your eyeballs moving around in your head. Your eyes aren't just the part on the surface, they're the whole balls in there, attached at the root.
data.reading_mnemonic: You know who has some pretty good <kanji>eyeball</kanji>s? <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (<ja>がん</ja>). Gandhi used his eyes to see the oppression around him and decided to do something about it. But it's all thanks to his eyeballs.
data.reading_hint: Look at Gandhi’s eyeball with your eyeball. It's pretty remarkable.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You come across a <radical>spirit</radical> wearing a <radical>top hat</radical> and it claims to be your <kanji>ancestor</kanji>. Well of course, if you remember correctly, all of your ancestors wore top hats when they were alive. This spirit must be your long lost, great great... uh... somebody.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine coming across your long dead top hatted ancestor in spirit form. What would you do? What would you say?
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask your <kanji>ancestor</kanji> what it wants and it points to the <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>) by the sink. Soap? It nods at you. I guess your ancestor is here to see the wonders of soap.
data.reading_hint: Your ancestor didn't come here to see you, it just wanted to learn about soap. Something that they didn't have back when it was alive. That's actually kinda sad... and stinky. Your ancestor needs to use this soap, if anything.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking a piece of <radical>thread</radical> you <radical>blame</radical> the <kanji>exploits</kanji> of your past on poor judgment. You tie this thread around your finger to remind you of all the exploits you accomplished in your day. Most of them weren’t actually on purpose, so you blame them on poor judgment and accident.
data.meaning_hint: Think up what exploits you accomplished. What sort of things might you have done, but not quite on purpose? Think about how it feels to be exalted for such exploits that were but mere accidents.
data.reading_mnemonic: One of your <kanji>exploits</kanji> was when you got dressed in the dark and were wearing funny clothes and everyone thought that it was <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>). The newspapers and fashion agencies couldn’t get enough of your sexy style.
data.reading_hint: Imagine setting this sexy fashion trend on accident. Imagine what you were wearing when you got dressed in the dark. Probably a pretty strange, mismatched outfit.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>comb</radical> and what looks like the <radical>same</radical> <radical>comb</radical>, and you found them on the <radical>ground</radical> next to some <radical>fins</radical> you showed <kanji>interest</kanji> in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that are interesting too.
data.meaning_hint: Pick up these fins and the two combs. Feel their weight in each hand as you examine them with interest. Smell the fish smell and feel the teeth on the combs.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since the combs <kanji>interest</kanji> you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. Dang, <ja>きょうと</ja> sure does make some nice combs.
data.reading_hint: You've always had an interest in <ja>きょうと</ja>, so it makes sense that you'd be interested in things from <ja>きょうと</ja> too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want to <radical>go</radical> to <radical>Korea</radical> you'll need a good <kanji>defense</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Things in Korea haven't been on the safest side lately, so make sure you have some ways to defend yourself before you go.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need a good <kanji>defense</kanji> to go to Korea, so you fill your pockets with <reading>a</reading>corns (<ja>えい</ja>). When you get to Korea you plant them all around yourself. In no time you'll have a strong tree defense, keeping you safe.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so maybe this defense strategy will take a while, but you aren't rich and acorns are on the ground for free. Don't judge!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>spirit</radical> in a <radical>black hole</radical> and a <kanji>duplicate</kanji> comes out. The duplicate looks exactly like the original spirit that went in. How strange.
data.meaning_hint: Examine the duplicate spirit. Same ghosty body. Same ghosty glow. A perfect copy.
data.reading_mnemonic: Suddenly the <kanji>duplicate</kanji> spirit starts yelling, "Why did you throw me into that black hole?! <reading>F***</reading> (<ja>ふく</ja>) you!"
data.reading_hint: You feel pretty bad now. The duplicate spirit seems to have decided to haunt you, and it's muttering "F*** you, f*** you," over and over in your ear.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You count <radical>nine</radical> of them in the <radical>tree</radical>, each <radical>turkey</radical> holding something <kanji>random</kanji> or <kanji>miscellaneous</kanji>. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the turkeys in the tree. There are nine of them and they are all gobbling up a storm. Hear them gobble as you imagine what random, miscellaneous things they are holding.
data.reading_mnemonic: As if things couldn’t get any more <kanji>random</kanji>, <reading>Zazu</reading> (<ja>ざつ</ja>) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys <kanji>miscellaneous</kanji> trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange.
data.reading_hint: Look at Zazu asking the turkeys random questions about miscellaneous trivia. You’ve seen the Lion King, right? Zazu should be pretty easy to visualize here.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>husband</radical> and his <radical>husband</radical> find a <radical>shellfish</radical> and <kanji>agree</kanji> to share it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the husbands pulling a different side of the shellfish, it pops in two, and they each get a shell. They smile and high five.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since the husbands were able to <kanji>agree</kanji>, <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of shellfish for Christmas.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Santa-san flying over the husbands in his sleigh, raining shellfish down upon them from the sky. It warms the heart, wouldn’t you agree?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Mix <radical>spider</radical>s into <radical>alcohol</radical> to make <kanji>acid</kanji>. Spiders have a little bit in them already, but if you really want to make it potent, smash them in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that will rip through anything.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine crushing up some spiders into alcohol. Watch it turn green. It's going to eat through the beaker! Quick, do something!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're trying to find a container for this <kanji>acid</kanji> when <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble.
data.reading_hint: It’s Christmas morning. Instead of gifts, Santa-san just throws a piece of charcoal at your face. Feel the charcoal smash into your face and explode into acid, burning you. Santa-san runs away laughing. Ho ho ho!
