data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>bar</radical> can be turned into a <kanji>coin</kanji>. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of this gold bar.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine taking this gold bar and punching a coin out of it. Imagine yourself pulling a lever to press a coin out of the gold bar. Feel the lever going down as you hear the sound of a gold coin being punched out.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need this <kanji>coin</kanji> to give to a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>). The centaur is your bodyguard and he only accepts gold coins as payment.
data.reading_hint: Imagine paying this centaur with your gold coin. Hear the centaur thank you in his gruff voice before he gallops away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>eat</radical> part of a <radical>director</radical> to <kanji>domesticate</kanji> him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down.
data.meaning_hint: Which part of the director did you choose to eat in order to domesticate him? Think about eating that part of the director and imagine its taste in your mouth as you chew. Eww.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you did succeed in your attempt to <kanji>domesticate</kanji> the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry!
data.reading_hint: You’re proud that you managed to domesticate the director, but now you feel kind of bad for having injured him. Okay, you really just feel bad because he’s probably going to sue you and he definitely has a lot of money. Oh, and he’s bleeding all over your car.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>gun</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to <kanji>wound</kanji> people. When you have a gun and a lot of responsibility it's easy to get carried away and mess up, wounding the people you were supposed to be protecting. You can even wound yourself.
data.meaning_hint: Picture how easy it would be for the leader of your country to wound someone if they had a gun. Scary, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: Which leader wounded the Japanese people? The <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). The Shougun is a military leader. The Shougun even has gun in the name. And they wounded hundreds of thousands of samurai and soldiers.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun you've slowly grown to know over the last thirty-ish levels. But he's holding a gun wounding everyone around him. He's screaming and shooting and wounding everyone in sight. Even his mom, even his dog, even his farmers.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> and his <radical>older brother</radical> join a <kanji>party</kanji>. They can raid and pillage better in a <kanji>group</kanji> like this, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this big group that contains the Viking and his older brother. Hear them shouting as a group and imagine their Viking battle cry.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>party</kanji> has decided to raid <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. <ja>とうきょう</ja> doesn’t stand a chance.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this group of Vikings rampaging through <ja>とうきょう</ja>. See all the Japanese people running away and screaming as the group of Vikings comes busting in, swinging their axes and shouting loudly.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Two <radical>pool</radical>s, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an <kanji>egg</kanji>. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar.
data.meaning_hint: Separate the two pools from one another. Now the pools look like the kanji. The kanji is one white pool and one yellow pool. Neat, huh?
data.reading_mnemonic: You remember <reading>Tamago</reading>tchi (<ja>たまご</ja>), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an <kanji>egg</kanji>, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg.
data.reading_hint: Just think Tamagotchi whenever you see this kanji. Tamagotchi = tamago = egg. Easy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you see a <radical>grass</radical>y <radical>cliff</radical> with an <radical>elf</radical> under it in <radical>winter</radical>, it's because their parents are so <kanji>strict</kanji>. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand under grassy cliffs to think about what they've done.
data.meaning_hint: Only really, really strict parents would make their kids do that in the middle of winter! It's cold!
data.reading_mnemonic: One of the <kanji>strict</kanji> parents of this elf kid is... <reading>Gen</reading>ji (<ja>げん</ja>)?! Looks like he had another illegitimate kid... this time with an elf.
data.reading_hint: Oh Genji, if only you were as strict about using protection as you were on your elf child.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're at your <radical>cottage</radical> the only thing you do with your <radical>fingers</radical> is <kanji>throw away</kanji> things. The cottage is for vacation. And vacation means being as lazy as possible. But you certainly don't want to live in filth, so you have to throw away your trash at least.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sitting in your cottage. You throw away a banana peel. You throw away some used sun tan lotion. You throw away all your cares in the world.
data.reading_mnemonic: The number one thing you <kanji>throw away</kanji> while in your cottage is your <reading>su</reading>it (<ja>す</ja>). Suits just don't fit the cottage life vibe, man.
data.reading_hint: Just throw away all your suits when you want to relax. Don't worry about needing one some day, throw it awaaaay!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> sits at the entrance where people <radical>enter</radical>. You jump on and are flung inside! Because a lot of other people did the same thing, it's really <kanji>crowded</kanji> in here.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine going to your favorite store. There's a scooter on and waiting at the entrance. You can't see inside, so when you are scooted inside by the scooter, you just get thrown into a packed room. So many other people on scooters! It's too crowded!
data.reading_mnemonic: Whoever came up with the scooter entrance idea, that made your favorite store so <kanji>crowded</kanji>? Only a <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>) could come up with something like this. They don't really think about the dangers and legal implications of using a scooter to launch people into a crowded space.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a <ja>子</ja> at the head of a huge conference table. "I know how to make our stores crowded again!" they shout before showing everyone their plan drawn in Crayons.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> of a <radical>certain</radical> <radical>mountain</radical> shrouds its contents in <kanji>secrecy</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: I can't even tell you which mountain it is, nor how to get in. That's what secrecy is all about.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is so secret that the people who know about it wear magical <reading>mitts</reading> (<ja>みつ</ja>) of secrecy that make it so we can't tell anyone, no matter what.
data.reading_hint: You can imagine trying to break one of the mitts-wearing members of this group, but they can't tell you anything because of their magical mitts.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits the <radical>ground</radical>, dumping all the muddy water onto this poor <radical>beggar</radical>, making him very <kanji>dirty</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the dirty beggar gasping for air on the dirty ground. He was not expecting to get hit by a tsunami today.
data.reading_mnemonic: The beggar sits up and sees how <kanji>dirty</kanji> his <reading>o</reading>bi (<ja>お</ja>) is now and starts to cry. "Oh, my obi. My obi is all dirty, oh no!"
data.reading_hint: The beggar's obi was the only nice thing he had left and now it's all dirty. Maybe he can beg for a new one but... probably not.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>valley</radical> you feel a <radical>lack</radical> of <kanji>want</kanji>. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty.
data.meaning_hint: Think of how much you want to be in this valley. They have everything in there. You lack nothing. You want for nothing. Man, you wanna be in that valley so badly.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you get to the valley, you <kanji>want</kanji> some protein. Egg <reading>yolk</reading> (<ja>よく</ja>) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth.
data.reading_hint: This was the yolk you wanted. Feel it slosh into your mouth from the sky. Taste the yolk on your tongue before swallowing it. Mmm, egg yolk.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're in the <radical>sun</radical> playing <radical>football</radical> and you get very <kanji>warm</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Feel how warm the sun is, as you try to throw and catch the football.
data.reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>warm</kanji> like this because it's <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>). That's when the sun comes up.
data.reading_hint: Dang, you knew you should have played night football so it wouldn't get so warm. Now the dawn sun is making you uncomfortable under all those layers of football protection.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> combines with a <radical>table</radical> to make a <kanji>desk</kanji>. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk.
data.meaning_hint: Chop this tree into pieces to transform this table into a desk. Hear the sounds of construction in your head as you make this desk with your bare hands.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you finish the <kanji>desk</kanji> you turn to your friend and say, “<reading>It’s cool, eh</reading> (<ja>つくえ</ja>)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.”
data.reading_hint: Okay, so this is a pretty tricky one to make a reading mnemonic out of, if you can think of a better one, please email us. Until then, just imagine someone slurring “It’s cool, eh?” While you think about how cool this desk really is. Run your hands over the finished project as you say it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>grain</radical> is <radical>certain</radical> to keep a <kanji>secret</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine telling a piece of grain your deepest, darkest secret.
data.reading_mnemonic: If someone finds out your <kanji>secret</kanji> (not from the grain though, it will certainly keep it) then your entire face will fill with <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: This works both ways too. If someone tells you a secret, that same heat fills you up. Now whether this heat is from embarrassment or the rush of getting to be part of a secret is up to you to figure out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> a <radical>shrimp</radical> who is bad with <kanji>translation</kanji> has no <kanji>reason</kanji> to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this one shrimp who is bad at translation. He’s trying to find a reason to live, but he’s having trouble. Look at him all alone, being shunned by the other shrimp.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>translation</kanji> this shrimp failed to make was for the word “<reading>yak</reading>” (<ja>やく</ja>). The shrimp found no <kanji>reason</kanji> to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart.
data.reading_hint: The translation of the word yak was the reason this shrimp fell into despair and gave up the translation profession. Now everyone hates him. See this poor shrimp being harassed by others while they shout at him, “Yak! Yak! Yak!”

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> runs into <radical>nine</radical> <radical>tree</radical>s and produces a <kanji>dye</kanji> the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this happening in front of you. See the tsunami turn from the color of water to the color of a forest. The dye washes over you and now you’re forest green as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>dye</kanji> continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of <reading>cen</reading>taurs (<ja>せん</ja>). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy.
data.reading_hint: Hear each centaur shouting about how he hates that dye for changing his color. They look kind of funny, so you laugh at them a bit, but not too loud – they might hear you and get even more angry.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Keeping at a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>interval</radical> is the definition of <kanji>simplicity</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Just one bamboo wide, over and over. That is simplicity.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Simplicity</kanji> is what Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) always demanded. Everything he decided was based on simplicity.
data.reading_hint: Simplicity is how he took over so much of the world. If he didn't stick to simplicity, there's no way he'd have been able to do what he did.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>gate</radical> to the <radical>genius</radical> is now <kanji>closed</kanji>. The genius’ visiting hours are over, so the gate is closed. This genius has been genetically modified to know more than any human could know, and his days are spent answering questions and advising. But now, his work day is over, so his gates are closed.
data.meaning_hint: See the genius sitting behind the gate as it creaks closed in front of you. Hear the gate slam closed as you keep in mind that this genius has been modified to have increased intelligence because the genius radical in this kanji is modified as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: On the other side of the <kanji>closed</kanji> gates there is still a line of people that want the genius's advice. They decide to keep waiting until morning and gather together some <reading>hay</reading> (<ja>へい</ja>) so that sleeping outside won't be so awful.
data.reading_hint: Picture a bunch of people in front of closed gates, sleeping in piles of hay. Super itchy hay.

data.meaning_mnemonic: To <radical>say</radical> what's in a <radical>samurai</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> you start a <kanji>magazine</kanji>. You go around writing about and interviewing all the samurai so you can share what they say to everyone who wants to read!
data.meaning_hint: Why hadn't anyone thought of making a samurai magazine before?!
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, your <kanji>magazine</kanji> helps the <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) samurai find other samurai... and kill them. None of the samurai want to share their feelings with your magazine anymore, oh no!
data.reading_hint: The sheep samurai is ruining your magazine! Maybe you should start a new magazine called, "All the places the sheep samurai will be, so stay away!" to make up for all the damage you've caused.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hole</radical> leading to the <radical>private</radical> <radical>heart</radical> of your house is the <kanji>window</kanji>. Or maybe it's just the window to your soul, and not your house. Like the poetry people say.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine someone looking into a hole that shows your private heart. That's a window. A window you probably should have kept closed. Now everyone is looking in.
data.reading_mnemonic: You realize that a ton of people are looking into your <kanji>window</kanji> and seeing all your private things. This makes you <reading>mad</reading> (<ja>まど</ja>)! What right do they have to know your private thoughts and desires?!
data.reading_hint: Look out your window back at the faces. Try to express how mad you are at them with your face through the glass. Make as many mad faces that you can think of.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Not</radical> <radical>Mouth</radical> says “<kanji>no</kanji>”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine encountering this Not Mouth. Ask it a question. It answers, “No”. Imagine doing this over and over until you believe that the Not Mouth always says “no”.
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>). The Not Mouth says, “<kanji>no</kanji>”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat.
data.reading_hint: Listen as the Not Mouth continues to scream in bloodcurdling agony. Hear the flames flicker as they lick across the Not Mouth’s being. Seems as though the heat was too much for the Not Mouth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>bamboo</radical> absorbed the <radical>moon</radical>'s <radical>power</radical>, and you want that power in your body, so you surgically insert them into your body to replace your <kanji>muscle</kanji>s and <kanji>tendon</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your new bamboo muscles glowing under your skin with the moon's power. You flex and feel the power coursing through you!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your special <kanji>muscle</kanji>s and <kanji>tendon</kanji>s have become famous and the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England has requested that you appear in his court! It looks like he wants you to teach his barber surgeons how you got your new muscles.
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing before the King, explaining in detail how you cut yourself open and replaced your weak human meat with the special muscles you have now. He's staring intently at you, but more so at your shining body than your mouth as you talk.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>car</radical> is all weird because it looks like the side is going to <kanji>dangle</kanji> and <kanji>drip</kanji> off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment.
data.meaning_hint: Compare this kanji to the car kanji, <ja>車</ja>. See how the sides and top are different? Use that to remember that this car looks like it’s falling apart. See the parts dangle, and hear the drip of car fluids falling out. This car is a wreck.
data.reading_mnemonic: You see the parts as they <kanji>dangle</kanji> off the car and you get an idea. You could probably <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they <kanji>drip</kanji> off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself swinging off these dangling car parts. Hear the car creak and groan as you swing around on it, causing more fluid to drip out of the car.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone climbs onto the <radical>roof</radical> from the <radical>ground</radical> when <radical>dawn</radical> comes to <kanji>proclaim</kanji> that a new day has begun! They proclaim this at the top of their lungs!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a shadowy shape on top of the roof, proclaiming to the entire town that the new day is here! It's come! And it's also time to get up.
data.reading_mnemonic: The thing that climbs up on the roof to <kanji>proclaim</kanji> that the new day is here is a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>). Ohoho, did you think I was going to say it was a rooster? Wrong! Centaurs are taller than humans and roosters, so when they climb onto the roof with their horse legs they can see dawn starting before anyone else.
data.reading_hint: Picture that shadow on the roof, proclaiming it's a new day, but this time make sure you picture the outline of this centaur. He has a human top half and a horse bottom half. And he's yelling down at you, "HEY THE SUN IS UP IT'S DAWN GET OUT OF BED!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>horns</radical> of the creatures who drink <radical>alcohol</radical> have a <radical>measurement</radical> so large that they are <kanji>revered</kanji> the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns.
data.meaning_hint: Look at one of these revered horns. Pick it up and feel its weight. It measures very large. Your arms are getting tired from the weight.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason you are interested in these <kanji>revered</kanji> horns so much is that your <reading>son</reading> (<ja>そん</ja>) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life.
data.reading_hint: Good thing you already have one of these revered horns. Now imagine yourself grinding it up into a powder to mix into a potion for your son to drink. Hear the horn grinding away as you physically break the horn up into millions of tiny pieces.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Those that are in the <radical>middle</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical> are the ones you have the most <kanji>loyalty</kanji> towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to.
data.meaning_hint: Who do you feel the most loyalty towards? Imagine them in the middle of your heart. Feel them in your chest. Imagine them, literally inside the middle of your heart.
data.reading_mnemonic: You pictured <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s <kanji>loyalty</kanji>. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so he deserves your loyalty back.
data.reading_hint: Chewbacca is very loyal. Focus on your loyalty to Chewbacca. Picture him right in the middle of your heart and hear his Chewbacca yell. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with <ja>中</ja> which is also included in this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: To make your <radical>fingers</radical> <radical>wide</radical> you <kanji>extend</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: Extend your fingers right now and see how wide you can make them.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>extend</kanji> your fingers a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) comes running by and runs straight into them. Bu-COCK!
data.reading_hint: You poked the cock right in the eye with your extended fingers. Maybe you shouldn't be doing that in public. Innocent cocks could get hurt.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
If someone has their <radical>fingers</radical> in your <radical>syrup</radical>, it's just another way of saying they <kanji>manipulate</kanji>d you. Cause only slimy people manipulate other people, so their fingers are slimy and sticky because they're covered in your syrup from mucking up your life.

This also has another meaning: <kanji>chastity</kanji>. Just imagine if someone wanted you to keep your chastity and they called s.e.x. when someone "puts their fingers in your syrup." That would be pretty effective, right? Cause it's like, super gross.
data.meaning_hint: "Ah golly gee wiz, he sure got his fingers all up in my syrup again, dagnabbit." You know, this saying we say all the time when someone manipulates us into doing something.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>manipulate</kanji> someone else it's going to have a permanent effect on your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). Being manipulative isn't cool. And your soul will suffer forever for it.
data.reading_hint: What happens to your soul, you ask? It gets covered in syrup. That's probably where the syrup fingers phrase came from in the first place.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Writing a <radical>poem</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is the only way to get <kanji>respect</kanji> from other poets.
data.meaning_hint: Even better, write a poem about winter IN winter. Then they'll really respect you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you have their <kanji>respect</kanji> you get <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: The cake has the word RESPECT in fancy, cursive letters. Imagine eating that cake and taste the respect of your poet peers. Mm mm!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>greenhouse</radical> is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the <radical>sun</radical> into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their <kanji>livelihood</kanji> will be awesome, now!
data.meaning_hint: Just feel happy that your plants have such a nice livelihood now that the sun is out. They look so healthy and fresh!
data.reading_mnemonic: From out of nowhere, <reading>Bo</reading>bo (<ja>ぼ</ja>) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their <kanji>livelihood</kanji>. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood.
data.reading_hint: Look at Bobo do what he needs to do to maintain his own livelihood. Hear the flowers screaming as they are plucked from their homes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>cliff</radical>, a <radical>fire</radical> burns to <kanji>ashes</kanji>. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go.
data.meaning_hint: See the light from the fire as the ashes fly off the cliff. The wind carries some of the ashes over to you. Feel the ashes as they strike your face and wipe the black ash with your hands.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>ashes</kanji> inspire you to write a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy.
data.reading_hint: Ashes on my face. Falling from the cliff of fire. Gives my life meaning. Or just come up with your own haiku. Whatever works for you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You lay your <radical>sock</radical> in a little <radical>circle</radical> and <radical>boil</radical> it so it will <kanji>ripen</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You don't want to clean the sock, you want all of those nasty foot and shoe juices to ripen into the sock. It's like how the longer you let an apple ripen, the worse it smells and tastes, after a while.
data.reading_mnemonic: You take your <kanji>ripen</kanji>ed sock, and throw it at your worst enemy! But they <reading>juke</reading> (<ja>じゅく</ja>) out of the way, and throw a ripened pair of socks at you! You manage to juke too, but they're already preparing what looks like some very ripe underpants.
data.reading_hint: Ahhh! Juke for your life, or you'll end up smelling like some ripened stuff I can't even mention!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>rice paddy</radical> <radical>together</radical> with other paddies and you'll see how much they <kanji>differ</kanji>. When you're driving or taking a train through the countryside it may seem like all of those rice paddies blurring together are all the same, but they can differ quite a bit!
data.meaning_hint: Try to picture how each rice paddy differs from the next. Can you think of any differences in the ones you've seen?
data.reading_mnemonic: To see how rice paddies <kanji>differ</kanji>, you need an <reading>ea</reading>gle's (<ja>い</ja>) eye view. It can be hard to see from the ground, so soar up into the sky like an eagle and look down at the rice paddies together.
data.reading_hint: Aha! As an eagle you can easily see that all of the rice paddies have differing colors, shapes, and (if you fly low) smells. They differ a lot!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Social commentary aside, the <radical>white</radical> <radical>king</radical> is the king that wears all white. Traditionally, this is someone better than a king. The <kanji>emperor</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: See the emperor, garbed all in white. There are other kings, but the emperor's white clothing shows his status above the rest.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who is the <kanji>emperor</kanji>? It is <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. <ja>こういち</ja> the emperor stands over his subjects.
data.reading_hint:
How did <ja>こういち</ja> become emperor?! His first decree as emperor is that everybody must learn kanji now.

Note: from now on, Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> will be a recurring character for the reading mnemonic of <ja>こう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>become</radical> a <radical>plate</radical>, I will <kanji>pile</kanji> food up upon you. With such a huge pile, everyone will think you're <kanji>prosperous</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: If you have piles of something, you're prosperous. If you become a plate, that's the best thing that can happen to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're so <kanji>prosperous</kanji> you use your <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) to cut the food pile and shove the bits into your plate mouth. In fact, your entire family is using your special saber to cut and eat off of you. A normal knife wouldn't be able to get through all this food!
data.reading_hint: You know a family is seriously prosperous when they don't use forks, they use a magical saber to cut their food. Wowee wow wow.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you grind a <radical>stone</radical> down to more than just a <radical>few</radical> pieces, it will become <kanji>sand</kanji>. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand.
data.meaning_hint: Feel these few grains of sand between your fingertips. Imagine the stones that they originally came from. Nature is crazy.
data.reading_mnemonic: What’s in your hand? A few grains of <reading>sa</reading>nd (<ja>さ</ja>)! <kanji>Sand</kanji>, sand, sand!
data.reading_hint: Just remember that stones become sand and if you remember that this kanji means sand you’ll remember how to pronounce it as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits the <radical>greenhouse</radical>, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a <kanji>desert</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The greenhouse was your only hope in turning the desert into a green forest. Now it's all washed away by salt water, meaning nothing will grow anyways. Feel disappointed about this.
data.reading_mnemonic: See the sun come up over the <kanji>desert</kanji>, then go <reading>back</reading> (<ja>ばく</ja>) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so <kanji>vague</kanji> in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out!
data.reading_hint: Up, back down, back up, back down. Move your head up and down to keep up with the sun’s movements. Will it ever rise like normal?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Bring <radical>rice</radical> under a <radical>canopy</radical>, crush it with your <radical>brush</radical>, and sweep the white powder in your <radical>mouth</radical>... it's <kanji>sugar</kanji> now! You make sugar by carefully crushing rice to a powder, until it's small enough to brush into your mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Taste the sugar in your mouth and feel the breeze waft under the canopy. You're surrounded by rice, but what's in your mouth is definitely sugar now.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned how to make <kanji>sugar</kanji> in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. You found a special <ja>とうきょう</ja> sugar sensei and they introduced you to all of the secret methods you know now.
data.reading_hint: As you eat the sugar, you picture <ja>とうきょう</ja>. The place where you fell in love with these sugar-making techniques.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> you have <radical>inside</radical> is your whole <kanji>supply</kanji>. When you're outside sewing and you run out, you just go inside, look through your supply, and pick a new one.
data.meaning_hint: Go inside your house or shed, it doesn't matter where, and look happily at your thread supply. You have thread in all sizes, shapes, and especially colors.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have this <kanji>supply</kanji> because <reading>No</reading>stradamus (<ja>のう</ja>) had a prediction, saying you would. And that if you didn't keep a good supply of thread inside, you'd run out.
data.reading_hint: Nostradamus says you should have a large supply of everything you use regularly. Thread, water, canned foods. You can't see the future, but he can, and if he's telling you to stock up on your inside supplies I think you should listen.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>moon</radical> and a <radical>city</radical> inside your <kanji>lung</kanji>. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a moon and a city inside your lung. Feel their presence as you breathe in and breathe out. Also, <ja>月</ja> often refers to internal organs as well, so remember that when you see this kanji.
data.reading_mnemonic: Having a moon and city inside your <kanji>lung</kanji> inspires you to write a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here.
data.reading_hint:
The city and moon
Inside my lung, forgotten.
Where is the answer?

Or just think of your own haiku. Be creative!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <radical>someone</radical> is holding <radical>flowers</radical>, they're probably an <kanji>author</kanji>. Authors really love flowers, because they help them think of flowery language they can use to sound smart in their books.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a time when a book you were reading used flowery language and you couldn't understand. Imagine the annoyance with the author for using words that are hard to understand
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the <kanji>author</kanji> is allergic to flowers. They are only allergic to touching them though, so the author is holding the flowers with a pair of <reading>cho</reading>psticks (<ja>ちょ</ja>), really close to their face. Using the chopsticks, they can still use the flowers to think of fancy, author-ly words without touching them.
data.reading_hint: Picture the author trying to use chopsticks to move around a little flower. It looks like they're having a hard time, but people will do anything to be a great author, I suppose.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take the <radical>flowers</radical> off some <radical>coral</radical> and <radical>boil</radical> them, <kanji>steam</kanji> comes out.
data.meaning_hint: Steam comes out of the coral flowers because they hold a lot of water. They're flowers, but they're coral flowers, so they came from the ocean. Of course there's water in them, and if you boil that water steam will come out.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the <kanji>steam</kanji> coming off the coral flowers, someone appears behind you. It is <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>), the big farmhand. "Are you steaming coral?" he asks. "Smelled it a mile away. I love crunching me some coral."
data.reading_hint: It's weird that Jourm is so sensitive to the smell of steaming coral. He's lived as a farmhand nowhere near the sea all his life... at least that's what he told you. And now he's in your house breathing in the steam really deeply with his nose practically in the pot.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>storehouse</radical> radical and the <kanji>storehouse</kanji> kanji meanings are the same. If you know the radical, you know the kanji!
data.meaning_hint: Your brain is like a storehouse, you know? Hopefully that's where you kept your storehouse knowledge.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>storehouse</kanji>. Inside is where you keep all your <reading>zo</reading>mbies (<ja>ぞう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Be really proud of your storehouse. You've collected a lot of zombies and put them in there, where they'll keep fresh a long time!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you see <radical>icicle</radical>s hanging off of a <radical>samurai</radical>'s <radical>clothes</radical>, don't worry, those are just part of his winter <kanji>attire</kanji>. Samurai have to travel and fight in all sorts of conditions, so it only makes sense that they have attire for every season.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a samurai in his winter attire. His helmet is white and fuzzy and he has decorative icicles hanging down off of his armor.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Attire</kanji> like this is important because it reflects your <reading>soul</reading> (<ja>そう</ja>). The samurai is wearing clothing with icicles because that's how his heart feels too: frozen over because he has to fight in this horrible winter weather.
data.reading_hint: Picture the kind of attire you'd wear as a samurai to reflect your soul. Mine would be bright pink and covered in horses and bananas and daisies to show that I have a happy, kind soul and that I don't want to be killed by anyone else.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>village</radical>, so you <radical>kick</radical> it over on its <kanji>backside</kanji> to see what's on its <kanji>underside</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You've been curious about what's on the lid (and your village's) backside for years, and you finally can't take it anymore so you kick the lid as hard as you can!
data.reading_mnemonic: It turns out your village's own <kanji>backside</kanji> is covered in <reading>ura</reading>nium (<ja>うら</ja>). Eureka! You're all gonna be rich!
data.reading_hint: Wait, isn't uranium bad for people? This explains why all of the villagers backsides are covered in weird glowing, green lumps.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>someone</radical> with <kanji>various</kanji> talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend.
data.meaning_hint: You are someone who can say things in various languages. Speak some of these various languages now. You are someone who is good at saying things. Nice job.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re so good at speaking <kanji>various</kanji> languages that you decide to put on a <reading>sho</reading>w (<ja>しょ</ja>). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself at this show. The spotlight is on and all eyes are watching. You feel kind of nervous, but you speak the various languages with ease.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> who is <radical>king</radical> of every <radical>shellfish</radical> sets the <kanji>rent</kanji> for everyone. If you rent a home in King Shellfish's kingdom, the rent will be set by the great shellfish leader himself.
data.meaning_hint: King Shellfish loves when people rent from him. Imagine him rolling in all of the rent money (shellfish) he collected from all the people who rent from him. Hear his shell clattering as he frolics on all the dead shells from the shellfish.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't have enough shellfish to pay your <kanji>rent</kanji>, King Shellfish will punch you in the <reading>chin</reading> (<ja>ちん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Feel your entire body shaking, but especially your chin, as you tell him you're two shellfish short on rent this month. The last thing you see is his big fist coming right for your chin.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> accidentally firing a <radical>catapult</radical> is an unforgivable <kanji>mistake</kanji>. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine shooting the catapult on your own people by mistake. Hear the catapult whoosh as your heart drops into your stomach. Oh, what a terrible mistake you’ve just made.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>mistake</kanji> alerts <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (<ja>ご</ja>), who thinks it's town destroying time. He barrels over the hills, sees where you mistakenly catapulted your own people, and proceeds to stomp on the rest of it for you.
data.reading_hint: Picture Godzilla jumping happily on the castle and surrounding town you hit by mistake. This is probably the worst mistake you've ever made.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>moon</radical> <radical>storehouse</radical> is another storehouse you own. Remember how your regular storehouse holds zombies (from the kanji <ja>蔵</ja>?). Your moon storehouse is on the moon, and it is filled with <kanji>internal organs</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Your moon storehouse has internal organs because 1) you have to keep them far away from the zombies or they'll go berserk, and 2) you think it's funny to see them bounce around in low gravity. Boing, boing, boing, haha look at that internal organ.
data.reading_mnemonic: Where did you get all these <kanji>internal organ</kanji>s from? You actually harvested them from the <reading>zo</reading>mbies (<ja>ぞう</ja>) from your other storehouse.
data.reading_hint: Basically, you store zombies in your regular storehouse, harvest their organs, then launch them into space where they are put into a storehouse on the moon where the zombies will never be able to find them again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>middle</radical> of the <radical>ground</radical> is a <radical>shellfish</radical> that is very <kanji>valuable</kanji>. Inside of this valuable shellfish is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this valuable shellfish. What could be inside? Pick it up and shake it about, trying to guess what valuable thing is enclosed.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to get the <kanji>valuable</kanji> thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). Search for the key!
data.reading_hint: You find a bunch of keys, so you try to jam them all into the shellfish one by one, hoping one of them is the right key to get the valuable, hidden treasure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside the <radical>building</radical> is the <radical>winter</radical> <radical>Cow</radical>. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to <kanji>descend</kanji> to reach it.
data.meaning_hint: Focus on descending the stairs. There are many signs that say "To Winter Cow: descend" with an arrow pointing down. "I guess I'll have to descend," you say.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>descend</kanji> to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>'s face.
data.reading_hint: "Hello, thank you for descending all the way down here to see me," says the Winter Cow with <ja>こういち</ja>'s face. "You thought you could use the Winter Cow to stop me, but as you can see, I got here first."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Into a <radical>well</radical>, a <radical>drop</radical> of rice falls from your <kanji>rice bowl</kanji>. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down.
data.meaning_hint: You lost a drop of rice from your rice bowl. Feel sorrow for the lost rice as you watch it fall down the well and hear it splat into the water below.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just then, the <reading>don</reading> (<ja>どん</ja>) of your local mafia shows up, steals your <kanji>rice bowl</kanji>, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well.
data.reading_hint: Hear the don shout, “See ya, sucker!” as he pushes you into the well. You’ve just lost a drop of rice, now your rice bowl, and now you’re all wet in a well. Worst day ever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put <radical>dirt</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> you're going to <kanji>throw up</kanji>. That's just a fact.
data.meaning_hint: That's pretty much what throwing up feels like too, right? Like a bunch of dirt coming out of your mouth. Barf.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>throw up</kanji> it sounds like you're shouting, "<reading>HA</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!" Then all the dirt-puke comes out in a wave. It's less of a laugh ha and more of an oh no I'm throwing up ha.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the sound you made the last time you threw up. It sounded like you were saying HA from the bottom of your tummy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> sitting on that <radical>stool</radical> is actually a <kanji>dude</kanji>. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks!
data.meaning_hint: Dude, I can't believe you called that dude a woman. What's wrong with you?!
data.reading_mnemonic: You only found out this <kanji>dude</kanji> wasn't a woman when a <reading>do</reading>g <ja>ど</ja> ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dogs face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!"
data.reading_hint: Look at the poor dog. He's not a dude and now he doesn't think he's a good boy, all because of this other dude. Was he sitting on the stool this whole time, waiting to make this dog feel bad? I guess you'll never know...

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>samurai</radical> has a <radical>jackhammer</radical>, a <radical>brush</radical>, and some <radical>water</radical>. All these things tell you that this samurai is actually a <kanji>slave</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Traditionally, samurai don't carry things like jackhammers, brushes, or water. The samurai is carrying these things for someone else, meaning this samurai is somebody's slave.
data.reading_mnemonic: You don't like seeing a <kanji>slave</kanji>. As you walk by, you hand him a <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun so he can free himself.
data.reading_hint: The samurai slave can use the ray gun to shoot his keeper and get away. Imagine watching him holding up his master and getting away. A ray gun is a truly powerful weapon in the hands of a slave.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you see some <radical>dry</radical> <radical>flowers</radical>, pull them up and you'll find a <kanji>potato</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Potatoes grow when flowers dry out. All the nutrients are going to the potato under the ground, so the flowers up top get sucked dry.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Potato</kanji>es are totally <reading>emo</reading> (<ja>いも</ja>) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.
data.reading_hint: Picture an emo potato sitting alone in a dark room, staring at a potato. "You and I are the same."

data.meaning_mnemonic: A magic <radical>thread</radical> fell from the <radical>roof</radical> onto the <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>hundred</radical> people, causing him to <kanji>shrink</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Picture one hundred people under the same roof watching in horror as their leader suddenly shrinks to nothingness before them.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the leader <kanji>shrink</kanji>s, the hundred people start screaming and running around the entire place. As a result, everything is <reading>shook</reading> (<ja>しゅく</ja>) up. Especially the poor, shrunken leader, who gets knocked around the most.
data.reading_hint: The leader gets shook so badly, he can't even call out to his people. They're going to trample his tiny, shrinking body!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Make your <radical>barracks</radical> out of <radical>thread</radical> so it will be <kanji>pure</kanji>. If you build it out of clay or bricks or wood, it will inevitably have some dirt in it. Build it out of thread to keep it pure of... well, impurities.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a barracks pure white, like pure snow, made of pure thread.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>pure</kanji> thread barracks can only be used in <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>), unfortunately. Any other time of year there will be snow and rain and mud and that will get tracked into the pure barracks and ruin them. But June is the cleanest, most pure month, so you can use it then.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so maybe building a pure barracks that you can only use in June was a bad idea, but it's there now and I don't want you getting it dirty, so just use it when I say so, okay?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>thread</radical> that wants to <radical>loiter</radical> from some <radical>horns</radical> and you would be <radical>correct</radical> to assume that it would hang <kanji>vertical</kanji>. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this vertical thread as it hangs from the horns. Take hold of it and pull on the vertical thread. Feel it in your hand.
data.reading_mnemonic: For some reason, Channing <reading>Tat</reading>um (<ja>たて</ja>) is strangely attracted to <kanji>vertical</kanji> pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat.
data.reading_hint: Look at Channing Tatum playing with this thread. He’s like a cat playing with a piece of yarn. Look at Mr. Tatum bouncing around batting at the thread like some silly feline.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s some <radical>rice</radical> in the shape of a <radical>nine</radical> on a <radical>cross</radical> and this is <kanji>stylish</kanji>. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it’s stylish to carry it around and be seen with it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine hefting this cross with the rice in the shape of a nine on it. You don’t feel stylish, but society tells you that you are. You’re stylish.
data.reading_mnemonic: It’s also <kanji>stylish</kanji> to <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>) the cross around while you wait for things. You’re waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off!
data.reading_hint: See the rice fly through the air from you swinging the cross. Hear it as it clatters to the ground. This cross just isn’t as stylish anymore now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ear</radical> and the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>king</radical> are <kanji>holy</kanji>. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine.
data.meaning_hint: See the holy ear and mouth of this king. They glisten and glitter and people write hymnals about their holy prowess. Imagine a song playing as you witness their holy majesty.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>holy</kanji> king has heard of you and your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) that glows with pure, blue light. Specifically, the holy king wants to use it on his food!
data.reading_hint: The holy king heard you turned into a prosperous plate and used the saber to cut your food and now he wants to try it too. As he holds your saber, a holy circle forms around it, making it sparkle and shimmer! Your saber is holy now too!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Seeing a <radical>stone</radical> and some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> next to a piece of <radical>poop</radical> and another piece of <radical>poop</radical>, you try and pick each of them up with a <kanji>magnet</kanji>. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your <kanji>magnet</kanji>. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!
data.reading_hint: Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In this <radical>construction</radical> project, they will be using <radical>thread</radical> to hold everything together. The color of the thread is a <kanji>deep red</kanji>, and it gives everything a <kanji>crimson</kanji> look.
data.meaning_hint: Because thread isn't that strong, you have to use A LOT (to hold things like beams in place). So, the deep red / crimson thread actually stands out a lot in this construction project.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're done, and the whole building is a <kanji>deep red</kanji> <kanji>crimson</kanji> color (it takes a lot of thread to hold a whole building in place). It's time to show the client, Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, the finished product.
data.reading_hint:
<ja>こういち</ja> walks up with a big smile on his face. "I love the color crimson!" he exclaims. "It's the same deep red color as my enemies."

Hint: When you see <ja>工</ja> in a kanji it will often take the <ja>こう</ja> reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to take a <radical>body</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> before you can <kanji>shoot</kanji>. Whether it's for a photo shoot, you're gonna shoot them with a gun, or if you're about to shoot them full of radiation for X-rays, you need the right measurements of that body first.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine someone measuring your body before they shoot you. You hope it's the good kind of shoot and that you're not going to die.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shoot</kanji> is being done by a <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>). Not only is he doing the body measurements for the shoot, but he's also going to be shooting you with a shot so you don't get the flu.
data.reading_hint: Shamans are just a different kind of doctor. And this shot is going to save you from getting the flu, which could kill you. Make sure you always go to the local shaman and schedule a shooting.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Hang a <radical>towel</radical> in a <radical>greenhouse</radical> and it turns into a <kanji>curtain</kanji>. Greenhouses are made of windows, it's all glass, there are no walls. So when you put a towel in there it turns into a curtain. It has no choice but to cover a window, after all.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine hanging towels over all the windows in the greenhouse. They're really fuzzy, thick curtains now.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're hanging these towel <kanji>curtain</kanji>s because you need a quiet place to eat a Big <reading>Mac</reading> (<ja>まく</ja>). But you're a little ashamed. Big macs aren't really good for you, but this stupid greenhouse has too many windows and everyone can see you stuff your face. So that's where the towel curtains come in.
data.reading_hint: Imagine hiding in a greenhouse blocked off with towel curtains, stuffing your face with big macs. No one can shame you in here. You can eat as many as you want. And hey, you can use the curtains as napkins too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> and <radical>dry</radical> them. Then <radical>dry</radical> them again. This is what you do when you are in  <kanji>worship</kanji>. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your sweaty, sweaty fingers. Dry them off before you enter a place of worship! No god wants to deal with your weird, damp hands.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you're dry and in wherever your <kanji>worship</kanji> is, you begin with a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway.
data.reading_hint:
Imagine being in your place of worship. Close your eyes and say a haiku:

So I won't offend
Lord Crabigator-sama
I dry my hands now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want some <radical>flowers</radical> to put on the <radical>canopy</radical> above your <radical>helicopter</radical> to keep the <radical>bird</radical>s away, so you ask people what they would <kanji>recommend</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You've bought flowers before, but you really don't know which ones would work best to stop birds from landing on the canopy and pooping on your helicopter.
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask for a <kanji>recommend</kanji>ation from the <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>) that owns the local flower shop. Now he's walking around your helicopter canopy and staring at the birds, nodding.
data.reading_hint: I hope the centaur recommends a cheap flower... but with your luck flowers that keep birds away will cost a fortune.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>turkey</radical> is pointing its <radical>fingers</radical> at you, you can <kanji>infer</kanji> that it wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now he’s going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take their fingers and wrap them around your neck.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a turkey is pointing at you with its fingers. The gears in your brain begin to slowly turn. From looking at the turkey to its fingers and back to the turkey, you can infer that something bad is probably about to happen to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You were able to <kanji>infer</kanji> the turkey's plan, so now it's your turn. You look around and see the only way out... is to <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>) to safety! How did I infer that, dear Watson? Why, isn't it obvious! There are vines here. Turkeys can't fly. So I shall swing my way to freedom!
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself as Sherlock Holmes, you inferred your way to freedom, swinging away on a conveniently-placed vine.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You stand on the <radical>forehead</radical> of your <radical>car</radical>, take your <radical>fingers</radical> and <kanji>brandish</kanji> them in the air! You wave them around for everyone to see.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing on top of your car, brandishing your fingers in the air, all of the cars stuck behind yours honking angrily.
data.reading_mnemonic: What are you <kanji>brandish</kanji>ing in your fingers? Your car's <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>)! You want every driver and every car to know that you aren't going to be driving ever again!
data.reading_hint: You brandish the key in the air and then throw it into the woods. No more cars for you! Everyone should follow your example! Brandish your car keys into the air and throw them away!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming, so you put your <radical>fins</radical> on, open your <radical>mouth</radical> wide, and try to <kanji>run alongside</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: Your mouth is open so you can scream, because this is probably a bad idea.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're able to <kanji>run alongside</kanji> the tsunami for about ten seconds before everything <reading>en</reading>ds (<ja>えん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Okay, so maybe trying to run alongside a tsunami with just some fins and a mouth full of screams and terror wasn't the best idea. But at least everything ended while you did... uh... something unique?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>original</radical> <radical>tsunami</radical> was the <kanji>origin</kanji> of Japan. A big tsunami came and uncovered the islands of Japan. It's the origin of all life, as far as Japanese people are concerned.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the original tsunami used in the origin story of Japan. It was huge. Bigger than anything you've ever seen. And without it you wouldn't have your precious anime and mangos.
data.reading_mnemonic: This tsunami was also the <kanji>origin</kanji> of <reading>Gen</reading>ji (<ja>げん</ja>), from "The Tale of Genji." Just think, without this origin, Japan wouldn't exist and neither would the first Japanese heartthrob, Genji!
data.reading_hint: The origin of Genji was the origin of all Japan: a big ol' tsunami.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Boot</radical>s give you the <radical>power</radical> to <kanji>work</kanji>! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting your boots on and suddenly being filled with the power and energy to work hard and efficiently.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need boots to give you the power to <kanji>work</kanji> for the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself in work boots. Now picture the King in work boots. Yours are worn and beaten up and his are clean and look brand new. But at least you both have them, which means you both work at least a little!

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>arrow</radical> is what this <radical>turkey</radical> <radical>lack</radical>s. For a turkey, that is a <kanji>delight</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: A turkey that lacks an arrow is a delighted turkey.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Delight</kanji> is what Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) felt when he saw his turkey friend, sans an arrow.
data.reading_hint: He loves his turkey friend, and every time he sees it he squeals with delight.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>child</radical> will ask if they want <radical>two</radical> <radical>water</radical>s because they need a grown-up's <kanji>consent</kanji>. Children aren't allowed to have whatever they want, they need to make sure it's okay and get consent first.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the child finishing their first water. They look at a big stack of bottled waters, but they know better than to just take two more, they need consent first. "Excuse me, sir, could I please have two more waters?" the child asks.
data.reading_mnemonic: "Of course my child, you have my <kanji>consent</kanji>," comes the voice of the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). The Shougun is very pleased by this child, because he expects everyone to ask for consent around him.
data.reading_hint: You need to make sure to get express consent from the Shougun before you do most things. Especially if it's something like taking more than you've been given.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Raise your <radical>fingers</radical> to another <radical>member</radical> and you'll receive a <kanji>loss</kanji> in return. You should never hurt a member of your team, group, or society. It's just wrong. And you'll incur a loss as punishment for your bad deeds.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine raising your fingers to slap, hurt, or point angrily at a member of your own team. How dare you! I hope you're ready for some deep, personal loss.
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately for you, payment is in the form of the <kanji>loss</kanji> of your <reading>son</reading> (<ja>そん</ja>). The loss of any family member is horrible, but this was your son. He was your favorite child. You loved him. But that's the loss you must bear for raising your fingers to a team member.
data.reading_hint: Picture your son. Your future son, maybe even your animal son, if you don't want to have real kids. Now imagine the loss of that son. Nooooo!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> <radical>branch</radical> is exactly what it sounds like: the <kanji>branch</kanji> of a tree.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a tree branch in your hands. Feel it. Smell it. It smells and feels like a tree.
data.reading_mnemonic: Take this <kanji>branch</kanji> and give it to a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). Sheep are like dogs, they like to play fetch with tree branches. And now you're playing fetch with this sheep and this branch.
data.reading_hint: Imagine playing fetch with a tree branch and a sheep. Man's second best friend.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>claw</radical> radical and the <kanji>claw</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing!
data.reading_mnemonic: You’ve got not one <reading>tumor</reading> (<ja>つま</ja>), but <reading>too ma</reading>ny (<ja>つめ</ja>) tumors and you need to claw them out with your sharp <kanji>claw</kanji>. One tumor is one tumor too many. Cut them out with your claw!
data.reading_hint: Imagine you have too many tumors. Feel the claw digging into your flesh and removing the tumors. It really hurts, but it is necessary.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>beans</radical> radical and the <kanji>beans</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
data.meaning_hint: *toots*
data.reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>beans</kanji> are from <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Everybody knows <ja>とうきょう</ja> has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans!
data.reading_hint: Imagine eating these beans from <ja>とうきょう</ja>. They’re the best beans you’ve ever had. Even if you don’t like beans, you love <ja>とうきょう</ja> beans. Mmm… beans, beans, <ja>とうきょう</ja> beans.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>slice</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> is called a <kanji>carve</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You carve meat, you carve wood, all with a slicing motion with a knife.
data.reading_mnemonic: You work up a sweat trying to <kanji>carve</kanji> meat and wood all day, so you grab yourself a nice <reading>Coke</reading> (<ja>こく</ja>). You like Coke, and it goes well with meat and sawdust.
data.reading_hint: Imagine washing down all your hard carving work with an ice cold Coke.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Attach</radical> <radical>meat</radical> to your <radical>canopy</radical> and it will <kanji>rot</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the smell of rotten meat hanging from your canopy. Now no one wants to come near here.
data.reading_mnemonic: You let meat <kanji>rot</kanji>. You're a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>). That's really all I can say at this point.
data.reading_hint: What, did you think attaching this meat to the canopy would make it turn into jerky or something? Fool...

data.meaning_mnemonic: Next to the <radical>scooter</radical>, there's a <radical>flag</radical> warning you that there are <radical>sheep</radical> around here, so you should go <kanji>slow</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's also a warning to the sheep that if they want to ride scooters they should also slow down, because as we all know, sheep are speed demons.
data.reading_mnemonic: You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to <kanji>slow</kanji> down so you have to get creative. You place <reading>chee</reading>se (<ja>ち</ja>) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite.
data.reading_hint: Picture all of the sheep finally going slowly because there is yummy cheese all over the road.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>circumference</radical> around someone's <radical>hair</radical>, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has <kanji>carve</kanji>d the hair off someone's head!
data.meaning_hint: Their hair has literally been carved out of their head, and you discovered it. Of course, the nastiness, the smell, and the feel should be applied to your imagination to make the mnemonic stronger.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have <kanji>carve</kanji>d out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this.
data.reading_hint: You can also imagine Mrs. Chou doing the act of carving someone's hair out, but that may just be too much.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> will pick up a bunch of <radical>shellfish</radical> and dump them on your shore, so you take a <radical>knife</radical> and <kanji>measure</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: You can't eat shellfish that are too small, so you place your knife along them to measure them. If they're big enough, you stick the knife in and eat them raw.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of the shellfish you <kanji>measure</kanji> that are too small go into your <reading>sock</reading> (<ja>そく</ja>). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean.
data.reading_hint: If you measure one of these shellfish and it's too small, stuff it right into your sock. Then once the sock measures about 12 shellfish long, toss it back to sea!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you scrape a sharp <radical>stone</radical> against your <radical>skin</radical>, it will <kanji>tear</kanji>. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this sharp stone. Feel its weight in your hand. Now drag the sharp stone against your skin. Feel your skin as it begins to tear. The pain is agonizing.
data.reading_mnemonic: The moment your skin <kanji>tear</kanji>s you can't help but yelp "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark.
data.reading_hint: You make this noise when you tear other things with the sharp stone too, but now it's more of a HA! TAKE THAT! Feel the same pain I feel!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>cottage</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical cottage, you know the kanji cottage.
data.reading_mnemonic: You got this <kanji>cottage</kanji> from a <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage.
data.reading_hint: I guess shamans are moving out a lot around here. Why don't you go look for a cottage you can buy from a shaman! I bet you'll get a pretty good, totally not cursed, deal!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Try to <radical>say</radical> something to a <radical>lifeguard</radical> and you'll just end up getting a <kanji>lecture</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: A lifeguard's favorite part of the job is telling people what to do, where to swim, when to get out of the water, and they love saying it in a bunch of words.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>lecture</kanji> loving lifeguard is none other than <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette?
data.reading_hint:
Close your eyes and picture <ja>こういち</ja> lecturing you. Ugh, it's the worst!

Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be <ja>こう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical>, once stopped by a <radical>belt</radical>, will begin to <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate.
data.meaning_hint: Watch this belt as it stagnated the tsunami. See the belt glow as its enchantment activates, immediately stagnating the tsunami water.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you watch the tsunami <kanji>stagnate</kanji>, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work.
data.reading_hint: Look in the mirror at you in your tie. Put the finishing touches on your outfit and imagine going out into the world with your tie on, no longer afraid of any tsunamis. They’re all stagnant now thanks to that magical belt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You create a <radical>thread</radical> with someone by <radical>call</radical>ing out to them to <kanji>introduce</kanji> yourself.
data.meaning_hint: You literally call out, and when they turn around, tie a thread to them, so you'll never forget that you introduced yourselves to each other.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>introduce</kanji> yourself to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!"
data.reading_hint: Finally the Shougun sighs and turns toward you. You call out your name and get the thread around him. Uh oh. He doesn't look happy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>jammed in</radical> radical and the <kanji>jammed in</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: Look down! You're <kanji>jammed in</kanji>to something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself jammed into a kayak. Your pants are bunching and sticking out the sides and top. You really don't fit in here.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>oneself</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>oneself</kanji> as well.
data.meaning_hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Oneself</kanji>. Who only thinks of oneself? Every <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>) in the world.
data.reading_hint: Kids can only think of oneself. Until a certain age, that's literally all they can care about.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you’re on the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> with a <radical>snake</radical>, you’re <kanji>unlucky</kanji>. You’re hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can’t pull yourself back up when you notice a snake approaching your fingers. The snake looks like it’s gonna bite you. How unlucky.
data.meaning_hint: What will you do? You can either let go and fall off the cliff, or get bit by the snake if you keep holding on. Man, you’re unlucky.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even though you’re so <kanji>unlucky</kanji>, you decide to take your chances and let go of the cliff. Amazingly, a <reading>yak</reading> (<ja>やく</ja>) runs below you and catches you as you fall. Saved by the yak!
data.reading_hint: What a nice yak this is. Perhaps your luck has turned around. Perhaps you aren’t as unlucky as you thought. Your butt sure does hurt from that fall though…

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>turtle</radical> radical and the <kanji>turtle</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Nice!
data.reading_mnemonic: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this <kanji>turtle</kanji> doing a <reading>Kame</reading>hameha (<ja>かめ</ja>). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom!
data.reading_hint: See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>shuriken</radical> have <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.
data.meaning_hint: Pick up the shuriken and throw it into the ground. Hear it whizz through the air and then plunk into the ground. This act of aggression causes their mutual respect to waver.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect is out of balance. This summons <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (<ja>ご</ja>) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground.
data.reading_hint: You give Godzilla a thumbs up, you see what he's trying to do. He looks down at you and nods. Now you have a mutual respect for one another too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Tie a <radical>squid</radical> to a <radical>knife</radical> and you get a <kanji>sword</kanji>! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine creating your own sword out of a knife and a squid.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned how to make <kanji>sword</kanji>s this way from <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword!
data.reading_hint: Picture Ken swinging his squid sword at you. *Squish* it squirts ink on your shoulder. But it doesn't really hurt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>spring</radical>, your <radical>measurement</radical>s will reveal your <kanji>lifespan</kanji>. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight.
data.meaning_hint: On the first day of spring, all the girls and boys line up to measure their lifespans.
data.reading_mnemonic: If your <kanji>lifespan</kanji> measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small <reading>ju</reading>ice (<ja>じゅ</ja>) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all!
data.reading_hint: Look at Salmon, over here. She drank a thousand small juice boxes last year and now her measurement says she's gonna live another hundred years!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around my <radical>skin</radical>, <kanji>he</kanji> will get angry at you. He is my boyfriend and he is very protective of me. So don’t loiter around my skin for too long or he will beat you up.
data.meaning_hint: He is a jealous guy. He will beat you down if you loiter around my skin for too long. Imagine he is beating you up right now. He is screaming at you as he does so.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>He</kanji> says the only way he will stop beating you up is if you give him some <reading>curry</reading> (<ja>かれ</ja>). You give him some curry.
data.reading_hint: He accepts the curry you give him. Smell the curry smell as he eats it right in front of you. He is eating very loudly.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ear</radical> listens to your <radical>heart</radical> and feels <kanji>shame</kanji>. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.
