data.meaning_hint: Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
data.reading_mnemonic: You must cleanse your spirit of this <kanji>shame</kanji>. You decide to complete <reading>Haj</reading> (<ja>はじ</ja>). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “<reading>HA</reading>HAHAHAHAHA!! (<ja>は</ja>) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.
data.reading_hint: You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
There’s a <radical>tree</radical> in your <radical>hair</radical>, I think it’s a <kanji>cedar</kanji>. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?

(Certain types of cedar trees have bark that comes off in fine threads, making them very hairy trees. So this kanji makes perfect sense!)
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a cedar tree in your hair. It’s just a little tree, a sapling, but it’s pretty strange and awkward. It does smell nice though. Mmm… cedar.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the <kanji>cedar</kanji> is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A <reading>Sue gui</reading>tar (<ja>すぎ</ja>), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it.
data.reading_hint: Give Sue her Sue guitar. Hear Sue squeal with glee as she receives her Sue guitar.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> carries a <radical>cross</radical> into your <kanji>soup</kanji>. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a bowl of soup, but now there is a cross and some tsunami water in it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You pull the cross out of your <kanji>soup</kanji> and see that the cross' <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup!
data.reading_hint: You're curious so you take a sip of this jewel soup and... it's delicious! You should make more and sell it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is wearing a <radical>mask</radical> so people won't realize you're the one being so <kanji>boisterous</kanji>. You want to be loud and rowdy, but you don't want anyone to know it's you. If you cover your mouth with this mask, people won't know you're the one being so boisterous.
data.meaning_hint: Go put a mask on right now, cover everything around your mouth so it's hard to tell who you are. Now go outside and be as boisterous as possible!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're being anonymously <kanji>boisterous</kanji> outside when suddenly someone shoves <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>) in your mouth! "I don't know who you are, but you're much too boisterous! Wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell.
data.reading_hint: Using your boisterous mouth, taste the disgusting soapy soap. The soap bubbles are already filling your mouth and stinging your tongue. This is the punishment for boisterous hooligans.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fire</radical>, <radical>fire</radical>, <kanji>flame</kanji>! There’s flames everywhere!
data.meaning_hint: Feel the fire all around you, the flames licking at your body. It’s really hot!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>flame</kanji>s gets bigger, surround you, and then everything <reading>en</reading>ds (<ja>えん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Sorry, but standing in a blaze isn't the best idea. Flames are pretty efficient at ending the lives of the things in it. Maybe you should do this kanji lesson over and try not to stand in the flames next time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sake</radical> radical and the <kanji>sake</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Sweet.
data.meaning_hint: For goodness sake! Please remember this isn't "sake" as in <ja>お酒</ja>! It's the English "sake," that rhymes with "bake," "cake," and "steak." Oops.. now I'm hungry.
data.reading_mnemonic: For the <kanji>sake</kanji> of convenience, companies will use <reading>ea</reading>gles (<ja>い</ja>) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery.
data.reading_hint: See this eagle as it comes to deliver your order just for your sake. Scree! Hear its wings flap and your package plop down on your porch as it's delivered.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>ability</radical> to <radical>boil</radical> is one of the main abilities of a <kanji>bear</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: I bet you didn't know this, but a bear can boil whenever it wants. Imagine a bear heating itself up and boiling, its fur and skin bubbling and letting off steam.
data.reading_mnemonic:
A <kanji>bear</kanji> boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magma <reading>cum</reading> (<ja>くま</ja>) laude.

Get it? A little hot bear humor for you.
data.reading_hint: You can also imagine a bear graduating in the top 5-10% of its class. Or, just imagine a bear saying "Cuma here!" to you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have an <radical>animal</radical> and you <radical>say</radical> it’s a <radical>dog</radical> to prevent it from going to <kanji>prison</kanji>. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine any animal that’s not a dog. Now imagine dressing it up like a dog so it doesn’t have to go to prison. Practice throwing your voice by saying “woof woof” aloud to help convince people that your animal is actually a dog.
data.reading_mnemonic: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named <reading>Goku</reading> (<ja>ごく</ja>). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to <kanji>prison</kanji>, so you say that he’s a dog.
data.reading_hint: Poor little Goku doesn’t want to go to prison either so Goku does his best to act like a dog even though he isn’t. How adorable.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have an <radical>alcohol</radical> <radical>nine</radical> times stronger than any other drink in a bottle shaped like a <radical>cross</radical> and you drink it all and become <kanji>drunk</kanji>. You’re like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before.
data.meaning_hint: Feel how drunk you are as you look at the cross shaped bottle that once held the alcohol. See the cross start to blur in front of you from how drunk you are.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you drink so much that you become <kanji>drunk</kanji>, then your alcohol will begin to taste like water. What is the reading of <ja>水</ja>? It's <ja><reading>すい</reading></ja>, which is the reading for this kanji.
data.reading_hint: Speaking of <ja>水</ja>, you need to drink some. You need to rehydrate and <ja>水</ja> is the best way to do it. Drink a lot of <ja>水</ja>. Go. Now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: To make <radical>alcohol</radical> the <radical>key</radical> is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become <kanji>vinegar</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine making a bunch of vinegar. You use a key to change it from alcohol to vinegar, yum!
data.reading_mnemonic: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a <reading>su</reading>it (<ja>す</ja>). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into <kanji>vinegar</kanji>.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself doing the same thing as before but you are now wearing a suit. Dang, you look good.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> man has one <radical>mustache</radical> above his lip and one <radical>mustache</radical> below his lip and keeps all his extra mustaches safely tucked away in a <kanji>pot</kanji>. This man is made of gold and has a lot of money. That’s how he can afford to groom two mustaches at the same time. If anything should happen to one, he has plenty of back up mustaches in his mustache storage pot.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this double mustachioed gold man as he rifles through his pot of mustaches. Imagine how ticklish they must be.
data.reading_mnemonic: The mustachioed man’s wife asks if he loves his <kanji>pot</kanji> of mustaches more than he loves her. “<reading>Nah ba</reading>be (<ja>なべ</ja>),” he says. “Nah, babe. Nah.”
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as this golden man with the mustache (and another mustache). Say “Nah, babe” over and over again like you’re trying to convince your wife that you actually love her more than your pot of luxurious mustaches.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical>s during the <radical>old</radical> <radical>moon</radical>s (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's <kanji>lake</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Where did lakes come from? They are the residue of tsunamis from many moons ago.
data.reading_mnemonic: "That's where <kanji>lake</kanji>s come from," you tell the <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: This is just a stupid story to get this <ja>子</ja> to stop asking "why, why, why?" about everything. Earlier, the <ja>子</ja> asked "where do lakes come from?" and you had to come up with a crazy story to quiet them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Gold</radical> is not the <radical>same</radical> as <kanji>copper</kanji>. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper.
data.meaning_hint: Take a piece of gold in one hand and a piece of copper in the other. Bang them together furiously as you shout. “GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER! GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER!”
data.reading_mnemonic: Smashing the <kanji>copper</kanji> against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (<ja>どう</ja>). Go get yourself a doughnut.
data.reading_hint: Mmm… doughnuts. Eat the doughnut and taste its yummy flavor as you look at the piece of copper. It’s shiny.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fingers</radical> are <radical>private</radical>, no one can see them unless they <kanji>pay</kanji>! And you decide if what they pay is enough to get a peek.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine people coming from miles around to pay for a look at your private fingers.
data.reading_mnemonic: If someone tries to look without paying, that's <reading>hara</reading>ssment (<ja>はら</ja>)! Nobody gets to see something of yours without proper payment, but more importantly, your consent!
data.reading_hint: If somebody looks at your fingers without paying, without your consent, file a harassment claim on their butt! That is NOT okay!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tsunami</radical> is the <radical>reason</radical> we have so much <kanji>oil</kanji> now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami!
data.meaning_hint: Watch as this tsunami crashes over the land, pushing earth out of the way. Once the tsunami passes, hear the spewing geysers of oil as they erupt out of the ground.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that <kanji>oil</kanji> is so abundant, everyone lives in <reading>yu</reading>rts (<ja>ゆ</ja>). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil.
data.reading_hint: Look at how this oil has changed the world. Instead of living in big homes, condos, or skyscrapers, everyone lives in a yurt at night and travels with all the oil by day.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>commander</radical>'s <radical>alcohol</radical> is really just <kanji>soy sauce</kanji>. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce.
data.meaning_hint: The next time you go to a bar, order yourself a commander's alcohol. It's like saying you want a Roy Rogers or a Shirley Temple, except it isn't pretty and it tastes horrible.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Soy sauce</kanji> also happens to be the <reading>Shou</reading>gun's (<ja>しょう</ja>) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun sitting on his throne, guzzling down some salty, brown soy sauce. It's splashing on his robes and the smell is making his assistants gag.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>stick</radical> next to the <radical>sun</radical>, reflecting on its <kanji>former</kanji> glory. The stick used to be a great tree, and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree.
data.meaning_hint: Pretend you are the stick. Really focus on your former self as you feel the sun warm you with its rays. Imagine yourself growing, larger and larger.
data.reading_mnemonic: It's working, it's working! The stick is returning to its <kanji>former</kanji> state and... w-wuh? It sprouted a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (<ja>きゅう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: I guess this stick was formerly a cucumber tree. Or maybe it just tried so hard it pooped a cucumber. I don't care which one is true, you pick whatever you want to believe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: That special <radical>woman</radical> in your <radical>life</radical> will eventually take your <kanji>surname</kanji> and make it her <kanji>family name</kanji> too. Traditionally, a woman will change her last name when she gets married and keep that name for the rest of her life. Her husband’s family name becomes her family name too.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having your surname changed for the rest of your life. How do you feel about having a different family name? Is it a big deal to you or does it not matter much?
data.reading_mnemonic: Picture this special woman in your mind. She's changing her <kanji>surname</kanji> to yours and taking hold of your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) as well. And it's... it's splitting in two!
data.reading_hint: Now you share a family name AND a holy blue saber! You can protect your legacy (and surname) hand in hand and saber in saber. (Or something like that.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: You send your <radical>private</radical> <radical>sword</radical> man out with your <radical>shellfish</radical> so he can <kanji>trade</kanji> them. Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your private sword holding a big bag of shellfish and going off to market to trade them.
data.reading_mnemonic: While he's out making the <kanji>trade</kanji> for you, you decide to relax and do some <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you.
data.reading_hint: Oh boy, I hope my private sword trades my shellfish for that new bowling ball I heard about!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>commander</radical> radical and the <kanji>commander</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: Who is the <kanji>commander</kanji> of Japan? The <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>)! And if you ever say anyone else or vote for someone else or even THINK about someone else being the commander, he'll find you and cut off your head.
data.reading_hint: You better remember the Shougun is the commander of everything... or else...

data.meaning_mnemonic: I’ll give you this <radical>bright</radical> <radical>plate</radical> if you agree to an <kanji>alliance</kanji> with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this bright plate. Look at it. It’s awesome. It’s blinding. Hold it in your hands. Marvel at it. Wow. This plate is sweet.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person you are trying to get in an <kanji>alliance</kanji> with you is the captain of the <reading>May</reading>flower (<ja>めい</ja>). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad.
data.reading_hint: This Mayflower boat is the best boat you ever did see. Hear the ocean around it as it bobs in the water, full sails billowing in the wind. Boats are cool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you go on a <radical>scooter</radical>, anything <radical>valuable</radical>, you need to <kanji>leave behind</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Rings, necklaces, wallets, phones? Don't take them on a scooter. Leave behind all that valuable stuff!
data.reading_mnemonic: Anything you don't <kanji>leave behind</kanji> will be stolen by <reading>ea</reading>gles (<ja>い</ja>). Eagles like shiny, valuable things, especially ones that are bouncing around on you while you scoot by on a scooter.
data.reading_hint: If you keep too many of your valuables on you, the eagles might not leave you behind either! They'll just pick you up off the scooter and carry you and your valuables off to their nests!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> who's <radical>humble</radical> will <kanji>stretch</kanji> in front of everyone. They'll show that they have to get up every hour or so and stretch just like the rest of us.
data.meaning_hint: The leader is humble and human, just like the rest of us, and has to stretch to stay healthy too. He's not some kind of god!
data.reading_mnemonic: The leader is currently working hard to <kanji>stretch</kanji> in front of all of you, and as he does, he munches on some <reading>no</reading>ri (<ja>の</ja>) seaweed snacks. Then he starts stretching the nori too.
data.reading_hint: Watch as the leader stretches his body and the nori seaweed. He takes a bite, stretches the other way, then stretches out a piece for you to eat too. How humble of him!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> gets the <radical>blame</radical> if your company is in <kanji>debt</kanji>. They're the one who led you all into that debt, so they should get the blame too.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the leader standing up in front of everyone as they blame him. He's holding a plaque with the amount of debt you're all in. Try to imagine what that number would be.
data.reading_mnemonic: To pay off this <kanji>debt</kanji> your leader says you need to sell your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>) to help the company. You fight him! You yell! You scream! The cyborg puts a half-human half-robot hand on your shoulder and shakes its head sadly.
data.reading_hint: Watch as your cyborg saves your company, even though it wasn't even his responsibility, from crippling debt. *sob* I can't believe your cyborg is gone!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Escalator</radical>s are used to <kanji>reach</kanji> things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself on an escalator. What is up above that you’re trying to reach?
data.reading_mnemonic: You're riding the escalator trying to <kanji>reach</kanji> a delicious <reading>cu</reading>cumber (<ja>きゅう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Cucumbers grow on trees sometimes, so you need to take escalators to get up there and reach them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>big</radical> <radical>jackhammer</radical> in <kanji>Nara</kanji>. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this big jackhammer. Look at it. It’s so big. Also it’s in Nara. Imagine being in Nara and looking at this big jackhammer. You’re all like, dang – that’s a big jackhammer.
data.reading_mnemonic: What’s the first part of <kanji>Nara</kanji>? <reading>Na</reading> (<ja>な</ja>). Well that’s easy.
data.reading_hint: Just keep in mind what the first part of Nara is. The first part of Nara is “na” so you’ll have no trouble remembering this one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to put this <radical>towel</radical> over this <radical>scarecrow</radical>, but you have to measure its <kanji>width</kanji> first. If the towel doesn't have a greater width than the scarecrow, some of it will be showing. Which you definitely don't want.
data.meaning_hint: The scarecrow creeps you out. You don't want to look at it anymore, so you're standing eerily close to it measuring its width, so you can hide it forever.
data.reading_mnemonic: You finish measuring the the <kanji>width</kanji> of the scarecrow and the width of the towel, and you realize you're the width of a <reading>haba</reading>nero (<ja>はば</ja>) pepper short. This is fine, you grow those. This is a whole field of habaneros! So you pluck one off the nearest plant, tape it to the cloth, and cover that scarecrow right up.
data.reading_hint: Do you know the width of a habanero? It's one scarecrow minus one cloth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>canopy</radical>, after your <radical>departure</radical>, will become <kanji>obsolete</kanji>. The canopy was here to protect you, but no one will need it once you're gone.
data.meaning_hint: During your departure you look back at the obsolete canopy just once. It's standing there, still and alone. It's a really sad sight.
data.reading_mnemonic: When something becomes <kanji>obsolete</kanji>, you must write a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>). Honestly, the best haiku are about something ending, so this is perfect.
data.reading_hint:
My sweet canopy
I don't need you anymore
You are obsolete

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sweet</radical> radical and the <kanji>sweet</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sweet</kanji>, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet resistant <reading>armor</reading> (<ja>あま</ja>) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload.
data.reading_hint: Put on the armor! Feel its weight on your body. Now taste the sweet flavor on your tongue. It’s sweet, but not too sweet.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>prison</radical>, when you have access to a <radical>big</radical> number of <radical>fingers</radical>, <radical>mouth</radical>s, and <radical>legs</radical> you can <kanji>exchange</kanji> them for things that are worth more to you. What are you gonna do with all these body parts in prison? You should exchange them for cigarettes and toilet alcohol.
data.meaning_hint: You just have so many fingers, mouths, and legs you've pummeled off of the other prisoners. Exchange them for better loot!
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this type of <kanji>exchange</kanji> from the mighty Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>). You read a book or watched a show about him once and you're pretty positive that Genghis Khan would exchange the body parts of his enemies all over the continents of Asia and Europe for nicer stuff.
data.reading_hint: Think back to when you were a kid and they would roll out those TVs on stands into the classrooms. Imagine watching a documentary on Genghis Khan's exchange routes where he bought and sold body parts. Educational!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Stick your <radical>fingers</radical> in your <radical>mohawk</radical> and <kanji>pluck</kanji> each hair out, one by one.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine plucking the hairs out of your mohawk with your fingers. It's kind of hard to grab onto them at first, but eventually you're plucking them like it's nothing.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>pluck</kanji> all your mohawk hair out because you're a <reading>techie</reading> (<ja>てき</ja>), and everyone at your techie job keeps making fun of you for your hair choices. "Techies should be bald!" your boss screamed. So here you are, plucking your hair out to fit in.
data.reading_hint: You didn't realize techies were so inclusive... but they just plucked and plucked at your self-esteem, until you decided to pluck your hair out of your own head.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>tree</radical> and <radical>slice</radical> it until you reach its <kanji>nucleus</kanji>. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine slicing this tree smaller and smaller until you finally get to the nucleus of it. It’s super tiny so you have to view it in a microscope. What does it look like?
data.reading_mnemonic: It looks like a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the <kanji>nucleus</kanji> of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird.
data.reading_hint: Look at this tree nucleus that looks like a cock. While you’re watching it, the nucleus goes “Cock-a-doodle-doo!”

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>tsunami</radical> in the <radical>middle</radical> of the <kanji>open sea</kanji>. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this tsunami in the middle of the open sea. When the tsunami isn’t destroying things and is just out there in the open sea it looks really majestic and pretty.
data.reading_mnemonic: Someone dares you to go out to the <kanji>open sea</kanji> and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “<reading>Oki</reading> (<ja>おき</ja>) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”.
data.reading_hint: You really regret saying oki doki this time. You don’t want to surf on a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Imagine doing so. It’s terrifying and wet and you don’t even know how to surf. You’re going to die.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone <radical>thread</radical>ed a <radical>turtle</radical> into long skinny pieces, making a <kanji>rope</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: A rope made of threaded turtles. Go ahead and grab onto it and see how it feels. A little rough, but strong.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person making these threaded turtle <kanji>rope</kanji>s is the local giant farmhand <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>). You watch him stretch and peel pieces of turtle off of turtles, then thread them together into a rope.
data.reading_hint: Besides being awful, where did Jourm learn to thread turtles into ropes? Why does he have so many turtles despite living on such an inland farm? These are nice ropes that Jourm is making though, and you kind of want to buy some.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>tsunami</radical> comes, the <radical>brush</radical> makes a good safe <kanji>haven</kanji>. Thick brush is a haven from tsunamis because the brush will break the tsunami water and keep you safe and dry.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being in the haven of a brush while a tsunami strikes. Hear the water crash and rush all around you while you remain safe in your haven.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only downside about this <kanji>haven</kanji> is that there’s only room for <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) people in the brush. The brush isn’t big enough for more than two people, so unless you have a lot of brush, you won’t be saving many people from the tsunami.
data.reading_hint: Since there is room for two people in the brush, imagine yourself in the haven with one other person. They and you make two. The other person is a real whiner though - imagine them crying the whole time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>South</radical> <radical>Dog</radical> gives you an <kanji>offer</kanji>. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything.
data.meaning_hint: It is well known that dogs in the South are famous for their kindness and hospitality. It's customary to always offer something when a guest arrives.
data.reading_mnemonic: The South Dog <kanji>offer</kanji>s you the services of <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai as you traverse his lands.
data.reading_hint: Ken offers to carry you, too. Imagine him offering this. You can choose whether or not to accept in your mind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone is <radical>sick</radical> feed them <radical>charcoal</radical> to <kanji>heal</kanji> them. Okay, so maybe you shouldn't feed it directly to them, but charcoal has amazing water filtration powers. So put charcoal in their water and the water will heal them right up.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being sick. Like sick as a dog sick. And then you take some charcoal, put it into your drinking water, and then you're healed!
data.reading_mnemonic: You aren't the only one that needs to be <kanji>heal</kanji>ed, so you take your <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) boat out onto the lake where your town gets its drinking water and you dump a bunch of charcoal into it! Now everyone will be healed when they drink.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself rowing your row boat into the lake with huge chunks of solid charcoal. You carefully break them up and toss them over the side, so you can heal everyone.

data.meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>thread</radical>, a <radical>lion</radical> sews together all the <radical>rice</radical> he'll <kanji>inherit</kanji> from his parents one day. He's convinced his parents are going to try to keep some of his inheritance from him, so he's linking it all together so it can't go anywhere.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this lion surrounded by the thousands of grains of rice he'll inherit from his parents. He's carefully threading them all together.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're going to <kanji>inherit</kanji> something from your parents, try to convince them to make it <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>), not rice. A single cake is much easier to keep track of and probably tastier (though it will be super stale by the time they die).
data.reading_hint: I'd much rather inherit a cake than a ton of hard to keep track of rice, like this poor lion.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You tie a piece of <radical>thread</radical> to your <radical>turkey</radical> in order to <kanji>maintain</kanji> proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding onto a thread that is attached to a turkey. Feel the turkey tug against the thread as you struggle to maintain control.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason the turkey is struggling is because there’s an <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to <kanji>maintain</kanji> control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread.
data.reading_hint: Now you and the turkey and the eagle are all bumbling about in pandemonium. You try to maintain order but it’s not possible. What a kerfuffle.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>nothing</radical> <radical>dance</radical> is still a <kanji>dance</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: If you want to do the nothing dance, just clear your head so there's nothing in it, and then dance!
data.reading_mnemonic: To help you do this <kanji>dance</kanji> you need some <reading>boo</reading>ze (<ja>ぶ</ja>). Just enough so it's easier to think of nothing, let all your fears go, and dance.
data.reading_hint: Feel the booze coursing through your veins as you dance like no one is watching.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>branch</radical> became the leader from doing <kanji>deed</kanji>s. You can't rise to the rank of branch leader if you don't perform a certain number of deeds! Most of them good, I hope.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the leader of your branch doing deeds around your office. Pulling out chairs for people sitting down, emptying the trash, balancing spreadsheets. All good deeds.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>deed</kanji> he's currently working on is finding your lost <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). He doesn't have to help, you're the one who lost your own house-combination-car key. But he's so used to doing deeds, he can't help but help.
data.reading_hint: Picture him doing this deed. He's crawling around on the floor looking for your key. You aren't really helping, you're just watching him do the deed of key-searching for you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You soak each <radical>foot</radical> in <radical>water</radical> before going out in the <radical>sun</radical> to take your first <kanji>step</kanji>. Stepping on the ground when it's been baking in the hot sun can burn your feet, so you're careful to make them wet with water before stepping outside even once.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine each step on hot, sun-baked asphalt. The water under your feet sizzles, leaving steaming footprints where you stepped from.
data.reading_mnemonic: Each <kanji>step</kanji> you take brings you closer to <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach <ja>とうきょう</ja>, no matter how many steps it takes.
data.reading_hint: Each step is taking you closer to <ja>とうきょう</ja>. Don't forget that, no matter how hard it seems, don't lose your motivation to keep stepping forward toward your goal. ♡

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>boat</radical> will have at least one <radical>weapon</radical>, <kanji>generally</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: In general, you can assume a boat will have a weapon, but not all of them will.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Generally</kanji> a boat with a weapon will be owned by <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo.
data.reading_hint: So of all the boats out there, generally all of them have weapons, and generally Han Solo will be on one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>bundle</radical> of <radical>geoduck</radical>s is something you can always <kanji>trust</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: A bundle of geoducks will never lie, never let you down, and never disappoint you. You can trust them completely.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you can <kanji>trust</kanji> a bundle of geoducks, never ever trust <reading>rye</reading> (<ja>らい</ja>) bread.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a bundle of geoducks and a piece rye bread. Think about how you can trust the geoducks but you can't trust the rye bread.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> has <radical>clothes</radical> that he is quite <kanji>reliant</kanji> on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this leader in his clothes. Look how reliant he is on them. Imagine what he would be without his clothes – nothing! And also, naked.
data.reading_mnemonic: The leader has become so <kanji>reliant</kanji> on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with <reading>ea</reading>gles (<ja>い</ja>) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore.
data.reading_hint: Look at the leader as he shouts at his clothes he’s become so reliant on to do something. Hear the countless eagles screeching around as they terrorize the neighborhood. People scream and weep in the streets.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> and a <radical>helicopter</radical> are being <radical>compare</radical>d by a <kanji>deer</kanji>. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the deer comparing the two structures. It probably has no idea what they are, but it's trying very hard to understand what it's seeing anyway.
data.reading_mnemonic: You walk forward, about to call out to the <kanji>deer</kanji>, when a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) suddenly appears out of no where and runs the deer over! Was this all just a trap set up to murder the deer?!
data.reading_hint: Deer get hit by cars all the time, but it was still really shocking . I mean it was right in front of you. The car could have hit you too!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something and the <radical>flowers</radical> are <radical>right</radical> in <kanji>agreement</kanji>. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement.
data.meaning_hint: What did you say to the flowers that you are so in agreement about? Think about what you said.
data.reading_mnemonic: You and the flowers are in <kanji>agreement</kanji> on the fact that neither of you like when a <reading>duck</reading> (<ja>だく</ja>) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face.
data.reading_hint: Imagine you are the flowers. There’s a duck. It’s making a poo. On you. Ew, man, that’s disgusting. Bleh.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fang</radical> radical and the <kanji>fang</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means <kanji>tusk</kanji>. It means fang and tusk.
data.meaning_hint: Since the fang radical is the same as the fang kanji, that should be easy to remember. Tusks aren’t too different from fangs, so that shouldn’t be too hard to remember either.
data.reading_mnemonic: Lots of animals have <kanji>fang</kanji>s, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the <reading>ge</reading>cko (<ja>げ</ja>)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.
data.reading_hint: Picture a gecko with cute little fangs. You can keep thinking they're cute as long as one never bites you. They may be little, but gecko fangs are no joke!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>foot</radical> heard an <radical>omen</radical> and now it's making you <kanji>hop</kanji> over things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your foot hearing this omen, "If you step on a crack, you'll break your mother's back." Now your foot hops over all of the tiny cracks in the street and the sidewalk and you look really silly.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you hop you start to hear an awful scream coming down the street. It's Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>) and she's running straight for you yelling, "STEP ON MY STREET'S CRACKS! STOP HOPPING OR YOUR MOTHER WILL NEVER BREAK HER BACK!"
data.reading_hint: Now you're hopping away in fear from Mrs. Chou!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> <radical>call</radical>s out to the earth by <kanji>shining</kanji> down on it.
data.meaning_hint: The sun doesn't have a voice, unfortunately, so it calls out the only way it can, with its shining rays.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shining</kanji> is aimed directly at the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun standing in the shining sunlight. He's so bright and beautiful!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> pushes all the <radical>fish</radical> closer to land, making for some easy <kanji>fishing</kanji>. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine going fishing for fish in a fishing spot after a tsunami. There are SO many fish here. Your hook barely touches the water and there’s already a fish on it. Man, fishing like this is easy! Smell the smell of fish and sea air around you.
data.reading_mnemonic: To get to the best <kanji>fishing</kanji> spot you need to <reading>go</reading> (<ja>ぎょ</ja>) <reading>row</reading> (<ja>りょう</ja>) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea.
data.reading_hint: Go! Go row! Go and row for the fishing! How do you go? You row! The row part should be pretty easy to remember since you gotta row your boat out to sea, but if you’re having trouble with the go part, just remember that it has the same reading as <ja>魚</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> presents you with a <radical>prize</radical> as <kanji>reparation</kanji> for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine receiving your reparation prize. Feel the prize in your hand. It’s all wrapped up but it’s heavy and feels expensive. What could it be?
data.reading_mnemonic: The leader who presented you with this <kanji>reparation</kanji> is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for).
data.reading_hint: Imagine receiving your reparations from the Shougun himself. You're angry at him for threatening you, wounding people, and cutting off the heads of people who go against him, but you take it anyway.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Destroy a <radical>lantern</radical> with your <radical>knife</radical> and you'll be <kanji>punish</kanji>ed.
data.meaning_hint: Even if it was your own lantern, why stab it with a knife? You could have recycled that. I will punish you for lantern stabbing and pollution!
data.reading_mnemonic: I will <kanji>punish</kanji> you by taking away your <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment.
data.reading_hint: The next time you want to stab a lantern with a knife, think about how good cake tastes and stop. Remember, DARE (Don't Attack Reusable Electronics)!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>greenhouse</radical> is the newest <radical>power</radical> of the city you decided to <kanji>recruit</kanji>. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what you had to do to recruit this greenhouse. Imagine schmoozing with the previous greenhouse owners to recruit them to your cause and sell you the greenhouse.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>recruit</kanji> the greenhouse, you recruit <reading>Bo</reading>bo (<ja>ぼ</ja>) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse.
data.reading_hint: Recruit Bobo the clown. Look at him. He’s terrifying. Bobo will make for a great deterrent for entry to your greenhouse.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Happiness</radical> is a <radical>circle</radical> that's <kanji>tenacious</kanji>. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can.
data.meaning_hint: Be tenacious about happiness in your life. No matter how many times it slips away, don't give up. Keep going after it, because it will absolutely come back if you're tenacious enough.
data.reading_mnemonic: Happiness is as <kanji>tenacious</kanji> as a <reading>shih tzu</reading> (<ja>しつ</ja>) with a <reading>shoe</reading> (<ja>しゅう</ja>). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it.
data.reading_hint: Will someone take the shoe sometimes? Yeah, but the shih tzu doesn't give up. That's how you need to be with happiness. Kids, be tenacious!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's an <radical>explosion</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> under a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, exposing the hidden <kanji>base</kanji> under there. A base from baseball! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field...
data.meaning_hint: Picture a serene rice paddy. Now watch the whole thing explode, rice and dirt going everywhere, and a secret, underground baseball base is left there, smoldering.
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the <kanji>base</kanji> is in <reading>rui</reading>ns (<ja>るい</ja>). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game.
data.reading_hint: Hold this ruined base in your hands. Darn, you love baseball. At least it's a collectible.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Below this <radical>mountain</radical>, a <radical>moon</radical> and another <radical>moon</radical> crash into each other and the entire thing <kanji>crumble</kanji>s to pieces.
data.meaning_hint: Watch as the moons crumble together, and then the mountain slowly crumbles down into them too.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the mountain <kanji>crumble</kanji>s you see your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too.
data.reading_hint: Your home crumbles like a dry cookie until it's nothing more than a bunch of dust, mixed in with the mountain and the moon. Now where will you live?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>skewer</radical> to the <radical>heart</radical> has <kanji>afflicted</kanji> your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying.
data.meaning_hint: You did not wish to be afflicted as such. Feel the skewer in your heart and the great pain it gives you. You know you’re dying.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since you’re <kanji>afflicted</kanji> with the death, you start to hallucinate and the ghost of Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) appears before you. "Ah, I was afflicted of the same disease. It killed me, you know."
data.reading_hint: You look on in horror as the affliction grabs hold and everything starts to fade, but Genghis Khan still floats before you, watching you closely.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>door</radical> is <radical>big</radical> and you need to <kanji>return</kanji> it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them.
data.meaning_hint: Heft this big door in your arms. It’s very heavy. Feel your arms tire as you look for who to return the door to.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are in <kanji>return</kanji> <reading>mode</reading> (<ja>もど</ja>). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode.
data.reading_hint: You’re obsessed with returning this big door. Once you enter this mode, the only way to get out is to return the thing you have.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take your <radical>fingers</radical> and slam a <radical>lid</radical> on the <radical>table</radical>. You make this big noise to <kanji>confront</kanji> the person in front of you.
data.meaning_hint: They weren't listening, which is why you slammed that lid down. You'll have to confront them more directly.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are trying to <kanji>confront</kanji> Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. You're confronting him about all the kanji he's forcing you, and everyone else, to learn. "Look here <ja>こういち</ja>! I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?"
data.reading_hint: <ja>こういち</ja> is laughing at you as you confront him. Which makes you angrier, so you bang the lid on the table some more.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Everyone from your <radical>clan</radical> puts their <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> as a way to <kanji>resist</kanji> their lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. This is a protest! Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your entire clan putting their fingers in the ground in unison as a form of resistance. It's a moving sight.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're all <kanji>resist</kanji>ing with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots!"
data.reading_hint: You make your choice to resist. He orders his guards to pull your fingers out of the ground, chop them into the size of tater tots, and then deep fry them. After they're done, the lord pops one in his mouth and says, "Oooh, resistance is delicious."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put the <radical>sun</radical> in <radical>prison</radical> and everything will always be <kanji>in season</kanji>. If the sun is in prison, the season's can't change. Want to wear a giant weenie costume all year round? Put the sun in prison on Halloween. Now your weenie body is always in season because it's always the same <kanji>time of month</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You're welcome. Now you know how to keep everything in season. Lifehack!
data.reading_mnemonic: When things are <kanji>in season</kanji> for too long, people are going to wonder what's going on. When's Christmas? When's Golden Week? <reading>Soon</reading> (<ja>しゅん</ja>), you say. Soon enough, it's <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>) which is the middle of the year so everything is soon.
data.reading_hint: Jokes on them though. Halloween will be in season forever now. Soon it will be Halloween. Soon it will be time for candy. Soon June will end and people will forget about everything else.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> dug out a chunk of the land and now it looks like a big <radical>red</radical> <radical>bow</radical>. It's a <kanji>gulf</kanji> now!
data.meaning_hint: Picture all the famous gulfs you learned about in geography class. Most of them look like someone pressed a bow into them and dug out the land. (And just imagine they're red because the earth is bleeding, making the sand red.)
data.reading_mnemonic: How many tsunamis does it take to make a <kanji>gulf</kanji>? Just <reading>one</reading> (<ja>わん</ja>). If there were more, then no land would be left behind. It would all be taken into the sea.
data.reading_hint: Watch one tsunami come in and cut out a chunk of land, leaving behind a big, red gulf.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you combine <radical>fire</radical> with <radical>violence</radical>, it will <kanji>explode</kanji>! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the fire explode. Feel the heat of the fire and the explosion. It’s very violent. BOOM BOOM BA-BOOM!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the fire <kanji>explode</kanji>, you start to <reading>back</reading> (<ja>ばく</ja>) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as you back away from the explosion. As you back away, see the fire dance and feel the heat of the explosion on your face.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What's more <radical>simple</radical> than a <radical>bow</radical>? A <kanji>bullet</kanji>. Bullets just have to be shot out of a gun and somebody dies. Bows you have to load with an arrow and pull it back and aim, yuck. Bullets are the new bows, people.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how simple life would be if we replaced all the bows in the world with bullets. (Insert sarcastic crying face here.)
data.reading_mnemonic: If you want to shoot <kanji>bullet</kanji>s, you need to do it at <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>). Back in the old days, it wasn't bright enough to shoot arrows at dawn, but you can shoot bullets at dawn because they're simpler to use!
data.reading_hint: Imagine shooting bullets into the sun at dawn. Pow pow, take that history! Blam blam, take that dawn!

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>ear</radical> is <radical>cross</radical>ed with sound, it catches it like a <radical>net</radical>, and sends it to your <radical>heart</radical> for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper <kanji>listen</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the whole process of sound going through your ear and to your heart, then the gears turning to really understand what someone is saying. It's a real listen, not a fake non-heart listen.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are <kanji>listen</kanji>ing so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>), who will destroy the earth.
data.reading_hint: Focus on listening, and focus on their message about Mrs. Chou. Feel afraid about the future because of it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>foot</radical> is a little <radical>red</radical> and you can see <kanji>traces</kanji> of ink streaked on it. Where did these traces come from?
data.meaning_hint: You look closer at your foot, examining the traces of red ink, and slowly the night before comes back to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Turns out the <kanji>traces</kanji> of red ink were from a <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>) rave you were at last night. Everyone around you looked so sexy, with their glow-in-the-dark paint, so you decided to put some of the red ink on your feet so everyone could see your sexy dancing.
data.reading_hint: As you feel the sexy, confident feelings return, you see traces of the ink on your carpet, all the way from the door to the bed. Dang it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>scooter</radical> is an <radical>insect</radical> and a <radical>bear</radical>. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call <kanji>dispatch</kanji>!"
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the conversation with emergency services. They say they will dispatch an ambulance immediately.
data.reading_mnemonic: Out of the <kanji>dispatch</kanji>ed ambulance jumps <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect."
data.reading_hint: He takes out a very tiny katana and performs surgery right there. The insect dies on the scooter. "It looks like I've dispatched this insect to the afterlife."

data.meaning_mnemonic: At this <radical>gate</radical> you're trying to get some <radical>beans</radical> through, but the <radical>measurements</radical> were off and you're starting to <kanji>struggle</kanji>. No matter how you push or pull these beans, they're just too big to get through the gate.
data.meaning_hint: "I'm really struggling here, I thought you said you measured these beans?" you ask the bean seller. "I did! I mean, I struggled with the measurements, I'm not very good at math..." Ugh.
data.reading_mnemonic: You continue to <kanji>struggle</kanji> because you need to get these beans to the other side of the gate and into <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. You usually struggle a little when people want to bring things through the gate to <ja>とうきょう</ja>, but this is ridiculous.
data.reading_hint: "How am I supposed to sell my beans if you struggle this much just to get them into <ja>とうきょう</ja>!" the bean seller shouts. It's making you struggle more, and beans start falling on your head, ripping their way out of their sack.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> is full of <radical>car</radical>s because it's an <kanji>army base</kanji>. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a giant army base housing all of the different cars the army needs at any given time.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of the people in the <kanji>army base</kanji> are wearing <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're on the base they have to wear jeans.
data.reading_hint: Jeans are pretty durable, now that you think about it. And if the soldiers are working on these cars in the base while they're there, it makes sense to wear a nice pair of jeans.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Grain</radical> left in the <radical>sun</radical> blossom and give off a wonderful <kanji>fragrance</kanji>. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this warm, grain fragrance. What does it smell like to you? Cooked rice? Gentle flowers? A warm summer's day?
data.reading_mnemonic: As you sniff this lovely <kanji>fragrance</kanji> you get lost in the smell. When you open your eyes again, you see a farming <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> standing in front of you. With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other <ja>こういち</ja>s."
data.reading_hint: This fragrance was <ja>こういち</ja>'s armpits the whole time. You thought it was warm grains. Or... maybe he smells like... grains?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>omen</radical> radical and the <kanji>omen</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: If you know the omen radical, you know the omen kanji as well!
data.reading_mnemonic: You listen to the <kanji>omen</kanji>, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>) will destroy the world.
data.reading_hint:
You can clarify with the person telling you the omen several things: "Do you believe in the omen about Mrs. Chou destroying the world?" "When will this omen about Mrs. Chou come true?" etc. As long as you're associating omen with Mrs. Chou you should be good, so keep harping on that.

Anyway, whenever you hear any kind of omen (omen is a radical in the kanji), there's a good chance it's going to be about Mrs. Chou.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give your <radical>servant</radical> a <radical>gun</radical> along with some other <radical>products</radical> to <kanji>look to</kanji>. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your servant as he looks to your gun and products. You can always look to him to take care of your menial tasks. You feel smug.
data.reading_mnemonic: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to <kanji>look to</kanji> your car’s o-<reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your servant as he looks to your car’s o-ring. Hear him clinking and clanking around in the garage as he does so.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>triceratops</radical> with a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>knife</radical> can <kanji>whittle down</kanji> anything.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the triceratops with its little moon knife, doing some whittling. Hand it anything and it will whittle it down.
data.reading_mnemonic: Everything it will <kanji>whittle down</kanji> shall be put in a <reading>sack</reading> (<ja>さく</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Check out the sack that holds all the things that the triceratops whittled down. Go ahead and look through it, it's quite filled.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The weight of <radical>life</radical> on your <radical>sword</radical> is <radical>big</radical> when you <kanji>pledge</kanji> to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding up your sword and pledging to protect the lives of everyone in this city. It's a big deal!
data.reading_mnemonic: Until the city is safe, you <kanji>pledge</kanji> to give up <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>), your favorite food.
data.reading_hint: Would you pledge to give up cake to show everyone how serious you are about protecting life?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You carry a <radical>cross</radical> across a <radical>rice paddy</radical> with a <radical>heart</radical> on it to return a <kanji>favor</kanji> for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it.
data.meaning_hint: This is a pretty big favor. Imagine running through a rice paddy carrying a cross with a warm beating heart on it. Thump thump. Thump thump.
data.reading_mnemonic: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the <kanji>favor</kanji> you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “<reading>Eh</reading> (<ja>え</ja>)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine!
data.reading_hint: Imagine how dumb you feel at this miscommunication. Eh? You don’t feel dumb? Well you should!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> and <radical>wrap</radical> them around another person. This is called a <kanji>hug</kanji>. Just make sure you include all the stuff attached to your fingers, like your hands and arms too, otherwise it's more of a squeeze, and we don't want to do that to people.
data.meaning_hint: Picture it like you're a baby who is new to hugs. You start with your fingers, spread them out and move forward. Now wrap all that stuff attached to your fingers around another person. You did it! You're hugging now!
data.reading_mnemonic: Who do you love to <kanji>hug</kanji> the most? Your <reading>da</reading>d (<ja>だ</ja>)! He gives the best hugs. They're warm and big and tight and comforting. The kind of hug dads are really good at giving.
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting a nice, big hug from your dad. Mm. It's cozy and feels like home.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're in <radical>prison</radical>, but you can use your <radical>fingers</radical> and a <radical>spoon</radical> in the light of the <radical>sun</radical> to <kanji>display</kanji> little moving pictures on your cell wall. It's like a shadow puppet display except you can only make a few characters with your limited hand tools.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine displaying your two favorite characters in the shadows on your prison cell walls. This one is mister fingers and this one is missus spoon. They're best friends.
data.reading_mnemonic: There is one thing you <kanji>display</kanji> more than anything else and it's <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>). You smush your fingers to make a cake shape and use the spoon to pretend you're eating it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine displaying cake on the wall. Now pretend to eat the shadow cake with your spoon. You can almost taste it. Except you can't, because this is still prison.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see an <radical>animal</radical> wearing a <radical>top hat</radical> and decide to <kanji>aim</kanji> at it. The top hat is a perfect, giant target you use to take down this animal.
data.meaning_hint: It's much easier to aim for an animal wearing a top hat than one without.
data.reading_mnemonic: Ready, steady, <kanji>aim</kanji>... fire! You throw a bar of <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>) at the animal. Yes, soap. You were sitting in your bathtub, washing and scrubbing, then the animal in the top hat caught your eye.
data.reading_hint: Your aim with the soap is perfect! The soap knocked the deer's hat right off.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You brought <radical>flowers</radical> to place on top of the place where a <radical>yakuza</radical> took a <radical>spoon</radical> and killed <radical>twenty</radical> people, and there is now a <kanji>burial</kanji> happening. You carefully toss the flowers in with the dirt and everything is buried together.
data.meaning_hint: This is the biggest burial you've ever seen. The hole is huge. It has to fit twenty people, after all, and the spoon didn't cut them up to make things any easier.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the <kanji>burial</kanji> is complete the <reading>sou</reading>ls (<ja>そう</ja>) of all the dead people come floating up and out of the ground. "Thaaannk YooOoOO~" they moan, as they ascend to the sky.
data.reading_hint: I guess the twenty souls couldn't go up to... wherever... until they had a proper burial.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>rain</radical> I take my <radical>rake</radical> and shake it, making a <kanji>demand</kanji> that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it!
data.meaning_hint: Go out into the rain and shake your rake. Imagine shouting your demand at the sky as the rain pelts you from above.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's <reading>ju</reading>ice (<ja>じゅ</ja>)! You shake your rake harder, and <kanji>demand</kanji> that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself demanding more rain from the sky, trying to fill up your tiny juice box with what little juice rain you were able to get.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You get <radical>tooth</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your <kanji>age</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You get baby age tooth orders (to get your first teeth). You get child age tooth orders (to get your adult teeth). Then you get old age tooth orders (when you start losing your teeth). There are tooth orders for every age.
data.reading_mnemonic: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on <kanji>age</kanji>. There is also an age in which you get your first <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun.
data.reading_hint:
Decide what age you have to be to get your first ray gun, and then imagine getting it when you hit that age. Perhaps you use this ray gun on your teeth, to keep them clean.

Hint: when you see the radical <radical>orders</radical> it's fairly likely the reading will be <ja>れい</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: By showing the <radical>roof</radical> of your <radical>top hat</radical> you send your <kanji>best regards</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Giving your best regards is basically just tipping your hat and showing the roof of it.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you give your <kanji>best regards</kanji> you always yell <reading>YOLO</reading> (<ja>よろ</ja>) to the other person.
data.reading_hint: YOLO means "you only live once," so in a way that's a good way to give your best regards. At the very least, it's an interesting way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>thread</radical> and some <radical>syrup</radical> and you need to <kanji>spin</kanji> them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine carefully dripping syrup onto a thread and then spinning it in a circle.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>spin</kanji> the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a <reading>coo</reading>kie (<ja>く</ja>)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air.
data.reading_hint: Imagine eating a syrup cookie you made by spinning it yourself. Homemade is always better than store-bought.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're on a <radical>scooter</radical> and suddenly someone throws a <radical>hot pepper</radical> at you and you have to <kanji>dodge</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine riding your scooter, dodging multiple hot peppers as they're tossed at you. A few of them get stuck in the wheels and keep coming around and around, and you have to dodge them too.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>dodge</kanji> the hot peppers, you feel a strong <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating.
data.reading_hint: Feel the heat flow through your body. It's getting harder to dodge as the heat grows and you start sweating!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sleeps with the <radical>king</radical> and becomes <kanji>pregnant</kanji>. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby!
data.meaning_hint: The king radical is slightly altered in this kanji, so just remember that the king is a strange alien and not human. Imagine being this woman and having this half-breed alien baby inside you. Feels weird.
data.reading_mnemonic: Being <kanji>pregnant</kanji> with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (<ja>にん</ja>). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore.
data.reading_hint: What game are you playing on the Nintendo? Maybe it’s a game where you kill alien invaders? That’s messed up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who has a <radical>landslide</radical> getting ready inside her is <kanji>pregnant</kanji>. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide.
data.meaning_hint: Picture an ultrasound of the pregnant woman, but instead of a little baby heartbeat, you hear a scary roaring sound. That's what being pregnant is like. Waiting for the landslide to come.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>pregnant</kanji> the baby is constantly kicking you with their <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being pregnant and getting kicked by the shins of your baby all day, but especially all night. You're so tired. Please let this landslide come already.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mole</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> will <kanji>do</kanji> whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it.
data.meaning_hint: They do most of their own chores during the rest of the year, so winter is when you should ask them to do things for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: To get the mole to <kanji>do</kanji> what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of <reading>chee</reading>se (<ja>ち</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Moles will do anything for cheese, but honestly, wouldn't we all?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You got your copy of "The <radical>Dry</radical> <radical>Knife</radical>." It's the newest <kanji>edition</kanji> of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry.
data.meaning_hint: You're really into this magazine, and when you heard there's a new edition of it, you went out and bought it right away.
data.reading_mnemonic: In this <kanji>edition</kanji> of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning.
data.reading_hint: The article on Genghis Khan was perhaps the best written article in the Dry Knife series to date. How did this magazine get such a big interview?

data.meaning_mnemonic: When it's <radical>spring</radical> in <radical>heaven</radical> they <kanji>play music</kanji>. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up.
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes and imagine all of the spring sounds that come down to you from heaven in the springtime. Mmm, you can almost smell the damp soil and rain.
data.reading_mnemonic: In heaven, the ones that <kanji>play music</kanji> are the <reading>sou</reading>ls (<ja>そう</ja>) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band!
data.reading_hint: Picture all of the souls in heaven playing spring music together!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> asks <radical>half</radical> of his men to <kanji>accompany</kanji> him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you are one of the leader’s men who volunteered. What made you want to accompany him? Imagine the good qualities of this leader and how he inspired you to accompany him on this mission.
data.reading_mnemonic: The leader you decided to <kanji>accompany</kanji> is none other than <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as you accompany Han Solo. You try to stay calm, but you’re just so excited to be around Han Solo.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> takes a <radical>lantern</radical> and searches for people to <kanji>join</kanji> him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this shady leader approaching you in the night. The lantern light shines in your face. Would you join him?
data.reading_mnemonic: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to <kanji>join</kanji> him. You look around and spot a large <reading>hay</reading>stack (<ja>へい</ja>). You quickly jump into it and hide from him.
data.reading_hint: The last thing you wanted to do was join that guy so you hid in a haystack to avoid him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>change</radical> this <radical>geoduck</radical> because you want it to <kanji>lean</kanji>. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead.
data.meaning_hint: Why do you want this geoduck to lean? Try to come up with your own reason. And why don't you look up what a geoduck looks like one more time for good measure. You don't want to be able to get this image out of your head.
data.reading_mnemonic: To get the geoduck to <kanji>lean</kanji> you put a piece of <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>) on one of its sides.
data.reading_hint: Watch as the geoduck slowly leans toward the cake, trying to get at it for a taste. But don't let it eat any! Keep putting the cake further and further away so the geoduck has to lean more.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Past</radical> <radical>stamp</radical>s usually depict images <kanji>contrary</kanji> to current views.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this stamp. There's Columbus being hugged by a bunch of South American natives. Yikes, that's contrary to how things went, that's for sure.
data.reading_mnemonic: Don't be the type of person who acts <kanji>contrary</kanji> to how they should and instead be like <reading>Kyaku</reading> (<ja>きゃく</ja>) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people.
data.reading_hint: Be contrary to the evildoers of the past and be like Kyaku instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there’s a <radical>drop</radical> on your <radical>head</radical> and the <radical>rice</radical> is <radical>big</radical>, you know you’re in the <kanji>interior</kanji>. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being in the interior of someone’s tummy. See the big pieces of rice all around you as drops of stomach fluid continue to drop down on your head.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you’re in the <kanji>interior</kanji> of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “<reading>Ok</reading>lahoma” (<ja>おく</ja>) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!”
data.reading_hint: If you’re unfamiliar with this Oklahoma song, check it out on YouTube. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s belly as you hear this song booming all around you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> needs to <radical>think</radical> and <kanji>consider</kanji> its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this tiger as it approaches you. Think what things it has to consider. It has to consider how big of a threat you are and so on. You need to consider how you’re going to escape from this tiger.
data.reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>consider</kanji>ing you for so long that it takes out a <reading>ro</reading>be (<ja>りょ</ja>), a pipe, and an armchair and starts puffing away, staring intently at you. You didn't even know tigers could wear robes, but this one seems to use it to help itself think.
data.reading_hint: Consider this! Tigers look great in robes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>prefecture</radical>, you come from a long <radical>lineage</radical> of people who share one <radical>heart</radical>. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and <kanji>suspend</kanji>s itself in the sky, for you to take.
data.meaning_hint: You see the suspended heart in the distance, and make your way towards it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You arrive at the <kanji>suspend</kanji>ed heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai.
data.reading_hint: "I've protected this suspended heart for you, for you are next in the lineage to receive it." He grabs the heart and throws it into your body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>door</radical> in that <radical>direction</radical> is among a <kanji>cluster</kanji> of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing all these doors, this cluster of doors. You feel confused at which one to enter but finally pick one. Hear the door creak as you open it.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you make it through the door, you come across another <kanji>cluster</kanji> of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) alley and people bowling, loudly!
data.reading_hint: Watch as clusters of pins fall when the bowling balls hit them. You back up and peek through one of the other doors in the cluster and it also houses a bowling alley. Huh.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Where do you put your <radical>fingers</radical> when you're on an <radical>escalator</radical>? On the <kanji>handle</kanji>! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being on an escalator and wrapping your fingers around a small handle on your way up or down. It's still a bit precarious, truth be told.
data.reading_mnemonic: You put your hand on the <kanji>handle</kanji> and an old person leans in close to you and says, "<ja><reading>暑か</reading></ja>?" (<ja>あつか</ja>).
