He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “<ja>暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！</ja>” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him.
data.reading_hint: <ja>暑か</ja>? Is the handle hot? Think about it. Is it? What does your imagination tell you?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> on the <radical>cat pirate</radical> to <kanji>suppress</kanji> him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine suppressing a cat pirate with your own fingers. His fur is so soft, but his nails are so sharp!
data.reading_mnemonic: He forgot, but you know you had to <kanji>suppress</kanji> the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg <reading>yolk</reading> (<ja>よく</ja>). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force.
data.reading_hint: Defend the yolk! Smell the smell of eggs in the air as you suppress the cat pirate. Maybe even share the yolk with him, once he's done trying to kill you for it. And then enjoy breakfast while petting your new cat friend.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Shove your <radical>fingers</radical> into a bowl of <radical>shrimp</radical> to <kanji>select</kanji> the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most.
data.meaning_hint: Feel your fingers touching each and every shrimp, one by one, until they graze the one you select as the perfect shrimp. Slowly pull it out and lower it into your mouth. Munch munch... ahhh! The perfect shrimp.
data.reading_mnemonic: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp <kanji>select</kanji>ion methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a <reading>tack</reading> (<ja>たく</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Oh, woe is me! How will I select the perfect shrimp with my fingers if there are tacks in the shrimp bowls! Boohoohoo!

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you see <radical>flowers</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> you can't help but use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <kanji>draw</kanji> them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine using your fingers to draw these rice paddy flowers. Don't worry about how well you can draw, this is so beautiful, anyone could capture it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even though you tried to <kanji>draw</kanji> the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell <reading>B.O.</reading> (<ja>びょう</ja>). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O.
data.reading_hint: To be fair, would you want to look at a drawing that makes you constantly smell stinky B.O.? I didn't think so.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>boat</radical> holds your <radical>weapon</radical> like a <radical>plate</radical>. So in a way, it's just a <kanji>tray</kanji> for your weapon.
data.meaning_hint: A big boat shaped like a plate is just a tray. You keep your weapons on it, nice and flat.
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, this boat <kanji>tray</kanji> is so big and flat that it keeps reflecting the light into your eyes, so you have to put on a pair of big Ray-<reading>Ban</reading> (<ja>ばん</ja>) sunglasses.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself wearing your Ray-Bans as you look at your tray boat. The steel of your weapons reflect a lot of light into your eyes too. That's why you're wearing Ray-Bans.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>grain</radical> and fashion it into a <radical>gun</radical> that is <radical>small</radical>, earning you the <kanji>title</kanji> of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations!
data.meaning_hint: This isn't exactly a title you're proud of, in fact, you're really embarrassed. Maybe you can make a name for yourself in something else so you can get a new title.
data.reading_mnemonic: Word of your SAD <kanji>title</kanji> makes it all the way to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it.
data.reading_hint: The plaque says, "No one is more deserving of this SAD title." - Love, the Shougun.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>thread</radical> <radical>someone</radical> <kanji>together</kanji> with thread. Someone is falling apart so you use thread to put them back together.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine taking some thread and putting someone back together with it. It’s awfully messy. I hope you’re good with blood.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re threading this someone back <kanji>together</kanji> as part of a <reading>show</reading> (<ja>しょ</ja>). The show is a demonstration to show med students how to thread someone’s skin together after they have an accident. You’re the most experienced, so you’re leading the show.
data.reading_hint: Imagine threading someone back together again, but this time you have an audience. Hear them “ooh” and “aah” as you put on a riveting show.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> on this <radical>football</radical> is <kanji>loose</kanji>. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this football. The thread is loose on the football and needs to be tightened. Attempt to tighten the loose thread on the football as you hold it in your hands.
data.reading_mnemonic: You finally tighten the <kanji>loose</kanji> thread and all of your friends cheer, “<reading>You ru</reading>le!” (<ja>ゆる</ja>) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man!
data.reading_hint: Listen to your friends shouting “You rule!” and hear their cheers echo in your ears as you toss the football around again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> if you put things on a <radical>slide</radical>, <radical>seven</radical> things to be exact, that’s the best way to <kanji>consign</kanji> goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what seven things you consign over to this other person for safekeeping. Visualize them in your head as you slide each one down the slide.
data.reading_mnemonic: One of the seven things you <kanji>consign</kanji> over to this guy is a <reading>tack</reading> (<ja>たく</ja>). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt.
data.reading_hint: Let’s imagine what it would be like to hit this tack while sliding on the slide. It would hurt. Good thing you are consigning it over to someone. Probably safer for everyone that way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The more <radical>shellfish</radical> you <radical>have</radical>, the more you can <kanji>bribe</kanji> people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
data.reading_mnemonic: Welp, the cops found out about your <kanji>bribe</kanji>, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "<reading>WHY</reading> (<ja>わい</ja>)?!
data.reading_hint:
Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything?

And you counter with.

Why not?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone is offering you a <radical>shellfish</radical> in exchange for a <radical>kiss</radical>. This is a <kanji>bribe</kanji>! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty.
data.meaning_hint: "Come on, don't you want this shellfish?" they ask, shaking it up and down at you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You go through with the <kanji>bribe</kanji> and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the <reading>ro</reading>ad (<ja>ろ</ja>). No!!
data.reading_hint: This is why you never accept a bribe. One second you're staring a yummy shellfish in the face, and the next you're standing alone in the road feeling used.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put on the <radical>shellfish</radical> <radical>mask</radical> once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind <kanji>presents</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You're like beach santa, except you're real and you wear a mask made of shellfish.
data.reading_mnemonic: The "<kanji>presents</kanji>" you leave? They are actually just <reading>zo</reading>mbies (<ja>ぞう</ja>). You leave zombies in people's houses.
data.reading_hint:
Ooh hoo, it's me! the Shellfish Mask Man!
I go to beach houses and leave presents where I can!
The presents are not clothes, or anything good.
I don't even care if you leave me some food.
Try whipping some up, try cooking me peas,
It matters not, I'll leave you zombies!

Tee hee hee hee hee!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>scooter</radical> when the <radical>omen</radical> comes so that you can <kanji>escape</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Unfortunately, the omen is riding a scooter too, so you're going to have to be crafty to escape this omen properly.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>escape</kanji> this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. By now, you know <ja>とうきょう</ja> like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way.
data.reading_hint: Imagine scooting in and out of <ja>とうきょう</ja> traffic, the omen looming ever further back behind you. You're doing it! You're escaping!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>scooter</radical> coming toward you with a <radical>net</radical> trapping a weird <radical>zombie</radical> on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to <kanji>send back</kanji> the zombie.
data.meaning_hint: You want to send back this zombie the way it came. You definitely don't want it loose in your neighborhood.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you prepare to <kanji>send back</kanji> the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came!
data.reading_hint: You managed to send back the zombie, good for you! Genghis Khan would be proud.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>run</radical> and <radical>call</radical> out to people at the same time because you're <kanji>super</kanji> <kanji>ultra</kanji> excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling.
data.meaning_hint: You're going for an ultra run, calling out with your super loud voice right down the middle of the street.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're just becoming <kanji>ultra</kanji> tired when you hear a terrifying sound. It's Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>) barreling down toward you. "WERE YOU CALLING FOR ME, CHILD?!" she screams.
data.reading_hint: Mrs. Chou is super ultra scary. And if you don't kick it into super ultra high gear she's going to catch up to you and make you super ultra dead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>three</radical> <radical>slide</radical>s sticking out of this <radical>building</radical> that lead to your <kanji>home country</kanji>. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing at the top of the building and looking down at the three slides that stretch off toward your home country. It takes a few hours to slide all the way there, but at the end you'll be home.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>home country</kanji> is your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Even if you move, even if you haven't been back in years, your home country will always be your home in some way, deep down.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take <radical>gold</radical> in exchange for executing <radical>orders</radical> to construct a <kanji>buzzer</kanji>. You are a <kanji>small bell</kanji> maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you construct this buzzer with your bare hands. Feel the cool metal clink around in your hands as you put it together.
data.reading_mnemonic: Finally the <kanji>buzzer</kanji> is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes <reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do.
data.reading_hint: Wait, should this buzzer be buzzing or ringing? Oh well, you got your gold. It’s the client’s problem now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> of rain falls on a <radical>bear</radical> leaning up against a <radical>cross</radical> stuck into a <kanji>mound</kanji>. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this whole scene. A drop of water rouses the bear and he becomes enraged after he rolls down the mound. Hear the bear roar with anger as he charges up the mound and violently smashes the cross into the ground.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the <kanji>mound</kanji> on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish.
data.reading_hint: Now look at the bear sitting atop the mound with his head in his paws, looking like a fool filled with regret. This bear feels like a fool for attacking the cross like he did.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>branch</radical> will <kanji>branch off</kanji> from the rest.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this part of the mountain, branching off from the rest, into a mysterious path of its own.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>branch off</kanji> from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: If you branch off from the beaten path, you need 1) access, and 2) to be really careful so you keep your head.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> will allow <radical>life</radical> to have <kanji>prosperity</kanji>. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a dark, bleak winter landscape. No life anywhere. Now turn around and look at the prosperity on display in the building you're in. Everyone is happy and eating food and not freezing to death.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>prosperity</kanji> isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (<ja>りゅう</ja>) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed.
data.reading_hint: Ryu's prosperity has made him realize that having things isn't always enough. Now he's looking wistfully outside at the winter weather, missing the rough times.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Whenever a <radical>turkey</radical> comes in the <radical>door</radical>, you <kanji>employ</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine hundreds of turkeys walking in. The word has gotten out amongst the turkey community that if they walk through your door, you'll employ them.
data.reading_mnemonic: Although you <kanji>employ</kanji> turkeys, when a <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>) walks through your door, you send them away.
data.reading_hint: "I will employ turkeys, but I will never employ children!" you exclaim.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Raise your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>sky</radical> to symbolize that you <kanji>abstain</kanji> from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain.
data.meaning_hint: Abstaining from doing what other people are doing is important sometimes. So make sure you never forget the universal abstaining symbol.
data.reading_mnemonic: This symbol to <kanji>abstain</kanji> comes from the <reading>hica</reading>tee (<ja>ひか</ja>) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee is endangered. So people started to rally around it, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming this hicatee!"
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself in Central America. Standing in the water, blocking poachers from the hicatee turtles. "Abstain!" you shout at them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>hot peppers</radical> hiding in this <radical>dirt</radical>, so you build a <kanji>wall</kanji> to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself walking around and seeing a wall around some dirt. You look inside and there are some hot peppers hiding just below the surface. Phew! Good thing this wall was here to protect you from them.
data.reading_mnemonic: On the other side of this <kanji>wall</kanji> there are much less threatening <reading>cob</reading>s (<ja>かべ</ja>) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in.
data.reading_hint: Picture some corn cobs. Now picture some hot peppers. Put a wall between them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> <radical>crab</radical> breaks into your games cabinet and steals a <kanji>chess piece</kanji>. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine finding this tree crab in your games cabinet trying to make off with your chess piece. This tree crab is big and you weren’t expecting to find it in your games cabinet so you’re kind of terrified. You scream in horror.
data.reading_mnemonic: Before the tree crab can make it out with the <kanji>chess piece</kanji>, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what?
data.reading_hint: You put the key in your pocket and call animal control. They unlock the cabinet with the key and remove the tree crab from your home. But who’s to say he won’t be back??

data.meaning_mnemonic:
There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming and you can't <radical>stop</radical> the <radical>explosion</radical> of <kanji>bitter</kanji>ness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and <kanji>astringent</kanji>.

This word also means <kanji>reluctant</kanji>, because wouldn't you be reluctant to let a tsunami come wash you away with that bitter explosion of flavor in your mouth?
data.meaning_hint: You're reluctant to face this bitter end at the hands of a tsunami.
data.reading_mnemonic: With the <kanji>bitter</kanji> taste in your mouth, you <kanji>reluctant</kanji>ly gather up all of your <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it.
data.reading_hint: Try to stuff some of the jewels into your bitter mouth before the tsunami stops you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>one sided</radical> radical and the <kanji>one sided</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: Think of anything that is <kanji>one sided</kanji>. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a <reading>cata</reading>pult (<ja>かた</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine a one sided situation that you've had. Now imagine the winning side with a catapult. For example, a baseball game where one team is destroying the other. That's because instead of a pitcher, they have a catapult.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>buddy</radical> the <radical>sheep</radical> is part of a <kanji>flock</kanji>. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine following your sheep buddy back to his flock. Feel the soft fur of all the sheep around you as they baa peacefully.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now take out your <reading>gun</reading> (<ja>ぐん</ja>) and murder every sheep in the <kanji>flock</kanji>. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun.
data.reading_hint: Feel the recoil or the gun in your hands and the ringing of the shots in your ears as you slaughter the flock without remorse. BANG BANG BANG!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> who lives in a <radical>mountain</radical> is a <kanji>hermit</kanji>. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this odd hermit leading mountain goats around the mountain, marching to the beat of a drum. It’s a strange sight indeed.
data.reading_mnemonic: One day the <kanji>hermit</kanji> was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a <reading>cen</reading>taur <ja>せん</ja>. The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel.
data.reading_hint: Picture this old hermit fighting this centaur in a duel. Who do you think is gonna win? Hear the hermit screaming in agony as the centaur demolishes him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>allocate</radical> radical and the <kanji>allocate</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>allocate</kanji> your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever.
data.reading_hint: Picture all the jewels you were able to buy because you allocated your funds correctly. Imagine swimming in these jewels. Like a rich duck.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>excuse</radical> radical and the <kanji>excuse</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Dandy!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, stop making excuses.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who always makes <kanji>excuse</kanji> after excuse? <reading>Men</reading> (<ja>めん</ja>)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway.
data.reading_hint: Imagine all the men you’ve talked to in your life. Think of every excuse they’ve told you. Think of the worst excuse you’ve ever heard. Remember that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s an <radical>arrow</radical> in that <radical>turkey</radical> and you do everything in your <radical>power</radical> to <kanji>recommend</kanji> that we don’t eat the turkey. There’s an arrow in this turkey. The arrow looks a little broken, so there’s probably splinters all up inside that turkey. I know you’re all hungry but I can’t recommend eating this bird.
data.meaning_hint: You can’t recommend this turkey. It’s probably dangerous. Imagine sending this turkey back in a restaurant, very upset with everything. Also keep in mind that the arrow is half buried in the turkey and looks a little broken since the arrow radical is a bit off.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>recommend</kanji> the Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) special instead of this arrow-tainted turkey! When it comes out, your heart sinks. Genghis Khan apparently ate a cow with an arrow broken off in it.
data.reading_hint: Welp, I guess if Genghis Khan recommends eating food with weapons still in them, you're okay with recommending it too. Eat up, everyone.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> contains a <radical>scroll</radical>, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the <kanji>range</kanji> of the <kanji>sphere</kanji> of your mouth.
data.meaning_hint: On the map, there is a circle drawn around your mouth showing what range your mouth exists in. Thankfully, your tongue and teeth are within that sphere.
data.reading_mnemonic: Looking at the <kanji>range</kanji> of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai.
data.reading_hint: Everything else on the map was accurate, so you take a close look in the mirror, and there he is: a tiny Ken the samurai, protecting the range that is your mouth. He gives you a small nod and goes back to his post.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> next to your <radical>village</radical> is where you <kanji>bury</kanji> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the village where you grew up. Can you see the dirt area where all your ancestors were buried?
data.reading_mnemonic: You don't just <kanji>bury</kanji> dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet <reading>u</reading>ni (<ja>う</ja>) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.
data.reading_hint: Imagine crying as you bury your pet uni. Your tears can't save it now. (Though it is a bit ironic, since it needed salt water.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is something <radical>odd</radical> sticking out of the <radical>dirt</radical>. Oh wait, it's just the <kanji>cape</kanji> jutting out into the water below. Phew.
data.meaning_hint: It's just the cape sticking out into the sea. Haha, for a second... you thought... no...
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>cape</kanji> below looks just like your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories.
data.reading_hint: Picture the cape (the land mass that sticks out into water) but it's shaped just like your old cyborg. Weep a single tear.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>big</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> has to <radical>measure</radical> a safe before he can <kanji>rob</kanji> it. If the safe is too big it won’t fit in his getaway van and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs the place he needs to measure the safe.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this turkey as he tries to rob this safe. See him with the tape measure as he determines whether or not the safe is too big.
data.reading_mnemonic: The safe that the turkey is trying to <kanji>rob</kanji> ends up being <reading>uber</reading> (<ja>うば</ja>) big. Like, really uber big. So uber big that the turkey can’t even measure it with his tape measure. There’s no way he’s gonna be able to rob this place.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the size of this uber big safe. What could be inside? Probably something good.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around with a <radical>gun</radical> while your friend tries to <radical>correct</radical> a <radical>stamp</radical> to make it more <kanji>honorable</kanji>. Someone messed with the stamp machine and your friend is trying to correct the error. You’re loitering around with a gun since you’re his bodyguard. To have an error on the stamp would not be honorable, so that’s why your friend is going to correct it.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the weight of the gun in your hands as your friend works to make the stamp honorable again. Listen to your friend complain about how there are so few people left in the world that are honorable. Also keep in mind that the correct radical is a little different with the vertical line going through the top, so just think of that as the error trying to be corrected.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just as you’re pondering what it means to be <kanji>honorable</kanji>, your friend gets shot by <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (<ja>ご</ja>). Godzilla must have been the one who ruined the stamp! "Go, go, save yourself, Godzilla got me!" your friend cries.
data.reading_hint: You run, leaving your friend and Godzilla to their honorable battle. A single tear runs down your cheek.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When someone wants to view the <radical>reality</radical> of your <radical>soul</radical>, show it with <kanji>humility</kanji>. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility.
data.meaning_hint: Focus on the feeling of humility here. You're putting it all out there, you know? With nowhere to hide.
data.reading_mnemonic: As <kanji>humility</kanji> washes over you, you feel a shaking in your <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground.
data.reading_hint: Imagine humility literally moving through your shins. Can you still stand or do you need to fall to your shins, in humility?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Show your <radical>fingers</radical> to a <radical>giant</radical> to show you <kanji>refuse</kanji> him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding up your fingers to show a giant you're refusing to let him do something. Yeesh, you're brave!
data.reading_mnemonic: What do you <kanji>refuse</kanji>? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops.
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing in front of a giant, refusing to let him crush Little Kyoto. I hope he doesn't stomp on you instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>tree</radical> on <radical>nine</radical> branches are some <radical>cross</radical> <kanji>frame</kanji>s. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the tree bark under your palms as you climb up the tree to take a frame. You get a splinter from grabbing the frame. It really smarts.
data.reading_mnemonic: The cross shaped <kanji>frame</kanji> you took has a picture of the American rapper <reading>Waka</reading> (<ja>わく</ja>) Flocka in it. If you don’t know who Waka is, take the time to YouTube a song of his to get the Waka beat flowin’ through your body.
data.reading_hint: Look at the picture of Waka Flocka as you imagine the sound of his groovy tunes. It almost makes you forget how painful that frame splinter you got is. Almost.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>turtle shell</radical> radical and the <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
data.meaning_hint: Cowabunga!
data.reading_mnemonic: With a <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> on his back, imagine <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Because this is WaniKani, <ja>こういち</ja> has probably set the turtle shell on fire, too. "Burn those turtle shells, burn those kanji!" he yells.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Criminal</radical> <radical>writing</radical> is always <kanji>patterned</kanji>. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters.
data.meaning_hint: Can you see the patterns in the writing this criminal did? It looks like a quilt or some plaid. It's almost beautiful, the way those death threats are arranged!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you look closer at the <kanji>patterned</kanji> writing you realize that it forms the shape of an <reading>eagle</reading> (<ja>い</ja>). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all!
data.reading_hint: Picture an eagle patterned out of cut out letters. What the words say isn't important (though it is asking for a ransom on your grandma), but the underlying image is gorgeous.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>stop</radical>s protecting you, you'll have to go on <kanji>welfare</kanji>. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else.
data.meaning_hint: The next time you see someone on welfare, be nice. Their spirit stopped protecting them, so they need a little more help right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: While on <kanji>welfare</kanji>, you have to do the only job available to you: herding <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it.
data.reading_hint: If you've ever been on welfare you probably already know about the sheep.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> stuck in your <radical>cleat</radical> had a <radical>former</radical> life. In that life it was a <kanji>rice plant</kanji>. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up and cleaned up and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now it's just a sad grain in the bottom of your shoe.
data.meaning_hint: When you look at a grain of rice, you should think of it's former life as a rice plant, not where it ended up.
data.reading_mnemonic: The grain of rice, as it thinks about its <kanji>rice plant</kanji> life too, mutters, "<ja><reading>いな、いね</reading></ja>." Yes little grain, it was a really nice life. I'm sorry.
data.reading_hint: You decide to bring the grain back to where all of the other rice plants are, and they all chant <ja>いな、いね</ja> as you return it to its home. You did a good thing today.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <radical>say</radical> "<radical>Nurse</radical>!" you're ready to <kanji>defer</kanji> to them.
data.meaning_hint: If you say "nurse" you're asking something of a nurse. For this story, pretend like you don't know what to do, so you're going to defer to their skill and let them take over.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>defer</kanji> to the nurse because you're trying to save the local farmhand, <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>), and you can't do it. He's bleeding a lot, and you don't know what to do.
data.reading_hint: It makes sense to defer to the knowledge of a medical professional. When going through this story, imagine yourself trying to revive Jourm, but nothing you do works. That's why you defer to the nurse. "Save Jourm," you say. "He's just a simple, kinda weird, ten foot tall farmhand with nine toes."

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> had more <kanji>modesty</kanji> than any other woman at the time.
data.meaning_hint: Leonardo da Vinci picked her for her modesty. She's so modest she shows no emotion.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>modesty</kanji> of Mona Lisa inspired <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai to become more modest.
data.reading_hint: Have you met Ken the samurai in person? He never smiles, and will never show you his emotions. He's too modest for that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>foot</radical> to kick <radical>Wolverine</radical> in the face so a <radical>turkey</radical> can <kanji>leap</kanji> to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine kicking Wolverine in the head with your foot as the turkey makes turkey sounds in the background. He’s taller than you so you must leap as you kick.
data.reading_mnemonic: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you <kanji>leap</kanji> onto a <reading>yak</reading> (<ja>やく</ja>) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it.
data.reading_hint: Leap! Leap onto the yak. Feel the yak fur beneath you as you ride away to safety, wind in your hair.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to <radical>allocate</radical> enough <radical>gold</radical> to buy a <kanji>gun</kanji>. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins and slabs and bricks.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself handing over an armful of gold bars to buy a single gun.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need this <kanji>gun</kanji> so you can steal some <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store!
data.reading_hint: Picture an old fashioned hold up. You're holding a gun and shoveling jewels into a burlap sack. The heist of the century!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Construction</radical> for <radical>geoduck</radical>s doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> to explain what you're doing.
data.meaning_hint: Actually imagine yourself writing one paragraph of explanation to the city so you can get the permits to construct housing for your geoducks. On the form, it specifies you should only write a paragraph.
data.reading_mnemonic: You turn in your <kanji>paragraph</kanji>, and it is given to Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application.
data.reading_hint:
In that paragraph, you praised <ja>こういち</ja> for being a great emperor, and you said that this construction project would help you to have more time to do your WaniKani reviews. Clearly you were pandering to Emperor <ja>こういち</ja> when you wrote it. But hey, it worked!

Hint: When you see <ja>工</ja> in a kanji it will often take the <ja>こう</ja> reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You come across a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>hill</radical>. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of <kanji>steel</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Dig out many other spots. Every time, it's just steel under there.
data.reading_mnemonic: You report your findings about the <kanji>steel</kanji> you found to Emperor <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel.
data.reading_hint: "I suppose I can use this steel, even if it is not a hill of gold," he says. "We will make steel weapons, which we will use to subjugate other nations. The whole world will learn kanji using the WaniKani system!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>employ</radical> a <radical>geoduck</radical> to <kanji>review</kanji> all your work.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine hiring a geoduck, then ask them to review your work. Please review my writing, geoduck. Please review my record-keeping, geoduck. Please review my taxes, geoduck. This geoduck you employed can review anything for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck <kanji>review</kanji>s your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: The geoduck tells you that while it was reviewing your records, it found information about a child you have. Even you didn't know this, so you're surprised that this review geoduck found something like this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> is your <radical>master</radical> and you are merely a <kanji>resident</kanji> in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a horse as your master. Hear him neigh out orders to you and the other residents of the horse master’s house.
data.reading_mnemonic: To prove yourself a worthy <kanji>resident</kanji> of the horse master’s house, you must capture <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Chewbacca in a cage in the horse master’s house. You’ve proved yourself a worthy resident. Hear Chewbacca making his Wookie sounds as he bashes against the bars of his new cage.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> goes to his favorite <radical>district</radical> to <kanji>gallop</kanji> around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there.
data.meaning_hint: Hear the horse clip clopping around the district as it continues to gallop. Clip clop, clop clip clop!
data.reading_mnemonic: Then the horse <kanji>gallop</kanji>s into the road and gets hit by a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it.
data.reading_hint: The tires screech, the horse neighs, BAM! Total destruction everywhere. Bystanders scream in horror. That horse will never gallop again. It’s a sad day for all horsekind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> is the <radical>master</radical> of a <kanji>pillar</kanji>. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master.
data.meaning_hint: See the pillar next to the tree master. See the pillar bow over and over in veneration of its tree master.
data.reading_mnemonic: While bowing, the <kanji>pillar</kanji> accidentally smashes <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished.
data.reading_hint: Hear the crack and snap of branches as the tree beats the crap out of the pillar for having murdered Chewbacca. Unforgivable.

data.meaning_mnemonic: It's time to do the <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>sun</radical> <radical>sun</radical> <kanji>chant</kanji>. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears.
data.meaning_hint: Open your mouth and practice the chant right now! Sun sun, sun sun, sun sun!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're doing this <kanji>chant</kanji> because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun is glaring intently at you as you chant. Open your mouth as wide as you can, get all those "sun suns" out, and pray that the sun will appear.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Teacher</radical>s are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of <kanji>filial piety</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Respect your elders, for they have much to teach us.
data.reading_mnemonic: With <kanji>filial piety</kanji> in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: I am so ignorant and have much to learn. I must show filial piety to my father, <ja>こういち</ja>, so that he may teach me.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of all the <radical>spider</radical>s is a <kanji>genius</kanji>! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the leader of the spiders weaving it's own little spider computer. Doing spider math, and spider chemistry. It's a genius!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the spider <kanji>genius</kanji> you realize that <reading>soon</reading> (<ja>しゅん</ja>) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs.
data.reading_hint: Soon we'll be slaves to the genius spiders. Soon we'll be the flies.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa <kanji>concurrently</kanji>," says your art class teacher.
data.meaning_hint: Pay close attention to the students around you. Don't go too fast or too slow, or you won't finish concurrently.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your entire class finishes <kanji>concurrently</kanji>. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai.
data.reading_hint: It's a nice painting, the frown is just right, and you finished concurrently with everyone else, but you're probably going to fail this class.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Simultaneous</radical>ly, you throw your <radical>knife</radical> at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a <kanji>dose</kanji> of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed.
data.meaning_hint: Watch as the dose of poison sinks into your body through the knife that's in your chest, as it simultaneously happens to the other guy too.
data.reading_mnemonic: "I need a <kanji>dose</kanji> of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny <reading>xy</reading>lophone (<ja>ざい</ja>) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?"
data.reading_hint: Now you're begging them for a dose of the xylophone drug. Just a taste, you want to live!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You attempt to expel wind out of your <radical>mouth</radical> but <radical>lack</radical> the breath to <kanji>blow</kanji> out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so.
data.meaning_hint: Blow some air out of your mouth. It’s easy, right? Imagine what could cause you to fail at this activity.
data.reading_mnemonic: You silly <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>), the reason you couldn’t <kanji>blow</kanji> any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you.
data.reading_hint: Attempt to blow air out of your mouth while covering it with your hand. It’s hard to do, right? Only a fool would try to blow air out of their mouth this way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're driving, you may notice the <radical>flag</radical>s in the <radical>dirt</radical> near the <radical>exit</radical>s. These flags mark the <kanji>ditch</kanji> running along the side of the road. You won't want to try to exit the road here or you'll end up stuck in one.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the flags in the dirt. Picture the ditch just over the edge of them. Now look for another way to exit this road, cause that way is just not a good idea.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you do end up veering into a <kanji>ditch</kanji> you'll find yourself yelling, "<reading>Holy</reading> (<ja>ほり</ja>) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch.
data.reading_hint: It's a pun, get it? Holy. Hole-y. The ditch is a long hole. See? It's funny.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're using your <radical>scooter</radical> to navigate the <radical>flood</radical> because you're on <kanji>patrol</kanji>. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine patrolling the flood waters on your scooter, which is bubbling and scooting along on the surface of the water. You have to be extremely vigilant in your patrol, you don't want any lives to be lost on your watch.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>patrol</kanji> all of the floods in <reading>June</reading> (<ja>じゅん</ja>). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot.
data.reading_hint: You're in a group with a bunch of other scooter people, and you're all assigned to one month of flood patrol duty. But you got June. The floodiest month. Womp womp.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>drunkard</radical> issued <radical>twenty</radical> <kanji>commandment</kanji>s to his people.
data.meaning_hint: He basically just made up a bunch of commandments to order all the other drunkards around and decided having twenty (twice the amount of that other religion he heard about) would be a good number.
data.reading_mnemonic: The drunkard is yelling out his twenty <kanji>commandment</kanji>s to the others at the bar, but they're all about <reading>ka</reading>yaks (<ja>かい</ja>).
data.reading_hint:
Commandment 1: Thou shalt not touch my kayak
Commandment 2: Thou shalt not look at my kayak
Commandment 3: Thou shalt give me beer to put in my kayak

It goes on like that for a while...

data.meaning_mnemonic: Raise your <radical>fingers</radical> to a <radical>criminal</radical> to <kanji>reject</kanji> their request to have your things. If someone is trying to steal something from you, just reject them.
data.meaning_hint: "Talk to the hand, I mean, fingers!" you say, <kanji>refus</kanji>ing the criminal.
data.reading_mnemonic:
After you <kanji>refuse</kanji> him, he recites this <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>) at you: 

You are very mean / What's a criminal to do / But haiku at you.
data.reading_hint: You refuse to listen to any other haikus and you push your fingers into the criminal's face and walk away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> to shoo a <radical>turkey</radical> down the <radical>stairs</radical> and into a <kanji>portable</kanji> carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers.
data.meaning_hint: Turkeys aren't portable on their own. I mean you could pick one up I guess, but it will bite and poop on you. So get it in a portable carrier first.
data.reading_mnemonic: You needed the turkey to be more <kanji>portable</kanji> because you're going to be bringing it to a <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference.
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting a portable turkey cake made of your pet turkey. It's made of turkey friendly cake mix.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>winter</radical> you are <kanji>alert</kanji> for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself out in the winter wilderness. You hear twigs snapping, growling, leaves rustling. You’re incredibly alert and aware of everything going on around you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Being the <kanji>alert</kanji> fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash <reading>bin</reading> (<ja>びん</ja>) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe.
data.reading_hint: Listen to the sasquatch rumble on by as you continue to smell the smelly smells of this putrid bin you’re in.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have <radical>gold</radical> you also need a <radical>guard</radical> with a very <kanji>sharp</kanji> sword to protect it.
data.meaning_hint: You should probably also get some sharp spikes, sharp traps, and sharp spears to keep that gold safe too. Just a bunch of sharp stuff.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a <kanji>sharp</kanji> <reading>a</reading>corn (<ja>えい</ja>) that's just laying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea!
data.reading_hint: Imagine covering the floor around your gold in sharp acorns. This is basically a Home Alone situation, and anyone who tries to steal your stuff is gonna get stuck full of sharp things and probably stabbed by your guard.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>cross</radical>, you walk through the <radical>rice paddy</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <kanji>spread</kanji> your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine facing the direction of the approaching winter while facing away from the rice paddy. Feel the weight of the cross in your hands as you spread your arms and implore the winter to hold off on its arrival.
data.reading_mnemonic:
You’re actually a <reading>Sheikh</reading> (<ja>しき</ja>) (an Arab leader) which makes the fact that you’re holding a cross while you <kanji>spread</kanji> your arms even more of a big deal. You spread your arms wider than any Sheikh ever has before.

Side note: The official kun'yomi reading is just <ja>し</ja> but since no vocab words ever use <ja>し</ja>, we're teaching you <ja>しき</ja>, which includes what used to be okurigana but is never used outside of the kanji anymore.
data.reading_hint: Feel the strain on your Sheikh arms as you continue to spread them. Since you’re a Sheikh, you have to set a good example for your people, so don’t let them (or your arms) down.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the same <radical>flag</radical>, all the people get <radical>together</radical> to present a new <radical>weapon</radical> to your <kanji>lord</kanji>. You all bow and say, "<kanji>Milord</kanji>, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord.
data.meaning_hint: When you address your lord you better say "milord," otherwise you might get beheaded with the weapon you're all giving him.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you give the <kanji>lord</kanji> his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, <kanji>Milord</kanji>?" you ask. "THERE'S A <reading>DEN</reading>T (<ja>でん</ja>)!" he bellows.
data.reading_hint: Oh no, oh no, oh no! Now the lord is running around with his dented weapon trying to put dents in all of you. You don't want a dent in your head! Run!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cow</radical> of <radical>righteousness</radical> is always there for us. He is the cow that must <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> himself for us to survive.
data.meaning_hint: The reason he is sacrificing himself is so we can all eat! Yum! Thanks to your sacrifice, righteous cow, we all have hamburgers. You should think about all the cows you ask to die for you every day. Maybe say thanks next time.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> must be done via <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing.
data.reading_hint: Of course, the reading is also shared with kanji like <ja>義</ja>. The righteousness radicals seems to have that effect on kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see an <radical>animal</radical> with some <radical>flowers</radical> and a <radical>turkey</radical> on a <radical>stool</radical> trying to <kanji>seize</kanji> them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this turkey straining itself on the stool trying to seize the flowers, grunting with effort. You think he’ll ever get them?
data.reading_mnemonic: The animal the turkey is trying to <kanji>seize</kanji> the flowers from is a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this scene again only with a big cock holding the flowers as the turkey attempts to seize them. Hear the cock shouting cock-a-doodle-doo as it defends its flowers.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take <radical>flowers</radical> down a <radical>slide</radical> to a <radical>drunkard</radical> that you picked from your <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
data.reading_mnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your <kanji>luxuriant</kanji> garden that he begins to <reading>mo</reading>an (<ja>も</ja>) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.
data.reading_hint: Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Every</radical> <radical>winter</radical> the <radical>thread</radical> fields become <kanji>overgrown</kanji>. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to wade through this overgrown field of thread. It’s really difficult, and also it’s really cold because it’s winter. You shiver. Imagine chopping the thread down with your machete. Chop chop chop!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason this field of thread got so <kanji>overgrown</kanji> is because you’re <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as Han Solo, bravely blasting your way through the overgrown thread with your blaster. Pew pew pew!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>walk</radical> by a <radical>geoduck</radical> a <kanji>frequent</kanji> amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking around near this geoduck. This is the best area to frequent when you want to look at the geoduck. Just keep looking at it as you walk.
data.reading_mnemonic: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because <reading>Hin</reading>du (<ja>ひん</ja>) people <kanji>frequent</kanji> this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people.
data.reading_hint: Look at all the Hindu people as you walk around and observe the geoduck. Hear them all speaking Hindi as you continue to walk around.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you go to the <radical>yakuza</radical> to <radical>fix</radical> your problems they'll just <kanji>multiply</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You thought you had problems before? Yikes, now you've done it. The yakuza are just going to make all of your problems multiply!
data.reading_mnemonic: Just like I said, your problems <kanji>multiply</kanji> before your eyes and give you quite a <reading>shock</reading> (<ja>しょく</ja>). You really shouldn't be shocked though, because I warned you this would happen.
data.reading_hint: Feel shock envelop your entire body as late payments multiply into more debt, and the number of people mad at you multiply too. You can't even think from the shock of it all.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> are being worked upon by a <radical>tsunami</radical> with a <radical>specialty</radical> for knowing how to <kanji>dilute</kanji> things. The tsunami can dilute the flowers by pouring itself onto it. A tsunami can dilute things because it is made of water. You could say that it’s its specialty.
data.meaning_hint: Look at the flowers as they begin to dilute. Their color and fragrance and dimensions become weaker and more spread out. It’s really trippy to witness.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch the flower <kanji>dilute</kanji>, you determine that this is obviously a nature <reading>hack</reading> (<ja>はく</ja>). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature.
data.reading_hint: As you continue to watch the flower dilute due to the water being poured onto it by the tsunami, imagine what techniques this tsunami is using to hack nature. Is the tsunami a super cyborg from the future? Maybe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>go</radical> somewhere but you're too <radical>heavy</radical> you'll <kanji>collide</kanji> with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all.
data.meaning_hint: Imaging being too heavy to go anywhere without colliding with things.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're going around the town, you <kanji>collide</kanji> with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun is glaring at you from the ground. "You've been colliding with my entire city and now you collide into ME?!" Smoke blows out his nostrils.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There’s <radical>grass</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and the <radical>fins</radical> there <radical>say</radical> you have no <kanji>honor</kanji>. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor.
data.meaning_hint: Listen to what the fins have to say as they flop around on the ground in the grass. Hear them swish about as they flop, brushing up against the blades of grass.
data.reading_mnemonic: Being one of little <kanji>honor</kanji>, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<ja>よ</ja>). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have.
data.reading_hint: Imagine taking your yo-yo out to do this. Feel the string tighten around your finger as you unleash the yo-yo and silence all the fins.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Lift the <radical>lid</radical> off your <radical>preserve</radical>s, <radical>kick</radical> it, and <kanji>praise</kanji> the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be!
data.meaning_hint: You also praise the lid. And praise the plants and animals that gave you the food.
data.reading_mnemonic: You do this <kanji>prais</kanji>ing in your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects.
data.reading_hint: If you're going to praise the ingenuity of the invention of the "lid" for its preservation methods, you should definitely do it from home. Or at least from the internet from home. Find your people where you can, you know?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> you made out of <radical>grain</radical>s and are about to ride down the <radical>stairs</radical> is completely <kanji>transparent</kanji>. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this transparent scooter. Well, it's actually a bit hard to see, because it's see-through. I guess imagine the outline and the feel, as you perch at the top of your stairs.
data.reading_mnemonic: You slip, the <kanji>transparent</kanji> scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back!
data.reading_hint: Almost immediately you lose track of the scooter because it's transparent. All you see is <ja>とうきょう</ja> in front of you. And no scooter. Maybe this is why people don't make transparent vehicles.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside that <radical>building</radical> someone is doing a <radical>rice</radical> <radical>dance</radical>. That someone is your <kanji>neighbor</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your neighbor doing a rice dance, whatever that may be, in the building next to yours. That's your neighbor, for ya.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>neighbor</kanji> has an incredible <reading>rin</reading>g (<ja>りん</ja>) that they use for their rice dance.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the ring your neighbor has as overly extravagant. You have to make it wild enough for you to remember. Maybe it is integral to their rice dance. Perhaps you covet your neighbor's rice dance ring.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>fang</radical> on a <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>elegant</kanji>. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this turkey with a fang. It’s elegant, but also frightening. See the fanged turkey staring at you menacingly.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>elegant</kanji> fang makes the turkey look more like a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (<ja>が</ja>) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle!
data.reading_hint: Picture this elegant gargoyle sitting in front of you. Reach out your hand and feels its hard, elegant stone gargoyle body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're in <radical>prison</radical> and all you have is a <radical>spoon</radical>. You use that prison spoon to scoop up nice <kanji>scent</kanji>s and <kanji>fragrance</kanji>s out of the air when you have outdoor time and bring them back into your cell.
data.meaning_hint: It smells really bad in prison, but your prison spoon is full of all of the lovely scents you remember from when you were free.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't remember what any of these <kanji>scent</kanji>s are anymore, you've been in prison for so long, so you call them all <reading>neo</reading>-scents (<ja>にお</ja>). They're neo, they're new.
data.reading_hint: Try to come with some neo-scents right now. This is neo-laundry, this is neo-flowers, and this is neo-delicious-steak I'll never get to eat because I'm in prison sniffing a spoon.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> is <radical>rejoic</radical>ing. She must be <kanji>glad</kanji> and <kanji>happy</kanji> to rejoice out loud in front of you like this.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a woman rejoicing loudly. She's got a big smile on her face and she wants you and everyone else to see how glad she is.
data.reading_mnemonic: "I'm so <kanji>glad</kanji>!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys.
data.reading_hint: You'd be happy too if you'd just found your lost keys. Though maybe you wouldn't shout it for the entire world to hear.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>skewer</radical> radical and the <kanji>skewer</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo.
data.reading_mnemonic: Uh oh, this <kanji>skewer</kanji> is really... <reading>cushy</reading> (<ja>くし</ja>). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to use this cushy skewer. It's the right shape (long, thin, pointy at one end), but every time you try to put something on it it squishes in on itself like a long marshmallow.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> has some hidden <radical>horns</radical>, and if you have the right <radical>alcohol</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> in your body, those horns will come out of your mouth in the form of <kanji>rumor</kanji>s and <kanji>gossip</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It's really easy for to let a rumor slip if you've had a certain amount of alcohol. And those rumors have horns, they're dangerous.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you start to tell a <kanji>rumor</kanji> or spread <kanji>gossip</kanji>, you're a little drunk, so you slur you words. "<reading>Ooo I saw</reading> (<ja>うわさ</ja>)..." is how you start every rumor. It's got some southern drawl to it almost (Uuuwahsahw).
data.reading_hint: If someone who looks a little drunk comes up to you and starts with <ja>うわさ</ja>, there is a 100% chance what follows is gossip.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have something to <radical>say</radical>, you <radical>stand</radical> on a <radical>towel</radical>, and shout, "I <kanji>GIVE UP</kanji>!"
data.meaning_hint: Standing on a towel is the universal signal for giving up, but you still need to say you're abandoning whatever it is with your mouth too (just in case).
data.reading_mnemonic: After you announce that you are ready to <kanji>give up</kanji>, you throw all of your <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots onto the ground. You have <kanji>abandon</kanji>ed your goal of eating all of them.
data.reading_hint: Look at the tater tots at your feet. You feel ashamed for giving up but you were so full, you had to give up! Now they're all down there mocking you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>fingers</radical> to grab this guy's <radical>foot</radical> and <kanji>catch</kanji> him! Not physically though, you do grab his foot, but you close your eyes, and catch the idea of him in your mind just by touching your fingers to his foot.
data.meaning_hint: You don't really like the idea of touching your fingers to someone's foot, so you do it ever so slightly, and only catch the gist of what it's like.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you touch his foot, you <kanji>catch</kanji> a glimpse of the <reading>Torah</reading> (<ja>とら</ja>) in your mind. Suddenly, you are able to grasp and understand every single thing written in the Torah. You fall to the ground.
data.reading_hint: You wipe your eyes and look up, seeing that the person running from you is wearing socks with little pictures of the Torah on them. You were able to catch that in your brain but not the person. You must have touched those Torah socks and not his foot. You've been tricked!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>moon</radical> beneath a <radical>tree</radical> there is a <radical>hat</radical> filled with <radical>water</radical>. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your <kanji>knee</kanji> in it.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the water splash over your knee as you stick it into this hat. It fits really well, the hat is the perfect size for your knee. Now look up at the moonlight filtering through the tree above.
data.reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, in your <kanji>knee</kanji>, you feel <reading>he</reading>at and a <reading>za</reading>p (<ja>ひざ</ja>)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hat water!!
data.reading_hint: Imagine the heat then the zap going through your knee. It isn't a nice heat, it's a hot heat, then BZZZT zap! Your knee was heat zapped pretty bad.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're holding a <radical>flag</radical> on a <radical>stick</radical> above your <radical>eye</radical>s to imitate <kanji>eyebrows</kanji>. You can't grow any of your own, but you really love eyebrows, so this was the best you could do.
data.meaning_hint: Look at yourself in the mirror. You can see the stick holding up the flag and it's very clear you drew some eyebrows onto the flag with some markers, but you still look pretty good (in your opinion).
data.reading_mnemonic: Underneath your fake <kanji>eyebrows</kanji> are two slabs of <reading>me</reading>at (<ja>み</ja>). Meat helps hair grow, according to many Internet specialists who also happen to sell meat. You're waiting for this meat to foster eyebrow hair, and when that sweet day comes you won't need these flags.
data.reading_hint: Imagine walking around town, holding your eyebrow flags. You can feel the meat sticking above your eyes. They stink and they're weirdly lukewarm, but you know your real eyebrows will grow under them any day now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits, it's <radical>rain</radical>ing, and you're outside trying to use a <radical>rake</radical>, you're going to be very <kanji>wet</kanji> and <kanji>damp</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how wet and damp you'd be with tsunami water up to your knees and rain pouring down on your head. You struggle with your rake anyway.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't stand how <kanji>wet</kanji> and <kanji>damp</kanji> you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the <reading>nu</reading>de (<ja>ぬ</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: You're still wet, but at least you don't have the feeling of damp clothes touching your body now. You'll have to be really careful raking in the nude though.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You are so <radical>sick</radical> that you've come to look like the <radical>humble</radical> <radical>stool</radical>: <kanji>thin</kanji>. Eerily thin, in fact.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing behind a stool and being able to disappear behind it completely. That's how thin this sickness has made you.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you're this <kanji>thin</kanji>, your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) is visible from outside of your body too.
data.reading_hint: Picture your soul pulsing through your thin body. You have no body fat to cover it up, so everyone can see it pulsing and lurking in there. This is why you're hiding behind one of the humble stools in your house.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Horns</radical> grow on the <radical>king</radical> that will be <radical>next</radical> because they're full of <kanji>envy</kanji> and <kanji>jealousy</kanji> for the present king.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the person next up for king. They have to sit in a chair behind the current king, and as they glare in front of them with envy, horns start to sprout out of their head.
data.reading_mnemonic: If they can't control their <kanji>envy</kanji> and <kanji>jealousy</kanji>, they'll start growing hooves and extra legs, until one day, they turn entirely into a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>)! A jealous centaur, who will never be king.
data.reading_hint: Centaurs can't be the next king, so people really need to be careful about how much they let jealousy consume them. If you don't watch out, you'll turn into something ugly and twisted.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A mix of <radical>spirit</radical> and <radical>reason</radical> helped you invent the <kanji>sleeve</kanji>. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born!
data.meaning_hint: Your spirit and your arms are free! Imagine how unreasonable no sleeves were. How on earth did you survive without them?!
data.reading_mnemonic: To make the <kanji>sleeve</kanji> holes you took your <reading>shoe</reading> (<ja>しゅう</ja>) and kicked a hole through your shirt. Then you did it again on the other side, because you have two of those weird arm things.
data.reading_hint: You also take the extra fabric that helped make your sleeves and turned them into another pair of really light shoes, since they're shoe shaped from the whole process anyway. Waste not!

data.meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>woman</radical> comes down from <radical>heaven</radical>? A <kanji>supernatural</kanji> one. She is so <kanji>enchanting</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your idea of what an extremely supernatural woman would look like, and have her come down from heaven towards you. You're totally enchanted by her looks.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>supernatural</kanji> woman comes down in front of you and she's so <kanji>enchanting</kanji> that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Touch the supernatural yogurt woman and feel the yogurt. Taste the yogurt, what flavor is it? It's totally enchanting you further.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>World</radical> <radical>Tree</radical>, all it does is <kanji>chat</kanji> and <kanji>talk</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You'd think the World Tree's mouth would talk wisdom, but all it does is chat, chat, chat.
data.reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>chat</kanji> or <kanji>talk</kanji> with the World Tree, just head over to <reading>Sha</reading>man <reading>Bay</reading> (<ja>しゃべ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The locals shorten Shaman Bay to "Sha Bay," because they always go there to <ja>喋る</ja> with the World Tree. Imagine all the shamans hanging about in the bay.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>fish</radical> jumps from <radical>dirt</radical> to <radical>dirt</radical>? A <kanji>salmon</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: When you're at the river watching salmon jumping up stream, they keep jumping onto the dirt, flopping back into the water, then doing it again.
data.reading_mnemonic: You make a drinking game out of watching the <kanji>salmon</kanji> going up stream. Every time one jumps onto the dirt, you drink a shot of <reading><ja>酒</ja></reading> (<ja>さけ</ja>). You realize you're drunk when you ask for more <ja>さけ</ja> but it comes out as <reading><ja>しゃけ</ja></reading>.
data.reading_hint:
Salmon. Drink <ja>さけ</ja>. Salmon. Drink <ja>さけ</ja>. Salmon. Drink...

"Ughhh.... I'm feeling tipsy... Hey, where's my <ja>しゃけ</ja>!?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>roof</radical> every <radical>evening</radical> you meet with <radical>snake</radical>s. All snakes know your <kanji>address</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You're snake famous. Snakes go on a pilgrimage to your address every evening. Your address is passed down from snake generation to snake generation.
data.reading_mnemonic: The snakes come to your <kanji>address</kanji> every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: <reading>a 手</reading> (<ja>あて</ja>).
data.reading_hint:
"You only give a <ja>手</ja> a night. Newcomers might have a <ja>手</ja> or two, but some snakes who have been coming to your address for years have hundreds of <ja>手</ja>s.

They are human hands."
